output: Mr. President, first of all, I would like to congratulate Mr. Sieb for the work done, because in his report many of the concerns expressed in this...
The Chamber is debating these crucial issues for the entire European Union. These are water scarcity and drought, issues that are no longer just a problem for the countries of southern Europe.

I am pleased that this project incorporates some of the reflections made in the opinion report of which I was rapporteur in the Agriculture Committee, in favor of agricultural activity, highlighting, for example, the role that farmers play in the sustainable management of available resources.

It also includes a reference to drought and water scarcity as factors that aggravate the prices of raw materials, an aspect that I also consider very important to point out in these times, so that we are aware not only of the environmental dimension of this problem, but also of some of its most relevant economic consequences.

The Environment Commission also included the idea of creating a European Drought Observatory, an action that is mentioned in the Agriculture Commission report and that I hope will one day be reflected in concrete facts.

The text to be voted on tomorrow, however, includes a proposal made by the Agriculture Commission to study the implementation of an economic adaptation fund against drought, a fund that would benefit all economic sectors, including agriculture.

For my part, I would like to make it clear that I will continue to defend the establishment of this fund, an idea that I will propose again to Parliament when the communication that the Commission is expected to publish on climate change adaptation arrives in the coming months.

I think that after the Solidarity Fund was established, which was created to mitigate the losses caused by climate disasters, it is time to think about an instrument that acts a priori and is intended to finance prevention measures to reduce the environmental and economic cost of those climate catastrophes.
Atlético de Madrid, the fans and even the Spanish police are being mistreated by the European Football Federation.
But the case goes beyond the particular, since those federal bodies aggravate the sanctions for those who resort to ordinary justice.
This medieval conception, this funnel law, is incompatible with the law, with European institutions, from which we must react.

And we will end up doing it, because those medieval gentlemen, arbitrary with the gallows and the knife, must fall in line with respect for the law and the ordinary procedural guarantees of our Europe.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, terrorism is a global phenomenon and so is the action of serious organized crime. Therefore, the measures must be proportional and must be fought effectively.

I have taken good note of the answers you have given to the questions that were timely. It is true that guarantees must be demanded, it is true that it is a delicate matter, but it is no less true that it is absolutely inexcusable to mount, to form a globalized and harmonized response.
For some, terrorism is a distant concern, and they are more worried about individual freedoms.
I am concerned about both individual and collective ones. And it is absolutely necessary that we start where we can.
If we are going to start with air transport, where the companies already have that data, let's start there.

Let's demand guarantees, let's see what the scope of application is, let's start with international transport relations and, beware, we will have to continue with the internal ones because terrorists often come from within rather than from outside.
that they ask the United States and that they ask the others, that it is like this and that we will have to face it like this.
Mr. President, I would like to thank the Commission for presenting this proposal.
I think it is a positive proposal and that it will help us to reduce unnecessary administrative burdens.
Well, as the speakers who preceded me have said, this Parliament has the obligation to bring to earth what are very generous and very altruistic proposals on the part of the Commission.

The reality is that there is a national reality in which there are 27 countries with different legal systems and with very different languages, which requires that in each one of those countries we adapt to the realities of the country, including the issue of languages.

Specifically, as Gossés has just pointed out, and as the previous speakers have pointed out, it is important that the recognition of these national specialties does not lead to an increase in costs, that the rates are uniform and that the governments eventually assume that additional cost.
But there is also a topic that appears, which is the topic of translations.
Specifically, in the European Union we do not have a common language.
In the 27 countries, very different languages are spoken, and even in some countries, such as Belgium, different languages are spoken and we live with this.
From a legal point of view, we are also faced with the reality that legal documents are different.
In the Legal Commission, the Legal Commission has proposed, for example, amendments on the authentication of the minutes of the documents, together with the authentication of the translation.
At this moment, the Legal Affairs Committee is preparing a report on the recognition of authentic acts in different countries of the European Union, which should be complementary to this report.
In short, I believe that the Commission has done well in presenting this report.
The rapporteur has done a magnificent job and I believe that we have all made an effort to make a legislative proposal that can be recognized by the Union as a whole, guaranteeing the rights of
Rights and starting from the bases of the reality of a union that is being built, that has different national orders and that has different levels of access to electronic communication.

Thank you, Mr. President. A large majority of farmers and ranchers are waiting for decisions and previous agreements that the Council of Ministers of Agriculture of the Union will adopt today and tomorrow on this check of the...

The CAP, because it is not just a simple review, but it will bring about profound changes, such as the disappearance of many farms, if the cut in direct aid proposed by the European Commission goes ahead.

Modulation is the central point of this parliamentary report and could be one of the few elements of the Parliament's opinion with some impact on the negotiations that the Ministers of Agriculture of the Union are maintaining.
We have been opposing for years any increase in what we euphemistically call modulation, because if the rural development policy does not have sufficient funds, it is not possible to
not for lack of resources within the spending ceiling of the PAC, but for an absolute lack of political will to provide the community budget with the necessary development pillar.
Pilar. Do you want to liberalize the markets?
Of course, do it, but with the same requirements and conditions for all producers, those within and outside the Union.

At this time, the European Union is playing the future of many farmers and livestock breeders, and I would like to make special reference to the fragile sectors such as sheep, cattle or tobacco, whose survival in many producing areas will depend on this check.

Some producers, such as sheep farmers, no longer ask for help, but simply want to be allowed to leave the market with dignity, because they have done the math and the only way to survive is to reduce the volumes produced.

Therefore, the abandonment of production is the only way out we leave to many producers, whose space will undoubtedly be occupied by imports from third countries, because the consumer will not stop consuming and the world will not stop increasing the number of consumers at a rapid pace.
The Parliament should issue a prudent opinion and the Council should listen to it.

I thank the President of the Agriculture Commission for the efforts made by Mr. Parry so that the Parliament is heard and not so clearly and openly ignored by the Council and the Commission as it has been until now.
Thank you, Mr. President. First of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr. Capoulas Santos, for his magnificent work.
I believe that you have found balance and moderation in your report.
I think that what is important at this point in the debate is to send a message of stability to our farmers.
European farmers need stability and solutions more than ever.
It is necessary to have sufficient transition periods, as well as to maintain specific measures that are necessary for sectors in difficulty.
Madam Commissioner, the same solutions are not valid for all sectors.
We must remember that there are sectors that are going through real difficulties.
The Common Agricultural Policy should not be the problem, but the solution, and for that we need a strong first pillar.
We believe in and support rural development, but we do not believe that the modulation proposed by the Commission is the solution.
It is not about strengthening rural development at the expense of the first pillar.
We agree that the single payment scheme needs to be simplified, and that the market instruments need to be reviewed.
But that does not mean dismantling them.
If we do it right, we will be laying the foundations for a Common Agricultural Policy beyond 2013. If not, we will be putting an end to the activity of many European farmers.

We are facing a plan that has been highly anticipated by the fruit and vegetable sector, not only because of the difficulties it is going through, but also because of the worrying decrease in consumption.
We are facing a public health promotion plan. I believe it should be a European plan and I also defend full community funding.

I do not agree that parents should be able to co-finance, because the same thing will happen as always: the children of parents who can contribute money will eat fruit and vegetables at school, and those who cannot will be left out of the program.
I think it has to be a plan funded by the community so that its distribution is homogeneous.
For this reason, I also want to emphasize that we must focus on educational measures.

It is not just about a student eating an apple, but knowing what type of apple they are eating, knowing its nutritional properties and understanding the beneficial effects that this fruit has on their health and development.
Of course, it must be a product of all quality guarantees, giving priority, if possible, to seasonal fruits and, when possible, I defend the community origin of our fruits and vegetables.

I believe that the beneficial effects of this plan, which I applaud and for which I want to congratulate the Commissioner, will be noticed immediately, of course, for the present and future health of our children and their education.

...food, but also I think it is very important for the fruit and vegetable sector, a productive sector that constitutes a genuine European cultural heritage. Thanks to it we can enjoy a balanced, healthy and varied diet.
I think it is worth betting on and investing in this plan to distribute fruit and vegetables in our schools.
I think the budget is a bit short because I repeat that I defend the full community financing of a plan as ambitious as this one.
Yes, thank you, Mr. President. I ask you not to include these first words in the time machine, please, because my
My first words are to join the message of condolence expressed by this Chamber to Mrs. Clam and, above all, to congratulate the speakers.
Now I really start.

I congratulate the speakers because with these two proposals we are taking a qualitative step towards a common immigration policy and we are entering the promotion of legal immigration, a key pillar of the global approach that we defend.
The general framework of rights and the single permit for residence and work for legal immigrants should be extended to the largest number of workers.
That is why the socialists ask that no category of workers be excluded.
The so-called blue card provides an opportunity for immigrants to settle with their families and work in our countries.
It opens a unique door to 27 labor markets.
Now, through this door, not only highly qualified workers should enter.
For this reason, we hope, Mr. Commissioner, that the Commission will soon present its proposals regarding the other labor categories.
Ladies, we must fight against the brain drain.
This blue card should not become a passport that favors a brain drain of vital human resources in developing countries.
For this reason, from the Socialist Group, we want that for every qualified professional that comes to Europe, we fund the training of a new professional in the country of origin.
Lastly, Europe must be an attractive destination not only for talents coming from outside the Union, but also for our own.
In 2007, almost 300,000 highly qualified Europeans left to work outside the Union.
Let's do everything possible to keep them in the European House.
Madam Vice President, do you think that the closeness or distance of the candidates to the voters has to do with the degree of participation in the European elections?
European. Do you agree that a state with 45 million inhabitants should have only one electoral constituency for the European Parliament elections?
What can the Commission do so that the most populated states can have constituencies closer to the citizens?
Excuse me, but I haven't heard the Vice President answer my questions.
Thank you very much, Madam President. You have given me a lot of information about the topic I raised and I thank you for that detailed information.
I believe that the new stage of the Commission is important and, above all, the Bamako project of a European Union center on immigration.

I know it has just opened, which is probably very soon, but the question I ask the Commission is, in the event that the Bamako-Valletta project on immigration issues yields good results, does the Commission believe it is possible to extend that experience to the rest of the countries on the southern shore of the Mediterranean?
I appreciate the answer on behalf of Mr. Yáñez, but I must tell the Commissioner, Mr. Michel, that his actions, words and gestures are very necessary in direct and regular contact.
really with the Cuban democratic opposition to fulfill the Council's priority conclusions and reduce the effects of the terrible Castro dictatorship in favor of freedom.
Mr. President, on behalf of the Socialist Group, I wish to express the strongest condemnation of my group of the murders being committed in this region of Somalia in the name of God.
Few atrocities have been committed by someone who has not invoked the name of God or a religion.

Specifically, the way in which this atrocious murder was committed, we already know, a 13-year-old girl who is raped and then accused of adultery, and that five men, if they can be called men, rush to stone her and even prevent anyone from trying to save her, in a stadium occupied by a thousand people.
This, together with the acts of piracy that this year, on the coasts of Somalia, have reached the level of almost 100 ships seized, constitutes an absolutely unacceptable humanitarian situation.
The international community cannot remain indifferent to this.
It cannot remain indifferent to cowardice, to the invocation of religion to commit atrocities,
Therefore, we must restore order by supporting the legitimate government of Somalia in regaining control of the entire country and establishing a state of law that respects human rights.
I believe that on few occasions have we been presented with such a clear situation and that imposes obligations on us.
I do not think that we can remain here, indifferent, in this community of 500 million people and 27 countries, the most important in the world, without intervening in this situation.
I don’t know how it can be done, but I do believe it must be done and that we must act quickly.
The Socialist Group does not agree with the amendments that have been presented at the last minute, which were not negotiated at the time.

We support the text of the joint resolution and hope that this will be the beginning of a greater concern of the European Union for this type of humanitarian issues and for the rejection of the abusive use of religious concepts to commit atrocities in the name of God.
I believe that the rapporteur and the speakers who preceded me have highlighted the characteristics of this proposal of the Parliament and the Council.
It is a matter of recognizing that weapons and ammunition are also part of the internal market, although of course with a series of limitations.
These are not ordinary goods, they are not candies or entertainment items, but objects that require precise control.
Of course, there are limitations in the treaty itself, in article 30 and article 296, which confer important responsibilities on the States in this matter.
The fact that we have a common market does not prevent States from being obliged to comply with security standards and having the right to apply them when their own security is at risk.

The work done in the Legal Affairs Committee and in the opinion committees that have collaborated with it, in accordance with the Council, under the expert direction of the Chairwoman, Mrs. Ruile, has been very positive.
I believe that the text we are presenting today is a very balanced text.

Basically, although on paper there seem to be many amendments, today we are limiting ourselves to a single amendment, which is amendment 63, which captures the spirit of compromise, and in that amendment you can see a well-articulated, coherent text that will allow the operation of this entire market.
Mr. Toubon has emphasized that this is related to other international texts.

For example, the adoption this month of the Oslo Convention, the signing of the Oslo Convention on the prohibition of cluster munitions, also the convention on the limitations of antipersonnel mines, and a whole series of international agreements and even European Union regulations aimed at limiting the use of weapons.

I believe that our model is not the model of the free circulation of weapons at any time, but rather a regulated market, controlled by the States and also controlled from now on by the European Union institutions.
Madam President, Commissioner, this proposal left the Commission more than a year ago, with truly very ambitious objectives.
And in this time there have been financial convulsions in the world that seemed to be going to sink these measures. But finally a balanced agreement has been reached that does not...
It does not satisfy almost anyone 100%, but it is a good agreement, which maintains the final objectives, but makes the means to achieve them more accessible to companies.

That is why we must thank and congratulate rapporteur Mrs. Doyle, the rapporteurs of the other political groups, and the French Presidency, especially, because their work has achieved a good result for all.

I trust that in the near future the circumstances will allow us to be much more ambitious and that there will be other countries that will also join this crusade against climate change that we so want to carry out in Europe.

Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. This was a good proposal as it came out of the Commission, not only for the sulfur reductions, but also for its new Article 7bis, which required suppliers to provide...
gradual reduction of greenhouse gas emissions and because it solved the old problem of vapor pressure for gasoline mixtures with bioalcohol in countries like mine with hot summers.
Precisely this did not pass the vote filter in the Environment Commission and this worried us a lot.
Today we have an agreement on the table that softens the application of article 7 bis and that resumes the waiver of vapor pressure, of course, hardening the conditions to access the exception.
And that, like the rest of this climate package, the agreement does not satisfy everyone 100%, but it is acceptable to everyone.
I would like to thank Ms. Corbey for her excellent work, for her willingness to solve problems, as well as Mr. Turmes and, of course, the French Presidency, which has also made a great effort here.
As the report says, "According to 2007 estimates, Zimbabwe has a population of 12 million, almost half of whom are starving."

Life expectancy is 36 years, and only 40% of the country's teachers are working, and only a third of the students are attending classes. So, Boko Haram is not only killing the present, it is killing the future.
The repression and mutilation of human rights is also on the agenda.
Human rights defenders in Zimbabwe have been systematically targeted with arbitrary detention, arrest and torture.
The legislation introduced by the government severely restricts the freedoms of expression, assembly, movement and meeting.
I would like to mention some of them, since the government has introduced increasingly repressive regulations, which have been used against these human rights activists.

For example, the Law on Access to Information and Protection of Privacy, used by the government to effectively silence journalists; the Law on Public Order and Security, which has severely limited freedom of assembly and hundreds of

Human rights defenders, including independent media workers, have been arbitrarily detained, and the 2002 Law on Private Voluntary Organizations, restored by the government, is allegedly being used to intimidate and harass NGOs.
Madam President, in my mother tongue, Basque, which is not official in this Chamber, Mugabe means "without limits", a good nickname for this character.

The dictator of this African country is not just one more in the long list of dictators that, unfortunately, we have on this planet, but I dare say that he occupies one of the top ten positions of dictators.
I think that in the EU we must do everything possible to make this person leave and end his days sitting in front of a human rights court.
We wish Zimbabwe a happy 2009 without Mugabe.
We have a draft resolution on Nicaragua in which we must consider different aspects.
First of all, there is an allegation of fraud, at least in two municipalities, Nicaragua and León, and this taints the electoral result of November 9.
On the other hand, we have a government that has been concerned with solving some of the problems that eliminate human rights in Latin America.
Specifically, poverty, illiteracy, infant mortality, access to drinking water and lack of ownership of indigenous lands.
So, when examining the case, we will have to perfectly distinguish the two aspects.

On the one hand, we have to promote human rights and we have to defend human rights in the traditional sense as political rights. And on the other hand, we have to encourage the Nicaraguan government to continue with its function of helping the most needy sectors of the country.
Of course, we must ensure that the opposition can perform its function, we must oppose fraud, but we must also defend the work of NGOs.
But, however, we must have a balanced result.
The Socialist Group has presented several oral amendment proposals, trying to guide the final text so that it is more balanced with respect to the claims of...
Regarding violations of fundamental rights, the criminal or not nature of the investigations, and the number of municipalities in which the effect has been produced, some type of derogation.

In short, we want to condemn the alleged violations of fundamental political rights, but without going to the extreme of placing the Nicaraguan government in a difficult situation to continue fulfilling its function of supporting the most needy sectors of society.
In a few minutes, we will discuss the situation created in Nicaragua by the attacks against some human rights defenders, against some fundamental freedoms, and against democracy.

It is not necessary to remember here and now Soy la América, nor Ernesto Cardenal, nor Carlos Mejía Godoy, nor Jarkín, nor Sergio Ramírez, nor so many other Nicaraguans who today feel betrayed in their hopes for a better Nicaragua.
In November 2006, Mr. Ortega asked for and obtained, democratically, from the Nicaraguans what he called a new opportunity.
Today we know why he wanted her.
Since then, arbitrariness, nepotism and corruption have settled in the government institutions, which have culminated in the electoral fraud of the elections on November 9.

Before that, very serious decisions had been made, such as the cancellation of the legal status of some opposition parties, threats and intimidation of members of civil society, journalists and media outlets.
President Ortega described the European Union governments as flies that swarm over filth and described the foreign aid that Nicaragua receives as crumbs.
He soon realized that there was not enough Venezuelan oil to do without that development aid.

As we are about to enter a decisive phase in the negotiation of an association agreement between the European Union and Central America, the Government of Nicaragua must know that it will always find in us an ally and a friend.

But for us, the demand for respect for human rights, freedom of expression and democracy in general, is a condition that we do not renounce because we believe that the people of Nicaragua especially benefit from it.
The municipal elections in Nicaragua were held on November 9th.
As in previous occasions, this electoral process has been questioned from the point of view of democratic legitimacy, with accusations of fraud being made and protests taking place.
Demonstrations and clashes between supporters of different political parties, with the result of numerous injuries and a deepening of the political crisis that this country has been suffering.
Two political parties were not able to run in the elections, which is unacceptable because it violates the fundamental right of all citizens to political participation.

On the other hand, we have received direct testimonies from representatives of human rights defense organizations who have informed us about the existence of a questioning of the judicial system by civil society.

On the existence of administrative mechanisms of repression that have taken up to 17 organizations of social movements to court, on the persecution of independent journalists and even the delegation of the European Commission.

For all this, we want to raise our voice and make a call, first to the political parties so that they condemn the acts of violence carried out by their followers, and second to the government itself so that spaces for participation are reopened.
Citizen, respect freedom of expression, stop prohibiting marches and let all NGOs receive international cooperation aid, not only those from Venezuela for pro-government associations.
Likewise, that it repeal the penalization of therapeutic abortion in cases of danger to the life of the mother.

And finally, we also want to ask the Commission that the negotiations of the Association Agreement between Central America and the European Union remind Nicaragua that it must respect the principles of the rule of law and democracy.

Democracy and human rights, all of this without prejudice to the fact that from Europe we continue to provide our help for the development and well-being of the Nicaraguan people, whom we wish to have the best possible future.
Madam President, I will refer to the Breyer report.
I must say that European farmers are fully aware that the use of plant protection products must pay particular attention to human health and also to the protection of the environment.
However, the sector is deeply concerned because the European Parliament does not understand the impact that this regulation may have in the future.
And it is that there are evaluations of its potential impact that indicate that due to the scarce future availability of phytosanitary products, it will be very difficult to...
Control of pests and diseases that affect the cultivation of a large number of foods, specifically all Mediterranean products, as well as the cultivation of ornamental plants and cut flowers.
I am fully aware that the agreement adopted in the three-way dialogue has been the result of hard negotiations and I cannot help but recognize the work done by the speakers.

However, it should be noted that the temporary definition of endocrine disruptors will lead to the disappearance of a large number of active substances, especially insecticides, which are of key importance for agriculture.

Producers must have a sufficient amount of active substances available to effectively and safely combat any plant disease or pest, bearing in mind that the danger is often not in the product itself, but in the misuse of it.
For all these reasons, the Spanish delegation of the PPE group supports the proposals that request an impact assessment and will vote in favor of the amendments.
by Mr. Stardust, which I myself have signed, regarding endocrine disruptors and those that facilitate the availability of phytosanitary products in emergency cases.

Moreover, if this regulation is adopted in the terms of the agreement reached, the effects will be a reduction in food production and a rise in prices that will lead us to import the same foods that we do not produce, treated with the products that we are prohibiting.
Mr. President, Mr. Capato, your report is full of good intentions. The most evident proof is that it did not deserve any amendment during its processing in the Committee on Civil Liberties.
You were the one who introduced 18 amendments to your own report.
And those amendments are the ones that have introduced a plus of radicality, so to speak, in general terms, into that report, which raises very serious doubts for me.

I would propose the amendments you have put forward in four different statements, which you have put forward to yourself, I insist, in a report that received the support of all the groups at the beginning.
Some are impossible. You have asked for some things that are impossible.

For example, Mr. Capato, you are asking for things that do not have a legal basis yet. For example, while the Lisbon Treaty is not in force, it will be impossible to harmonize the regulations of different commissions.
Something similar to what Commissioner Wallström just said. Or you ask, for example, that we declare 2009 the year of transparency. We are late, there is no more time.
Therefore, you are asking for things that are impossible.
In addition, it requests some others that are not advisable.
For example, you ask for transparency in the meetings of the political groups.
No, sir.
What is needed is citizen privacy, privacy is a political good.
If I want to disagree with my party, to maintain an opposition, I want to do it in private, and that is not a lack of transparency.
Transparency must be demanded in public bodies, but not within the parties, where debates must be guaranteed within privacy.
Therefore, I cannot follow you on that.
There are some other assessments that you make, Mr. Capato, that are uncertain.
For example, you say, “90% of legislative activity is pro-forma.”
That is a reckless exaggeration, Mr. Capato.
And, moreover, criminology carries implicit norms of transparency in itself.
If we are going to create more mechanisms, more bureaucracy, more controls, we will be going against what we want to achieve, which is transparency, something that is very close to simplicity.
Lastly, before the President calls me to order because I am already consuming my time, there are some things that are unnecessary.

For example, I understand that it is very popular and very attractive to public opinion to say, let's make the activity of the deputies transparent, let's make it known that they come to the plenary sessions.
We already know, Mr. Capato.
Or they go to the committees, it is already known, if there is a record of all of them, they are acts accessible to all citizens.
Or the diets they charge, it is already known, Mr. Capato.
That is, it is perfectly possible for a citizen to have access to that information.

Therefore, I understand that it is very popular with the public and that it is very fashionable to defend transparency, but I want you to know that transparency is about making things seen as they are. And when one contributes to things not being seen as they are, Mr. Capato, then we are not contributing to transparency.
Thank you for your generosity, Mr. President.
The situation in Gaza with horror, pain and shame, but also with the commitment to defend peace and those who suffer the most and to maintain dignity and hope.
Horror at the repeated scene of murdered children and women torn apart in their endless suffering after the bombings of the ghetto that Gaza has become.
The same horror that Picasso painted in his Guernica, our Guernica, razed by the Junkers of the Condor Legion seven decades ago.
Pain in solidarity with so many victims of so much suffering.
and shame for the inability of all, of our states, of the European Union and of the international community, first to prevent and then to put an end to the criminal aggression that we denounce.
Shame and indignation for so many lies, so much ambiguity and so much talk.
Shame because we know exactly what is happening and we do not act with the necessary and required firmness and consistency.
Therefore, history will demand an account from many as accomplices of the crime, at least by omission.
Because better late than never and because it is essential to keep a door of hope open, the European Union should support the belated resolution of the Security Council. But there will be...
We must do what we must do, and we must comply with our association agreement with Israel, which provides for its suspension in the face of conduct such as that which is taking place.
By the way, Jamás is also responsible for the media blackout that I have not heard anyone denounce so far.

We must clearly and firmly tell Israel to stop killing, to allow the wounded to be treated and the affected to be fed, and that its attitude against international law must have consequences in its relations with Europe.
I want to greet the few young European cooperators who are suffering along with the people of Gaza, particularly Alberto Arce.
They represent the best of the values of solidarity and freedom of this Europe of ours, which must be consistent in this terrible conflict.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, as we can see, in recent times the textile sector is suffering a major crisis that has led to numerous business closures, relocations and unemployment, facts that are concentrated precisely in regions specialized in this activity.

In the current economic crisis situation, the European Commission should act quickly alongside the Member States to mitigate the socioeconomic effects of this restructuring, which is especially dramatic for the affected territories and families.
I think it is necessary to help workers in the textile and clothing sector with social measures, with plans for companies that are being restructured and that are currently in serious trouble.
It would be desirable to allocate a substantial part of the Globalization Adaptation Fund to the restructuring and requalification of the textile sector.
In particular, small and medium-sized enterprises, which make up the majority of the sector in the European Union and which suffer the most from the effects of market liberalization.
On the other hand, it is necessary to restore the control system of imports from abroad and especially, due to its volume, from China.
It is not at all about promoting trade barriers.

It is about compensating for the negative effects of such an important transformation. And we must not forget that the European Union is the second largest exporter of textile products and clothing in the world.

invest, which makes it necessary to ensure the best conditions of access to the markets of third countries, essential for the future of the textile and clothing industry based in the European Union and especially for SMEs.
All this, of course, always guaranteeing fair competition based on the promotion of environmental and social standards in these countries.

In this sense, the publication of the correct information to the consumer, for example, with the regulation on the indication "Made in", which, as far as we know, has not been implemented, would be of great use, since
Among other things, this would imply subjecting imported products to the same safety and consumer protection requirements as those manufactured within the European Union.
Mr. Romeva, the Spanish government will not worry, it will cooperate as it has always done.

I remind you that in this matter, the Spanish Minister of Foreign Affairs, Miguel Ángel Moratinos, was the first to appear before the Investigation Commission and the one who answered all the questions, including yours.

From this Chamber, we have been denouncing for some time the torture and inhuman and degrading treatment that was being committed at the Guantánamo military base in the name of the fight against international terrorism.
For this reason, we applaud Obama's decision to suspend the trials for four months and his intention to close the prison permanently within a year.
However, although the responsibility lies with the American government, the Union cannot look the other way and must offer its collaboration to achieve the closure of the detention center.
We should also consider the possibility of receiving those prisoners who come from countries where human rights are not guaranteed, if the United States does not request it.

We will have to give a common European response, in which the Spanish government will participate, respecting the international legal framework and analyzing, case by case, the legal situation of each citizen, of each detainee, their origin and detention and their situation.

Mr. President, in the EU there are several cases of languages of historical European peoples that, because they are not established as states, are not allowed to be used in the debates of this Parliament, and this is a democratic and representative deficit.

One of these cases is that of the Basque language, which is not a minority language but an official one, at least in the southern part of the Basque Country, which is administratively part of the Spanish State.

But the same does not happen, and do not take it personally, Mr. Commissioner, with the Northern Basque Country, which is part of the French State, whose president, before the UN Assembly, states that denying respect for national identities and languages is to feed humiliation and that without that respect there will be no peace in the world.
And then, neither Basque, nor Corsican, Breton or Occitan have the slightest official consideration nor do they have support to respect and promote their use.

For this reason, I ask that the Fundamental Rights Agency, BELI, work to ensure that the rights of the mother tongue of any European people are not violated within the Member States, nor are their inhabitants discriminated against, and that all of them are considered official within their respective territories.
The European Union is a political and economic union of 28 member states that are located primarily in Europe.

Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank our rapporteur, Claudio Fava, for his great work in reaching a common position with the Council, which includes many improvements proposed by our Chamber.
With this directive, we demonstrate once again our commitment to building a common migration policy based on a global approach.
The purpose of this directive is clear: to fight against mafias, to punish unscrupulous employers and to protect exploited immigrants who have no social protection.
We want to eliminate the unfair poverty wages for immigrants that also distort average salaries, especially in sectors such as construction, agriculture, domestic service or hospitality.
These measures require great courage and political will, since there are many vested interests and a lot of money involved in the underground economy.
Precisely in difficult times, it is more important than ever to manage migration flows intelligently, with generosity but also with responsibility.
It would be so easy to give in to the temptation of not trying to curb the underground economy.
We cannot look the other way and leave some 8 million undocumented immigrants in a state of helplessness with working conditions close to slavery.

Ladies and gentlemen, if we want this directive to be effective, rigorous inspections and economic sanctions, and even criminal ones in the most serious cases, are necessary, which have a deterrent effect on businessmen.
We will thus be able to reduce the underground economy and cut the migratory incentive that is generated by the possibility of working irregularly.
It must be clear that the only option to work in Europe is the legal way.
Therefore, we want to continue with the global approach and ask the Commission, Mr. Commissioner, Mr. Baró, to present as soon as possible the new "blue cards" for the other labor categories.
Dear colleagues, Ms. Ferrero-Waldner, Mr. Solana, I would first like to thank the three speakers for their work, and as a shadow rapporteur on the PESC report, I will refer to...
I would like to start by congratulating Mr. Saryusz-Wolski for the result of his work and for the collaboration he has offered to the other groups to achieve a consensual result.

In the same way that this Parliament has demanded on numerous occasions that the European Union be equipped with the necessary instruments to speak with one voice in the world, the Chamber itself must show cohesion around the evaluation and promotion of the major priorities in common foreign and security policy.

Our group's commitment, the Socialist Group, has gone in two directions. On the one hand, to introduce or reinforce major issues that are key to us in a transversal manner to all foreign policy, such as the fight against climate change, the promotion of the

Peace on the entire planet or a bet on human development. On the other hand, to propose elements of rebalancing between the geographic priorities of the ESS, in relation to how they originally appeared in the text, if they appeared, or to introduce them as a new element if they were absent.
In this way, we have advocated, for example, for a greater clarification of the relations between the institutional and cooperation frameworks involved in the recently defined Eastern dimension.
We have defended greater diversification and greater relevance of relations with Africa, a continent that we often only remember when especially virulent wars occur, and many times not even then.

With regard to Latin America, we have wanted to reflect the current negotiation processes of association agreements, the first of a bi-regional nature that the European Union will conclude in its entire history.

As for the Mediterranean, we have opposed a reductionist approach that only speaks of security, to include instead the entire rich political, economic and socio-cultural heritage contained in the Barcelona Process.

As for the amendments to the plenary, our group has not presented any, believing that in some way this reinforces the balance achieved with the commitments and therefore we will oppose most of the amendments so as not to weaken the commitment reached in the Foreign Affairs Committee. Thank you.
Mr. President, the Venezuelan referendum has ended with a victory for the "yes" vote, elegantly recognized by the democratic opposition.

It is no less true that there has been no equality of opportunities in the campaign and that the government has had the overwhelming support of the entire state apparatus, while the opposition has suffered constant harassment and coercion.
Even under these conditions, the country has been practically divided in two and it will be very difficult to build the future with only one of them.
The European Union must promote dialogue, inclusion and consensus among Venezuelan political and social actors for the good of the country.
It is not with visceral attitudes, disqualifications or insults that we will help Venezuela to find its democratic, pluralistic and free path.

In this sense, we criticize the decision of the Venezuelan government to expel a Spanish MEP, and even more so the manner in which such expulsion was carried out. But we call on this Chamber to avoid...

That our representatives make statements during their visits to third countries that violate the local legislation in force and much less that they insult a head of state, however criticizable he may be.
With this attitude, we are compromising future missions of the European Parliament to other countries.
Mr. President, I have just arrived from Venezuela, where I was invited by its electoral power as a member of an international electoral accompaniment group for the referendum of last December 15.

The European members of that group have submitted a report to the National Electoral Council with a positive overall assessment of the process in terms of its organization, transparency, participation, free and secret exercise of the right to vote and security in all its phases.

Regarding the statements made by Congressman Herrero to a Venezuelan television station, I would like to point out that they seek to delegitimize the ongoing electoral process, they make serious accusations against the democratic institutions of that country, and they border on interference in the internal politics of a sovereign country.
Our Parliament should not provoke any kind of confrontation with the democratic institutions of Venezuela.
On the contrary, it would be up to the deputy to give explanations to this Chamber about an action that affects us all.
The Budget Committee considers it of the utmost importance to clearly define each of the budgetary instruments.

Therefore, the most realistic option seems to be the creation of a new instrument for actions different from public aid for development of the countries that fall within the scope of the said regulation.
From a budgetary point of view, the financing proposal from the Development Commission does not seem appropriate, since this money does not exist.
These lines do not have a multi-year credit assigned. There is a credit for 2009, but not beyond.
In any case, given that the financing of this new cooperation instrument must be compatible with the 2007-2013 financial framework, it is appropriate to
Remember the importance of the mid-term review of the financial framework, which should allow for an adjustment of the maximum limits of the different headings.
Well, at this late hour on Monday, the Commission will probably have other things to worry about more than this report.
In short, what we are doing is simply responding to a report from the Commission, a report on the application of Regulation 1206/2001 of the
Council Decision of 28 May 2001 on the mutual recognition of decisions on supervision measures as an alternative to provisional detention.

We are in a field that is really not community-based, it is an intergovernmental field, in which, from the Council, through the regulation, an attempt has been made to stimulate cooperation between those judicial bodies.
But in doing so, I think that there is a certain lack of rigor on the part of the European Union.

That is, certain measures have been foreseen, for example, the issuance of practical guides, the use of electronic media, etc., but I recognize that it is quite difficult for the Commission to take action.

I don’t know what the Commission has achieved or intends to achieve, but I think it is quite difficult to achieve it because of the enormous difficulty that this form of intergovernmental cooperation constitutes.

That is, we are asking judicial authorities that collaborate with each other, we are talking about 27 countries, judicial authorities that handle 22 different languages, with very different legal systems, and we are trying to achieve results.
The Commission has found that the results are not good, that there is a huge delay in these cooperation mechanisms and, of course, that we do not have the means to do it.
The ideal would be to have material resources.
For example, what could the Commission do to provide the judicial bodies, especially those of a lower level, with technological elements such as a videoconferencing system?
Video conferencing may be a utopia in many small courts in the European Union, but it seems to be the only way to do it.
I believe that the European Union should rely on existing institutions, specifically the European Judicial Network.
We would have to strengthen this institution so that the judges themselves, through their recovery systems, could develop this type of communication.
On the other hand, everything that has to do with the training of judges is fundamental.
This is something that the Commission cannot do on its own.
However, the Commission can encourage the development of this type of training courses in Community Law and in the knowledge of the different legal systems.
Then there is a huge difficulty, which is the problem of languages, that is, how can a Spanish judge communicate with a Finnish judge when the two languages are so different.
It cannot be expected that judges, in addition to having to deal with their own law, which is already complex enough, are obliged to have knowledge of this type of code.
What can we do from a practical point of view to make the task of interpretation and translation easier for judges?
Translation: What could we do to help them do it?
When presenting this report, did you show any rigor or harshness towards the Commission?
I think the work is quite difficult.
What I would like to know, taking advantage of the fact that we have here a commissioner who is interested in this topic, is what the Commission thinks can be done to give greater relevance.
rigor to this 2001 regulation, which is a bit imprecise, a bit voluntarist, and I do not know if from a practical point of view it can have any consequence or if it can be advanced with it.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I am very pleased to be able to conclude the current legislature with the final approval of the last of the maritime packages.

However, I remember that when I arrived at the European Parliament in 1999, we suffered a major maritime accident, that of the Erika ship, near the French coasts, which gave rise to a first block of legislative proposals aimed at cutting and avoiding accidents.
We thought we had averted the danger, but shortly afterwards the coasts of Galicia were ruined by the oil spill from another accident even greater than the first, that of the Prestige.

Since then, in the Transport Committee, we have worked on successive legislative packages, trying to overcome the excessive resistance we found in shipowners, oil companies, classification societies and also in certain Member States that rejected our proposals because they considered them too demanding.

Over these ten years, we have approved different directives and regulations, some of which we have had to review again because, due to the cuts made by the Council, they were not effective in their first draft.

We approved the regulations for the introduction of double-hulled ships, the European Fund for Major Oil Spills, and ports of refuge, and now we are reviewing and approving the liability of sea passenger carriers, the investigation of the...

maritime accidents, the Community system for monitoring and information on maritime traffic, the control by the State of the port of registry and, finally, the regulation and directive relating to ship inspection and recognition organizations.
All of this is good and desirable, and it should come into force and be applied by all Member States in the shortest possible time.
I am satisfied with that.
But the legislature ends, I leave Parliament and I go with the pain of not having achieved that the introduction of control systems, which exist and are used in other countries,
They are patented to know when and how much bilge and fuel tank waste has been illegally dumped into the sea by a particular vessel.
That is, a kind of black boxes or tachometers that can be inspected by maritime authorities every time a ship arrives at port.

I believe we owe the marine environment better attention and more severe procedures to curb the pollution we produce, and if we do not do so, it will affect our food chain and our lives, making us pay a high price.
I hope that we do not have to wait another ten years to control illegal marine discharges more effectively and efficiently.
Mr. President, the review of the Eurovignette Directive is a matter of great importance that concerns and worries us all, especially the peripheral countries, who feel like victims of this proposal.
The European Commission has decided to address the internalization of the external costs of road transport by adding three new costs: air pollution, noise pollution and congestion.

Although the principles that inspire the proposal, "whoever uses pays and whoever pollutes pays", are reasonable, the solution proposed is not, as it will be discriminatory for a sector that has been suffering for months the disastrous effects of the economic crisis.
The demonization of road freight transport, even if it was not the objective, has ended up being the result.

This proposal, ladies and gentlemen, is ill-timed and, far from achieving the expected objectives of sustainable transport, would be a death sentence for a large number of small and medium-sized European companies that employ thousands of people.

There are people in the European Union who contribute daily to the distribution of goods, ensuring that products reach their final consumer, who will see their products become more expensive due to the application of these rates.
Ladies, we need a competitive, sustainable and environmentally friendly transport system, without neglecting the road, because at present it is the only way to get everywhere.
The modal shift continues to be a dream, far from being a reality.
The trans-European networks, the motorways of the sea, the cross-border connections are still projects, not realities, in some cases.
Ladies, when the titan of the global economy sinks, it is not possible to ask the orchestra to keep playing, much less for joy.

Mr. President, on 15 July 2008, the European Commission adopted a communication addressed to the Council and the Parliament recommending the establishment of a strategic association between the European Union and Mexico.
For its part, the European Council on Foreign Relations, on October 13, recognized Mexico as a strategic partner, pending the opinion of the Parliament on the matter.
Let us remember that in the seventh meeting of the Joint Parliamentary Commission of the European Union-Mexico, held at the end of October of last year, we said that a
The strategic association between Mexico and the European Union is a necessary boost to strengthen and develop the true potential of our bilateral relations.
We note the good moment of the relations between both parties and the positive balance of the current global agreement.

We insist on the need for our respective executives to strengthen political, economic and maximum cooperation in the face of the new challenges of all kinds derived from the financial and economic crisis that is shaking our continents.

With the great country that is Mexico, we share values and objectives such as the development of democratic forms of government, the commitment to gender equity, the consolidation of the rule of law, equitable and sustainable development, and respect for human rights.

We advocate for strengthening cooperation in the fight against organized crime, terrorism and drug trafficking based on the principles of shared responsibility and strict adherence to international law.
Consequently, we will support the proposal of recommendations on the strategic association between the European Union and Mexico, which will be submitted to Parliament this very morning.
I would like to congratulate all the speakers on the microcredit report because they have done a great job.
The Commission's initiative has undoubtedly improved.
I understand that the recommendations established here will allow us to be the basis for developing a genuine framework in the European Union for the microcredit sector, a sector
which has been a success in many developing countries, even in some European ones, both as a mechanism for economic activity and as an instrument to improve social inclusion and job creation.
but it had not been transferred to the sector or to the community context. And I think it is an opportunity to do so, especially starting from the economic and financial context in which we are.
It is a priority, in that sense, to reinforce the initiatives that are being advanced here, but more steps need to be taken.
The funds available for this microcredit support structure must be increased.
We must facilitate availability for people and companies that do not have access to loans and in that sense I would like to highlight, Madam President, the example of...
The European guarantee for microcredit loans as an instrument that can facilitate access and that is included in the report.
And I end by thinking that this will undoubtedly lay the foundations for us to create a harmonious framework in the European context that will boost the microcredit sector.

Madam President, taking advantage of the fact that we are talking about the budget, I understand that we must prepare ourselves for next year to negotiate the continuity of the aid for coal, an indispensable source of domestic energy.

And I say this with due notice, because in an improper manner, a high-ranking official, confusing public opinion, allowed himself to give an opinion to the contrary, leaking it to an economic publication.
None of that.
We will have to continue supporting my country’s coal after 2012 and I want it to be recorded in the minutes.
Gentlemen officials, limit yourselves to complying with the current plan and then, starting in 2012, with the instrument that we will begin to negotiate with the sector next year.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, this question, as Mr. Bockland has explained, is very timely, given the diplomatic conference on the ship recycling convention that will be held in May.
For this reason, I would like to congratulate Mr. Blokland, not only for the question, but also for the resolution he has prepared.

In the Popular Party, we are in favor of the fight against the bad practices and methods that have been used to dismantle ships, and therefore we support the resolution proposal of Mr. Brockel. But there are some points that worry us.

The first is section 3, which he also pointed out, which states that ships in their entirety must be considered hazardous waste and, as a consequence, must be within the scope of the Basel Convention.

We have presented an amendment on this section because there are different interpretations within and outside the European Union and we understand that the Basel Convention must be taken into account and not contradicted, but it must be the future international agreement on ship recycling that defines the details of its application.
The resolution proposal also requests, in its point 14, a funding mechanism based on mandatory contributions from the maritime transport sector.

We believe it is really a bit premature to talk at this time about mandatory contributions when it has not yet been decided within the IMO what the system will be that will be adopted for this financing. And it seems to me that the European Commission does not have a clear answer on this matter either.
Finally, in point 15, the Commission is urged to clearly establish that the State with jurisdiction over waste is the responsible State.
We believe that it is the Commission’s responsibility to decide this, which should also be decided in an international convention.

The important thing is to ensure the coherence of the future agreement on ship recycling and the Basel Convention on the transboundary movement of hazardous waste and its disposal, and all of this taking into account not only the Basel Convention but all existing legislation.

Madam President, Madam Commissioners, colleagues, the first thing I would like to do is congratulate the rapporteur, with whom we share a great deal of agreement regarding this programme, and congratulate ourselves, because in times of economic crisis it is essential to maintain a programme like this, with clear positive social effects.

Although we are facing a consultation procedure from the European Parliament, we must send a clear political signal that in these times of economic uncertainty, from Brussels and Strasbourg we are not exclusively concerned or obsessed

We are not only concerned about the recovery of the financial system, but we are fully aware that social policies, especially those that support those who need it most, the poorest in the European Union, must grow.

This food distribution program should continue to be considered part of the Common Agricultural Policy. We agree with the Commission on this. Not only because European agriculture has a strong social character, but also because it is a working tool, because it is needed more than ever now, and because it should continue to work.

From the Socialist Group, like the speaker, we are against this program being co-financed between the European Union and the Member States, as this would mean discrimination between States according to their wealth, and it could happen that the program cannot be implemented in the most needy countries.

It is not understood that now, when it is most needed, the Commission wants to save community money in the most social aspect of the CAP, especially considering that there are budget surpluses in the agricultural budget every year.
Community pre-financing is essential for us.
We need to ensure that this program reaches all countries and especially the most needy.
43 million potential beneficiaries of this program demand a greater effort from us and in no case should budgetary expenses be saved.
Austerity, yes, but not for the poorest.
And it is precisely to ensure that it reaches the citizens of all Member States that the program must cover the entire journey of the distributed food.

For this reason, from the Socialist Group, for which I am responsible for the report, we have presented an amendment so that all expenses derived from distribution, including those of transport, storage, and administrative, are covered with community funds.
We also agree with the rapporteur that food should preferably be local and of good quality.
It is a consistent position with the one held by this Parliament in other similar programs that we recently discussed in this Chamber, such as the case of the school fruit distribution plan.
Nothing more and thank you very much.
We hope that the Commission will take into account the position of this Parliament when it votes and, above all, that the plan will be implemented in the European Union as soon as possible.
The Arctic region is one of the most fragile regions on our planet.
The consequences of unrestricted exploitation of its natural resources would be catastrophic not only for the immediate environment and the indigenous population, but for the world as a whole.

The melting of large areas has brought these risks to the fore, making it necessary to have a new global regulation to protect the Arctic, similar to the one that already exists for the Antarctic, taking into account the differences that have already been highlighted in the debate.

An international treaty is needed among all the parties involved, including the European Union, to protect its unique environment, ensure the fully sustainable nature of all types of human activities, and regulate navigation through the new maritime routes that are becoming accessible.
The Arctic Council, during its many years of existence, has been a model of cooperation to manage common problems.

In these times of difficulty and uncertainty, we must raise to higher levels that spirit and that harmony to avoid that the states of the area or other international actors get involved in geostrategic struggles, forgetting what should be the common objective, the preservation of a great shared heritage.
Mr. President, unlike the two speakers who just preceded me, I agree with most of the speakers.
This is a good directive, an excellent directive aimed at protecting interpreters.
When we talk about the need to find a smarter way to do business, what we are really talking about is the end of intellectual property.
Because business can only be done if there is an established right.
Do we already have an established right at the national level?
The Commission, under the leadership of Mr. McCreevy, has adopted a bold initiative, a positive initiative, and I believe that the House should approve the commitment that we have made.
It has been achieved in the field of the Committee on Legal Affairs, thanks to the work of the rapporteur, Mr. Crowley, and the different shadow rapporteurs, such as Ms. McGuill and Mr. Tugendhat.
I think it is a magnificent directive, that it is a directive that will boost the creation of intellectual property.
And in addition, this directive includes a number of recommendations regarding the continuation of the work.

I believe that the approval by this Chamber of that report, and I hope that the Council aligns with the lines of the Council, of the Commission and of the Parliament, will serve so that in the next legislature the

The Commission should continue on this path, make proposals to Parliament and move forward in the area of intellectual property protection, which is essential for the development of our European Union as a major institution based on a common culture.

Yes, Mr. President, the information you give me is correct, but the impression that we European parliamentarians, and ultimately European citizens, have is that we have a very dangerous loophole in community law.
At this moment, as fiscal requirements are being strengthened in each of the member states, mobility is almost impossible.
And when we ask the Commission, the reason for the pragmatic approach is that the Commission never finds support in the Council.

We are in a sort of vicious circle whereby the Commission refers us to the Council and the Council refers us to the Commission. But meanwhile, the reality is that the citizens who live in this Europe that we want to build do not have the possibility of living in different countries or establishing relations as a result of the heavy tax burden that can be caused by the lack of tax harmonization.
Can the Council do something to get us out of this vicious circle?
Madam President, for once I am glad that you are not the chair, that Mr. Tajani has come, because Mr. Tajani has the advantage of having been a Member of the European Parliament.
And as a European parliamentarian, I know that you have experienced the frustration that we European parliamentarians have with regard to the application of community law.

Now, in Parliament we tend to meddle with the Commission. I believe that we are asking the Commission to perform an impossible mission, because all Community law and all the application of Community law is based on indirect application.

That is, the Commission has only a few officials at its headquarters, where it receives some complaints and has some possibilities of action. But at this moment, moreover, the tendency is to limit budgetary powers, so the Commission will not have the possibility to do so.
All community law, all application of community law is based on the action of national authorities, national parliaments, national judges, national officials.
In this regard, I do not think we can demand too much from the Commission.
What we have to do is help the Commission. And I believe that in the report of Mrs. Frassoni there are some points that can be useful to achieve this application.
I am referring to those related to the correlation of directives, the collaboration of national parliaments and the action of national courts.
Mr. President, two years ago, on a mission led by my colleague, my group colleague present here, Marián, I had the opportunity to visit.
...Sierra Leone and of being present in this court and of being aware of the immense work that this court was doing, not only for Sierra Leone but for all humanity.
As has already been said here, the Special Court for Sierra Leone has certainly set a precedent.

A precedent because, as the resolution rightly indicates, it is the first international court funded by voluntary contributions. It is the first court to be created in the country where the alleged crimes took place and it is also the first criminal court, as has already been pointed out, in which a former prime minister has been tried.

For all of this, not only because it is a precedent, but because it is a reference for other courts that have been created at its will, such as Rwanda, the former Yugoslavia, Cambodia or Lebanon, we consider it essential that this resolution be approved, in which we have been working jointly with the Court for several months.
Two years ago, we approved a resolution to support its financing. Two years ago, the court was going through a difficult period in which it was running out of money.
...money and did not have enough support. We must thank the European Commission here as well for coming out in financial support of this court.

Now we ask for two things above all. First, that the convicted persons serve their sentences. What is at stake is not the functioning of the court, which ends next year, but the legacy that this court will leave us. And secondly, obviously all this has to be accompanied by greater funding.
In short, the Special Court for Sierra Leone is an example and a reference for all of us and for all the courts that have tried war crimes.

It is an example and a reference, and it is a lesson that the second poorest country on this planet is giving us, in which, upon entering the court, we saw a motto written that said, "Without justice, there is no peace."
And precisely for that reason, we have the moral obligation, not only as Europeans, but as human beings, that the legacy of this court remains permanent in history.

Thank you, Mr. President. I will be brief, as I am sure you will appreciate at this hour. Mr. Vice President of the Commission, thank you once again, because you have shown, as you did in the third package,

Maritime, whose drive, its political category has been able to drive an agreement close to the Council and make it possible for Parliament, Council and Commission to agree at this point and in these last days when the legislature ends.
I think we have to congratulate ourselves.
I thank the close collaboration of the rapporteurs in both the Legal Affairs and the Environment Committees.

I thank and reiterate the work and collaboration of the shadow rapporteurs and, in short, I believe that tomorrow we will adopt an agreement at first reading on such an important regulation, which undoubtedly comes to complete the work of the...

The third maritime package means a success for this Parliament and for the European Union in the three institutions and once again justifies the co-decision procedure, which is useful and allows for constructive dialogue in favor of all the citizens of the European Union.
I am missing a minute. Before that, I want to answer the Commissioner, who knows about my friendship and affection for her, and indeed, my friendship and affection for Mr. Orbán.
But the Commissioner has not said a single word about the recommendation of the Ombudsman.
That is, the Ombudsman, who knows all the arguments that the Commissioner has given us, has made a precise recommendation that the Commission seems to ignore in all its aspects.

I do not even want Mrs. Cuneva to answer me, because obviously she does not have the data. But all the data she has given me is in line with what we knew and with what the Ombudsman also knows. And she does not tell us if effectively...

Despite all this, and as the Ombudsman, who knows this, recommends that the rule be changed, it does not tell us whether the Commission will assume what the Ombudsman requests and what the Parliament recommends based on what the Ombudsman has requested.

Thank you, Mr. President. I believe that the regulation proposals submitted to us by the Commission are important and necessary, and on the other hand, it was also important and necessary that from the
that the European Parliament insist on the principles on which the two European Parliament rapporteurs have insisted, both Mr. Viesca and Mr. Depré, and it is the principle of community competence.
This is a matter of community competence, in which, for practical reasons, it is convenient to maintain certain state competencies, but as Mr. Baró has said, limited in terms of their scope and time.
Community competence is not available and neither the Council, nor the Commission, nor the Parliament have the power to waive those community competences.

Having established this, it is an exceptional procedure. I believe that the amendments that we have discussed and that we have presented, and that I believe will be approved by Parliament tomorrow, will allow the approval of this package of measures in first reading.

But I also hope that, from the Commission, in the future, and starting from this, we can make progress in the development of a genuine European private law, which is increasingly necessary, as Mr. Sogor has highlighted in his last intervention.

We are talking about the problems that most directly affect people and to the extent that we are able to solve those problems of the people, people will realize that the European Union has a function.

In short, Mr. President, I would like to congratulate my colleagues, Mr. De Brey and Mr. Esviesca, and thank the Commission and the Council for their willingness to collaborate with us on this matter.

Madam President, Commissioner, I have signed this resolution and have asked to speak on this matter because I was a witness to what was called an expulsion but was in fact a kidnapping of our colleague Luis Herrero.

I was also able to verify that political persecution, abuse of power by the Chavista regime, intimidation of the opposition, threats, contempt for the dignity of people and the use of justice as a tool of torture, among other things, are common practices in Venezuela.

The case of Manuel Chávez is the straw that broke the camel's back and led to this resolution. However, there are thousands of cases as serious as his that are mentioned in the resolution and others that are not mentioned.
As is the case of Ligio Zedeño, who was born in the humble neighborhood of Petare, in Caracas, well known for its danger and also because he voted for a mayor who was not from the Chavista regime.
Eligio studied thanks to the help of others and, specifically, of Citibank, he managed to found his own business, the Caracas Bank, and then he lived normally helping the neediest.
However, today he is serving a sentence in a Caracas prison, illegally, after two years of having been detained without any valid charge.
Their only crime was being part of the economic oligarchy.
Another case is Nisson Moreno, student leader of the University of the Andes, elected several times to the University Council and president of the Federation of University Centers.
He won the 2003 elections against the Federation, the current Minister of the Interior and Justice, and this is his crime.
Today he is accused of attempted murder, violent sexual acts, and all of that despite having been exonerated of such accusations.

Situations like yours are the daily life in this country where the persecution of the opponent with the intention of excluding them from political life and discouraging dissent have become part of everyday life.

However, from here, it is necessary to send a message of hope to Venezuelan democracy, despite the difficulties, I am sure that democracy will prevail and that President Chávez will be removed from office at the polls.
Madam President, Commissioner, it is true that progress has been made in recent times, but despite all the progress, the south of the Union is burning and it is burning more and more.
That is why the resolution that this Parliament is going to adopt cannot be just another resolution that serves to show the great concern that other people's misfortunes cause us.
Forest fires are caused by one thing or another, but no one can deny that they are fueled by climate change.

Regardless of the responsibilities that may exist in some states or in some autonomous communities, the fact is that this Parliament must clearly call on the Commission to act swiftly and to use all the resources at its disposal, which are not few.
Neither the victims, nor the damages suffered, nor the needs of reforestation understand bureaucracy, nor can they understand budgetary shortages.

We must prioritize and we must act. And acting in this case means modifying strategies, mobilizing resources, increasing them and coordinating preventive policies in an optimal manner, demanding, if necessary,

in this case, responsibilities to the states that lack them. But assuming that this is not a problem of some states in southern Europe and that climate change does not affect only some states, it affects all of them and is a common cause.
That is why one of the main tasks that this Parliament has in the near future is to ensure that the European Union achieves clear commitments at the next Copenhagen Summit.

...round and firm to mitigate greenhouse gas emissions as much as possible, because they are obviously at the base of the fires, of their causes, and these in turn are the causes of more climate change.
Therefore, approving this resolution is now the challenge of this Parliament, for sure.
But that it is fulfilled is the challenge of the Commission, if truly, Mr. Commissioner, you want to avoid that the south of the Union, which does exist, continues to burn.
Mr. President, thank you very much for giving me the floor. I address Mr. Barroso.

Mr. Barroso, I must tell you that I have been following you with great interest and respect for a long time, since you were the Prime Minister of a country that is very close to us and very dear, which is Portugal.
However, I must tell you that you have me absolutely surprised.

I am surprised for two reasons. First, because you have shown disdain for the group I am part of, the group of non-affiliated members, by not granting us even a minute of your time to come and tell us about your political proposals.
We represent many European citizens and you have shown contempt for all our voters.
Secondly, because of the fragility of their political project, because of the poverty of their political proposals in the document “Political Guidelines for the Next Commission”.
Proposals that do not even manage to gather what you have defended throughout your own term as President of the Commission.
