I was surprised in this sense that issues such as energy, which throughout your term have been well treated, now when you offer us your proposals for the next...

Madam Commissioner, you ended your speech by telling us that there is a crisis in the dairy sector, but you started by telling us that you had already taken all the measures and that the situation was being resolved.
Look, to correct is to be wise.
And that is a Spanish saying that could be applied very well to the case that concerns us today.

The dairy sector has been suffering for months one of the most serious crises in its history, and despite this, you do not want to give in, nor does the European Commission or some of the governments, among which it seems that the Spanish government is also included, which refuse to backtrack on the decisions of the health check of the CAP.
These decisions were made without taking into account the fragility of this sector and in a market context very different from the one that emerged after that commitment was closed.
It gives the impression that the Member States either did not want to or could not see the storm that was brewing at that time.
The reform became obsolete in a short time due to the great turn that the market has taken, a turn that shows that the sector is at the mercy of the volatility of prices.

That large producers such as France and Germany, countries that achieved the largest increase in their national production quotas in absolute terms in that agreement, are now the ones requesting a review of the decisions of the check, gives much to think about.

In my opinion, the Member States were wrong and should have listened more carefully to the voices, among which I find myself, that were asking to postpone until 2011 any type of final decision on the future of the sector.
What a shame that they did not listen to us.
They will listen to you. Do it now.
Mr. President, this Parliament is the Palace of the Chimera, it is the Palace of Dreams.
The Irish people, with their strong vote, give us encouragement and strength to continue to prosper and build a strong Europe and, above all, a federal Europe.
Only in this way, only in this way, would we deserve the title of legitimate heirs of the fathers of Europe, for whose work we are all here.

Mr. President, now that the concern generated by the approval of the Lisbon Treaty has been overcome, it is time, in my opinion, to think about the treatment that will have to be given in the future to the nationalist attitudes that so hinder European construction.
My idea is that these delays cannot be free.
With a cool head, it is time to think about the possible measures to be taken in the coming days and years.
This modest deputy wants a president of the Council in the future who is a man, or better yet, a woman, convinced of European federalism, who handles the...
that is in the Schengen area and that is identified and committed to the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union. Thank you very much, Mr. President.
Commissioner, that is, on behalf of the Commission, I would only have to add "amen", but I had already prepared an intervention on behalf of the Socialist Group.

The rupture of the constitutional order in Honduras breaks two decades without coups in Latin America and creates a perverse precedent for other countries, especially the weakest ones, as is the case now of Paraguay.
The European Parliament cannot and must not remain deaf and mute in the face of such a violation of the rule of law.

Both the Council and the Commission have unequivocally condemned the coup, supporting the mediation of President Arias, in line with the position adopted unanimously by the OAS with the support of the United Nations.

The self-proclaimed de facto president, Micheletti, has failed to comply with the agreements recently reached, mocking the international community and preventing, among other measures, the return to the presidency of the deposed president, Mr. Zelaya.

Under the current circumstances, the election of a new president in the elections scheduled for November 29 is illegitimate and its results cannot and should not be recognized by the international community.

The European Parliament would make a serious mistake if it sent a delegation to observe the elections, as this would be interpreted as an endorsement of the coup. The OAS has already ruled out sending an observation mission to these elections.
This Parliament has been consecrated as a guarantor of freedom, democracy, the rule of law and respect for human rights.
As Vaclav Havel said this morning, there cannot be two weights or two measures.
We are all democrats here, and therefore, freedom fighters. And so, whether we are talking about Cuba, China, North Korea or Andorra, our discourse must be firm against authoritarianism.
Let us not be blinded by our ideological preferences.
There are no right-wing or left-wing coup leaders or dictators, only liberticidal and repressive ones.

We are very afraid that things in Honduras will not change and that a very dangerous precedent will have been created and the doctrine of the good coup, temporary and not too bloody, will have triumphed.

I would like to congratulate the members of the ENVI Commission and its president, Mr. Leinen, for the work they have done so that we can have a resolution like the one we have and that we have to approve unanimously.
We cannot be satisfied with just talking about having enough with sectoral agreements, because talking about a patchwork agreement is already admitting a part of the failure.
We have gone to approve this resolution that has three noble aspirations.
One more evident is to avoid climate change, with concrete proposals to reduce emissions and with a commitment to financing and aspiring to a binding agreement, I mean, not a patchwork.

And two latent aspirations: one, to start sooner rather than later to work on having a common energy policy, as we once had a common agricultural policy because it was needed, and the other, of course, which is also included, to recover the citizens' trust in politics and politicians, which we do not have much of in Europe.
In that sense, the success of the summit will be the success of the three aspirations.
That is why I encourage the President in his functions as President of the Council to continue with his optimism, to press and negotiate everything he can to drag the others to this success.

I don’t know if the leaders of this multipolar world want to be judged by history for not being able to reach a binding agreement. But I, as a deputy, and I believe all the representatives of the people, cannot be judged by history for not having been able to reach the binding commitment that we have with humanity to avoid climate change in Copenhagen.

Today, there is no doubt about the commitment of the European Union to the fight against terrorism. And thanks to the Stockholm Treaty, to the Stockholm Program, we will continue to advance in this space of freedom, justice and security that is so necessary.

In my opinion, this fight has been based on the mutual trust of the Member States, but now, with the possibilities offered by the Treaty of Lisbon, we should harmonize national legislations in the direction of not prescribing terrorist crimes, which should be considered crimes against humanity.

The day this happens, no one in this Parliament or any other will defend terrorists, as has happened, is happening and may continue to happen, with the ensuing damage to the victims of terrorism, who see how those who murdered their loved ones are treated as heroes, while they suffer in silence.
I therefore ask this Parliament to promote and adopt the European Charter of the Rights of Victims of Terrorism, based on the defense of memory,

Thank you very much, Mr. President. I would like to congratulate Ms. McGuinness on this initiative, which highlights the important role played by the CAP in addressing the needs of international food supply.

Now that the European Commission seems to want to reduce the weight of the CAP within the community budget, it must be said very clearly that the CAP is no longer a priority, but food security should be. And in past decades it has been seen that without the CAP, food security is very difficult, if not impossible, to achieve.
Agriculture cannot therefore be compared to other sectors of the economy that are able to prosper in a free market, because the food market is not a free market.

The farmer needs the support of the European Union to be able to move his business forward and the Union, in turn, needs the farmer to maintain an agricultural model capable of providing sufficient and quality food to an increasingly demanding citizen.
I therefore believe that the CAP should change course, but not disappear.

To do so, it would be necessary to guarantee direct aid to farmers, as well as to restore a policy of agricultural market management that provides greater price stability, which would benefit not only farmers, but also consumers and third countries.

It would be necessary to establish a framework of good practices to foster balanced relationships among the different agents in the food chain, avoiding abusive practices and promoting a fairer distribution of commercial margins.
In addition, a policy of informing the European consumer is needed, which emphasizes the efforts made by community producers to comply with the European Union's environmental regulations.
environment, food safety and animal welfare, because community producers have to compete with the production of third countries where much lower standards are applied for these imports.

And those producers from third countries prefer to export to the European Union rather than supply their own countries' markets for a matter of profitability, with the approval of the WTO negotiations.
According to a United Nations report, in 2009 around 270,000 people were victims of human trafficking in the European Union.

With these figures in hand, it is necessary for the action of the European Union to be based primarily on the protection of victims, with special attention to the situation of women and children, who are the most vulnerable.
We cannot continue to watch this theatre, this spectacle of sexual exploitation that is unfolding before our eyes, with indifference.
That is why I fully support this Parliament's request that assistance to victims be unconditional, more forceful and with harsher penalties, as Mr. Barrot has just told us.
That said, I would like to ask the President and the Council to use all the European legislation at their disposal, both existing and future, to protect the victims of human trafficking.

I consider that the proposal for a European Protection Order for victims, which I personally requested from the Spanish Presidency during the debates on the Stockholm Programme and which has finally seen the light of day, will be an effective instrument for combating these crimes.

And I hope for a firm commitment, as we have already seen from the Spanish Presidency, so that this order offers the victims special protection measures that are effective throughout the territory of the European Union.

I hope that those of us who have the responsibility to act in the face of the most serious problems in our society will give a real and concrete response to this very serious problem of human trafficking and that we will not just stay with good words.
We truly owe it to all the victims.
Mr. Zapatero, for a Spaniard like myself, it is an honor to greet your presence here in the functions of the rotating presidency of the European Union.
There are many expectations and challenges in this period, and we certainly cannot disappoint the expectations created.
Let the citizenship see that our renewed institutions are an instrument capable of providing solutions to real problems.
What we have exposed to Your Lordship is shared by us.
For the Partido Popular of Spain, this is a matter of state and we will be behind your lordship in everything that we see as common interests of Europe and that is important for Spain.
It is an ambitious program and it is a program that hopefully will be filled with content.
I would like people to see, in that album of the Spanish presidency, since it will surely be colorful and varied, that they see in each event a milestone on real problems that affect them.
The crisis hits the economies and unemployment seems like a fifth horseman of the apocalypse.
You have been honest enough to acknowledge that 20% unemployment exists in Spain, but that does not incapacitate you.
What I believe is that it forces us to produce a solution among all of us, a real problem that we have to solve among all of us.
This is a real problem.
Time does not allow me to say much, Mr. President.

But I do want to tell you that Spain has many challenges ahead. I believe, I am sure of Spain's capabilities as a nation and I want to believe and I am sure that you will be up to the task for our country.

We cannot disappoint these expectations at this time in Europe. On the other hand, the globalized world, and it has been referred to with intelligence, produces new centers of power, and it is necessary for the European Union to play a more active and coherent role in defense of its values and interests.
Otherwise, we run the risk of becoming irrelevant.
Finally, Mr. President, Spaniards do not accept that anyone takes away our ability to make proposals.
We have that legitimacy.
We must also have the humility to accept those pieces of advice that Don Quixote gave to Sancho when he recommended humility in the dream of governing the island of Barataria.
I am pleased to say that José Luis Zapatero has not stopped surprising European women with measures of great innovation and progress.
Of course, the formation of a truly paritarian government and the brave way in which it has brought to the national and European agenda the issues of gender equality and respect for others.
Mr. President, I warmly congratulate you on your ambitious action program, of course against gender violence, which is a social scourge.
The creation of a European Observatory on Gender-Based Violence is a pioneering proposal that European women support and applaud.
Mr. President, on behalf of the Portuguese Socialists, I wish you good luck.
You can count on our solidarity.
Solidarity, women with Zapatero.
Mr. President, thank you. In a matter as serious as terrorism, we should not wait for events to happen to act.
We should have anticipated this, but we didn’t.
And unfortunately, we are moving forward with each attack, like the failed Detroit attack, which forces us today to make decisions that guarantee the safety of air transport.
Deciding on body scanners in airports is a responsibility we cannot shirk, ladies and gentlemen.
We cannot keep waiting because the terrorists do not wait.
Therefore, the Commission must, as soon as possible, guarantee us that the dignity and privacy of people will be preserved and that there will be no negative effects on health.
Once this is guaranteed, we must make decisions for the entire European Union.

And to those who fear that fundamental rights will be violated, I will say that there is no right higher than the right to live, and those of us who love freedom above all else need to live in safety to feel truly free.
Mr. President, I believe that this crisis is an opportunity to move forward with firmness and conviction in the creation of a strong Europe.

In that strong Europe, it is likely that the expression “improve coordination” should be dispensed with, since it makes everything dependent on the subjects to be coordinated and, strictly speaking, leads to paralysis and vagueness.
We know that the finances and public debts of European countries will suffer while there is no progress towards European financial integration and there are no eurobond issues.

In any case, European institutions can already carry out specific actions. I do not insist on the rhetoric of coordination. And there are, on the one hand, the European Central Bank to harmonize financial supervision and
Good evening. I wanted to say that I have not come to this Parliament to applaud the recently enacted law in Spain on abortion.
What worries me is human life. I am worried, above all, and I am here to defend women whose lives are in danger because of gender violence and to offer them a space in which to live free and safe.

The resolution of this Parliament of 2 February 2006 recommends that Member States adopt a zero-tolerance attitude towards all forms of violence against women and that they adopt the necessary measures to ensure better protection for victims.
The Stockholm Program, approved in this Chamber, established a space of freedom, justice and security for all European citizens, and in it the fight against gender violence was considered a priority.

In it, my request to the Spanish Presidency was reflected, that it would promote during its mandate a European order of protection for victims of gender violence, to ensure that victims of these crimes have the same level of protection in all Member States.

In a borderless Europe, the fight against gender violence should also be borderless, and member states should strive to harmonize their legislation so that the idea of fighting violence against women transcends borders.

legislative obstacles and, in the end, we could offer, at least within the European Union, we could protect the lives of women and their children. And we could, I therefore ask the Commission and the Council to do everything

...necessary and everything within your power to ensure that this European Protection Order for Victims, which is a very effective instrument for combating the impunity of those who do not respect the dignity of women or their right to live free and safe, is implemented.

It has been a long time since Fidel Castro and his oligarchy put an end to the ideals of the Cuban Revolution, which meant so much echo and illusion for the peoples of the world, for the most elite of the international youth.
What characterizes the Castro brothers’ dictatorship at this moment is the cruelty towards political and conscience prisoners, the cruelty against their own people.
It reminds me of Franco on his deathbed, with the mistreatment of political prisoners, whom he also considered common criminals, and his obsessive contempt for exiles.
Castro ends up like Franco, and all the enemies of freedom when they become entrenched in power.
But we must save lives and be in solidarity with those who struggle and suffer.
It is our duty as Europeans committed to democracy, freedom, and human rights.
Thank you, Madam President, President of the Council, Commissioner. Never again, never again let us allow our silence to become complicity with the liberticides.
Let us never allow a person who fought for their rights and those of everyone else to die in a Cuban prison or anywhere else without our strong and firm voice rising up to demand their salvation.

Mr. Orlando Zapata Tamayo, a 42-year-old bricklayer of color, who only asked for an improvement in prison conditions, died after 86 days on a hunger strike and 7 years in prison for demanding respect for human rights.
And during those seven years he was mistreated, humiliated, and abused by his jailers, amidst, it must be remembered, the thick silence of the international community.
Other prisoners and human rights activists in Cuba are now on hunger strike, such as the psychologist and journalist Guillermo Fariñas.

Madam, the resolution that we present today, that we debate today and that we will vote on tomorrow, and that I represent on behalf of the Social Democratic Group, demands the release of all prisoners of conscience in Cuba.
It is once again pronounced in favor of a democratic transition and strict respect for fundamental human rights.
Let's not get into a topic that divides us, whether or not to maintain the common position.
Let's focus now on the issue of saving lives and the issue of human rights.
And we are talking about a period of serene reflection in which we seek places of encounter in the themes of the future policy with Cuba.
But this text also has an important added value.
The fact that it is presented by six political groups expresses a new time of broad consensus in this Chamber on the issue of human rights.

That the European democratic right never again be said to bow to the orders, so to speak, of Yankee imperialism, but that it also never again be said that social democrats are complacent or accomplices of communist dictatorship.
Simply because both statements are false, and the victims of the holocaust, wherever they are, must know that they will find us united in the unconditional defense of their cause.

Mr. President, I would like to thank, lastly, Mr. Salafranca, who has negotiated this text on behalf of the European People's Party, Ms. Weber of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe Group, Mr.

On behalf of the Green Group, to Mr. Kasutnik, from the Conservatives and Reformists, and to other colleagues who have participated in this difficult, complicated, but I hope tomorrow successful effort.

Lastly, I would also like to thank the President of the Spanish Government and President in office of the European Union, Mr. José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero, for his encouragement and support in moving forward with this resolution that we are debating today.
“History will absolve me” was the famous speech of a young lawyer that made his people vibrate.
History absolves him for his rebellion against tyranny and later against the North American blockade.
But with the same emphatic condemnation, this Parliament, which represents the largest space of freedom and democracy in the world, condemns the dictatorship that
The Cuban people suffer from human rights violations on the island, the cruelty towards political prisoners, and the contempt for their exiled nationals.
History’s judgment is clear.
With this resolution, deputies of all ideologies, we stand alongside the Cubans who fight.
We must avoid at all costs the brutal repression they suffer, even overcoming the paralyzing so-called common position.
I pay tribute to the poet Raúl Rivero in the last verse of his Havana. Do not impose taxes on affection, on emptiness, on asphyxiation, on bitterness.
The ruins of the homeland are safe.
Calm down, comrades.
We are leaving now.
This week, International Women's Day was celebrated.
In this Parliament we had many posters in all the languages of the European Union saying that yes, it is possible to end violence against women.
Today we are talking about violence in Mexico and it seems normal to recognize that Mexican women, indigenous and non-indigenous, are the least protected victims by local and federal authorities.
Mexican women are victims of all forms of violence, from domestic violence to sexual violence and torture perpetrated by members of the army or the police, and even murder.
Unfortunately, up to now, the responses of the Mexican authorities have been ineffective and that is why it is correctly spoken of almost absolute impunity.
Our resolution asks the Mexican government to fight femicides, a harsh word but correct when we see that almost all murders committed against women remain unpunished.
For example, in the State of Mexico, in the last four years, only 11% of the criminals who murdered almost 700 women were convicted.
At the same time, it seems that women are the preferred victims of the judicial system.
There is no other way to explain how it was possible that two indigenous women, Alberta Alcántara and Teresa González, were sentenced to 21 years in prison and up to
Now more than three years have passed in prison for the six men of the Federal Agency of Investigation who kidnapped Estras alone during an incident in a market.
Hopefully the judge, who will decide in a week on the appeal in this case, will realize the ridiculousness and injustice of the situation. But violence against women starts in the family.

I hope that Mexican legislators will soon improve the General Law on Women's Access to a Life Free of Violence so that the types of violence and the mechanisms that make the rules operational are defined.
It would also be normal to establish that domestic violence and marital rape are criminal offenses.
Moreover, for Mexican society to change and reject violence against women, it is important that schools make this topic a primary issue in the education of young people.
Mr. President, the truth is that the first thing I would like to do tonight is to thank Mr. Escot for his excellent disposition to negotiate this report.
It has been a true pleasure to work with him and with the other spokespersons of the parliamentary groups.

We are proud of the position that will be demonstrated tomorrow in the vote in this European Parliament and we are proud of a position like this one that defends quality, that bets on the development and the enhancement of rural areas, not only as...

not only as mere testimonies of a traditional European culture, but as true generators of wealth and employment. Employment that we need so much now in these times of economic crisis and dramatic employment situations in some Member States.
We also like the defense that this European Parliament maintains and that position that it already maintains, as the Agriculture Commission has made clear, to bet on quality at its highest level.
And in that maximum degree, we are betting, of course, on maintaining that differentiation between the designations of origin and the protected geographical indications.
Of course we reject the ideas of lowering the quality and we want attention to be paid and the community production to be valued.
I celebrate the words of Commissioner Cholo.
It was certainly a pleasure to hear him talk about the bet for the future of the European agricultural sector.
Of course, we hope that he listens to the voice of this Parliament, which will be made clear tomorrow in that vote.

Lastly, we hope that the European Commission will never again come before this Parliament to prohibit things such as, for example, the marketing standards for fruit and vegetables, which have done so much damage to European free competition.
We want the market imbalances to be corrected and we also want to bet on quality, variety, food safety and adequate production quantity.
We also want the community productions and the quality of those community agricultural productions to be defended in the World Trade Organization.
We also count on the work of Commissioner Cholos, of course, because our producers and European consumers cannot continue to be defenseless.
What do you think, Mr. President? The commissioner spoke about the absurdity and obsolescence of the procedures.
Let us be consistent, then.
We have lost too many opportunities, too many treaties to introduce community competence over European airspace.
But if we could not intervene as we should in the sky, we could on the surface of the earth.
For example, by monitoring the rights of passengers and also by mediating or requesting a truce in the various collective conflicts of land transport.
No minimum services, maximum services to all parties.
Thank you very much, Madam President. When from different and distant positions, such as those of Mauro, Colnish or Coleman, we reach the conclusion that...
The procedure, the electoral systems, the election of the deputies to the European Parliament present problems. This means, Madam President, that we need a uniform electoral procedure.

It was a mandate that was already in the Rome Treaties. And that is why the coordinators, and I want to take this opportunity to express my gratitude to all, but especially to Mr. Jauregui and Duff, we have agreed on an amendment.
Tomorrow, we will vote, and I hope that this Chamber will support it, precisely so that this issue, this matter of the uniform electoral procedure for the European Parliament, can be resolved soon.
I think that with this we would eliminate this type of questions.
In his speech, Mr. Traskowski spoke about the necessary representativeness of this Chamber. And this is a factor that most of the speakers, including Vice President Sefcovic, have highlighted.
I agree, and we say so in the report in article 1, that the 18 should enter as a block, because if not, we would lose representation.

And for them to enter as a block, to fulfill that act of political justice that is the Lisbon Agreement, we must, ladies and gentlemen, be pragmatic, because a transitory and exceptional situation also requires transitory and exceptional solutions.

That is why, and I am not hiding it, I do not like the possibility that deputies who did not come out of the 2009 elections enter this Chamber. I say it with all clarity in paragraph 2, but if I have to choose between that and not entering...

To enter the 18 or to seek a pragmatic solution and to enter the 18 and to comply, therefore, with the Lisbon Agreement, I ask this Chamber, and from there my report, to opt for that solution. Transitory, pragmatic, but above all, Madam President, fair.
Thank you all for your collaboration and for the interesting contributions you have made to this work.

As I could not do it on March 11th, International Day of the Victims of Terrorism, I would like to pay them a well-deserved tribute today from this Parliament, to recognize the enormous sacrifice of those who have paid the highest price in the name of freedom.

It is urgent to start working on a directive that protects the rights of the victims of terrorism, who are always the great forgotten ones and suffer the humiliation of being unjustly equated with their executioners.
It is high time that these European institutions recognize the dignity of the victims of terrorism and help them in their right to protection and justice, and that this is soon translated into law.

that will honor all those who make it possible, and that the first article be that the support for the victims of terrorism be the one that recognizes the right to justice and that no government ever pays a political price.

I call on all those who can defend the victims to never forget that true peace is born of justice. And that is the only thing that we who believe in justice should defend from Europe and from anywhere in the world.

It has been necessary, Mr. President, to find ourselves before the abyss and the economic collapse for the heads of state and government to understand that the way is not more nationalism, but more Europe.
In this direction, measures have been adopted such as the decline of the right of veto in the European Council or the seed of a European public treasury.
Finally, although belatedly, we have realized that we are all in the same boat and that it is useless to address individual situations and, moreover, to do so in an improvised manner.

But I wonder if this attitude is a parenthesis or, on the contrary, the beginning of a true European economic government. Because what is in excess, dear colleagues, is governance and what is lacking is authentic government, if we want to be faithful to the testament of the founding fathers.

That is why, from this Parliament, we must promote all those reforms aimed at strengthening Europe and making budgetary and fiscal discipline a reality, forgetting, of course, nostalgic sovereignties.
Colleagues, strengthening the European Commission and strengthening this Parliament is the only right recipe to build a Europe that, otherwise, would fade away like a fleeting shadow.
Thank you, President. Commissioner, from the INTA Commission, thank you to Ms. Desarnod for the collaboration we have had.
Today more than ever, it is necessary to unite around the Mediterranean, to strengthen major projects and institutional development.
Today more than ever, it is necessary to find solutions to the crisis, to research, to climate change, to water, to new energy models, to sustainable development.

To do so, it is necessary to promote and complete commercial and economic relations in the area, with short- and long-term measures, free trade zone, elimination of tariff barriers, opening of the North-South and South-South markets.
The Barcelona Summit, the Spanish presidency, will provide the opportunity for a new commitment, a new situation, a new joint bet on the democratization of economic solutions and social solutions.
The Barcelona Summit can put us in a position to lead the Mediterranean.
Thank you, Madam President. Within the trans-European transport corridors, there is the railway corridor called the Mediterranean Corridor.
It is a vital communication that will connect North Africa with Europe.
It is vital for Spain because this axis is a priority, as it would connect Algeciras with Europe.
Not excluding other priority corridors, it would go through Almería, Murcia, the Valencian Community and Catalonia.
And why? As Commissioner Reding said, there is greater economic activity and a high concentration of land transport.
This is one of the two conditions.
The possibility of communicating with different ports in the Mediterranean area was opened.
We need to gain economic momentum, be competitive, as the Commissioner also said, because more than 50% of Spanish exports are produced in this area.
Therefore, if we increase the issue of a strategic railway axis through the Mediterranean, we will increase competitiveness for Spain and competitiveness for Europe.
Thank you, Madam President. I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate the Spanish Presidency for the efforts it has made this semester to overcome the pandemic.
a common position with respect to Cuba and create a new type of relationship of the European Union with Cuba that includes, naturally, as a priority issue, the defense of human rights.
This policy has not been successful, basically due to the intransigence of the Cuban dictatorship, which began this presidency in January of this year.
This year, with the expulsion of the deputy who is speaking to you, when he was trying to visit, with all the visas and all the legality, the island to worry about the human rights of the same.
But that policy, that new policy that the Spanish government has undertaken will bear fruit sooner or later.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, colleagues, this is a regulation of utmost importance for consumers and for the food industry, because it is not easy at all to achieve a balanced labeling that contains all the essentials but that is not so exhaustive that it complicates the information.
This is a great report and I must congratulate the rapporteur for it.
I agree with her on the major issues regarding nutritional information and the controversial issue of profiles, especially if we take into account that the Commission did not comply with the
The commitment to establish said profiles, as well as their conditions of use, before January 19, 2009, as prescribed by Regulation 1924/2006.

There is an issue that concerns me, and that is the possibility of the coexistence of national regulations for labeling, because it goes against the objective of the legislation, which is harmonization and to avoid all possible obstacles for a true single market to function.
As regards the indication of the country of origin, the current legislation provides that this information must be provided when, in the event that it is not indicated, it may mislead the consumer.
In addition, it is planned that there will always be voluntary labeling.
Going further may complicate, may imply economic costs and administrative complexity for companies without providing any clear benefit to the consumer.
As for the use of different languages, I must say that the Commission's proposal coincides with the existing directive, which has worked well and has not posed any problems.
Reopening this debate can be dangerous and unnecessary and cause problems for the circulation of products.
Mr. President, the best proof of the goodwill we have is the thousand amendments we are seeing from the Commission to the Plenum.

But in addition to good intentions, I believe we must be practical when it comes to labeling food, if we do not want to achieve the opposite effect of what we are pursuing. That is, to confuse the consumer instead of helping them to be informed.
It is not about illustrating, but about preventing, informing them about what they can eat and in what quantity.
It has to be labeled for fat, for sugar, for trans fats.
Effectively,
Indeed, about what affects cholesterol, about all those substances that affect what we have said, obesity, the health of people.

Yes, but with other foods, with other information such as place of origin, when it does not lead to confusion. Or, for example, in the case of meat, to say the place of birth, the place of passage, the place of pasture, the place of slaughter of the animals, can illustrate a lot, but they will end up confusing.

It is up to us to be practical and for this regulation to be the one that harmonizes and informs consumers, or otherwise, it will be the one that confuses them even more and will impose issues that, far from achieving better health accounts, will achieve greater degrees of confusion.

That is why I ask, for example, that some of us opt for the GDA, the daily intake amount, instead of the traffic lights, because it is very clear that if you consume this amount or double it, you will get fat, so only consume one.
The daily intake amount versus other types of codes, that is what some of us are proposing, so as not to confuse consumers even more.
Thank you very much, Mr. Martín Fraguero, for being here on behalf of the Spanish Presidency in a report like this, Madam Commissioner.
Mr. Milana, congratulations on the ability to reach a common agreement and to bring together all the interests and put on the table an initiative report, one of the first initiative reports.
The development of aquaculture is important.

It is necessary due to the increase in fish consumption and the stagnation of fishing extraction capacity. But I want to highlight at this time the economic importance of this activity that generates economic wealth and generates employment.
Sanitary guarantees are important, sustainability is important, and marine environment protection is important.
The image of aquaculture must be enhanced and the scientific and research sector must also be enhanced.
Aquaculture is an opportunity, as Mr. Martín Fragüeiro said, within the PCP, as the Commissioner said.

It must be given a coherent coordination framework. It must be given the possibility of regularization, because aquaculture can provide sufficiency, sustainability and economic resources. And I believe it is important for Europe.

Mr. President, in my opinion, this excellent report outlines the main guidelines that should inspire the new White Paper on Transport, which will shape European transport policy for the next ten years.

The present report has several milestones that are worth noting: the need for a financial fund as an indispensable tool, the challenge of the growing demand for freight transport, the search for solutions that are compatible with the environment,

It contributes to the safety of users and goods. The urgent need for sufficient and safe rest areas in road transport. The diagnosis, in my opinion, is accurate, that there should not be mere competition between the different

not to compete with each other, but to complement each other, seeking efficiency criteria. The speaker's statement, which I consider bold and unfair, is that rail or maritime transport is not always more environmentally friendly than road transport.
In short, the concept of efficient mobility is a concept of the future and, without a doubt, must be supported, in my opinion, with all rigor.
Yours, Mr. President, is a mistake in the approach.
Did you think you were going to preside over Europe and influence the gears that make the complex European machinery work?
He even came to believe, because he let people close to him proclaim it, that the world would live under his presidency a stellar moment.
None of this has come true.
Let's go over some details.

In these six months of Spanish presidency, I would like to distinguish, on the one hand, the political direction of the same and, on the other hand, the work of the officials who have been working in the engine rooms.
It is the first one that has failed, and this is due to the lack of adequate drive from the government presidency, which has been more like a pendulum swing.
However, I want to highlight the effort of the officials, their varied willingness to serve Europe and Spain.
And it is that, Mr. President, Spain has magnificent professional civil servants and if there is something to regret, it is that they are too scattered in daily reality.
That said, it is recognized that some commendable initiatives have been adopted in these six months.
Among them, I would like to mention the organ donation and transplantation plan and the treatment given to patients' rights in cross-border healthcare.
The agreements on the new 2020 strategy and especially those related to the European External Action Service have been left in the air, both still too fragile.
The European Protection Order for victims of gender violence has been regrettable, and the same gloomy result has been offered by the
The European patent is essential for the life of thousands of companies and is partially blocked by the linguistic problems that Spanish legislation encourages.

But all the major political actions have ended in spectacular failure. From the Mediterranean summit to the one of the European Union with the United States, the latter being the one for which its own government was in charge of creating exaggerated expectations.
However, we must agree that not being able to push forward his policy regarding Cuba has been highly positive for Cubans.
Lastly, the progress made towards better European economic governance cannot in any way be attributed to your presidency, which was conspicuously absent on the most relevant issues.
Goodbye then to the Spanish presidency.

A positive conclusion if I want to extract from this experience. My fantasy of a convinced Europeanist is excited by the thought that it could mean the end of the rotating presidencies, as they have been conceived until now.

Would this be good news? Because while Europe does not strengthen its common institutions, firmly uniting its fragments, it will continue to run the risk of being swallowed up in the empty spaces of irrelevance.
Mr. President, believe me, Mr. Zapatero, I would have liked to give a different speech today.
Your Lordship has set out a semester full of ambition and has set the bar so high in your demands that, when compared to what has actually been achieved, disappointment is inevitable.
The truth is that Your Lordship has not been able to overcome a complex situation that required leadership and credibility.
Your Lordship has once said that the European Union is a club with rules, and I agree.
But it was your Lordship who was responsible for enforcing those rules.
The reality is that it was the Spanish government who was being imperiously demanded to fulfill their obligations.
In this picture, positive achievements, which have not been lacking, have been overshadowed.
Your Lordship has had time to read them, I have not.
Democracy, sir, is a regime of public opinion.
And that is what it seems. Obama's snub, the cancellation of the Mediterranean Summit and the announced European Union-United States Union constitute failures of great magnitude.
The rush to close agreements hastily at any price has not helped the image of Spanish management. The way of achieving any respectable goal has been described as makeshift.
Spain is a great nation and it will continue to be so, despite the bad management of this time.
Our diplomats and officials have kept their cool and, thanks to them, Spain's prestige will continue.
The truth is that the value judgment that will be made of this presidency will weigh more on the situation of Spain than on what has been done or not done here.
It would be difficult to lead such a difficult company for someone who has placed their country in a stage of uncertainty and restlessness.
In the best of cases, this presidency has turned out to be sadly irrelevant.
Thank you. Mr. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in the coming months we will be fully engaged in the debate on the new CAP.

It is important to reach a good agreement, so I hope that the Belgian presidency will achieve what the Spanish presidency has not, that is, to channel the discussions so that the Member States commit to maintaining a policy in the future.

A truly strong Common Agricultural Policy, with a sufficient budget to meet the needs of the 27 Member States, the new and the old, and not like in 2005 when there was no money and modulation had to be invented.

In the next reform of the CAP, we are playing for the viability of a sector that not only provides intangible goods and services, such as environmental care, but that should also ensure the supply of food to European citizens.

We have been witnesses in the past of painful situations of scarcity, so it is necessary that the European Parliament has to provide security and supply based on community production, as the main objective of the next reform, without leaving aside other contributions such as the fight against climate change.

Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, I agree with Commissioner Chatzimarkakis that this report is necessary, very necessary, and it comes at a good time, because it has shown the abuses committed by the large-scale distribution, which have severely disrupted the different links in the food chain.

The BOVE report, which at some point may go too far in trying to be too interventionist, must be recognized from the perspective of the social market economy that we advocate from the European People's Party, I say that it must be recognized that it collects responses to the fair demands of European producers.

It also brings transparency to the different parts of the food chain, which is always good, and gives many more possibilities and support to defend the weakest sectors of that chain and, of course, supports European consumers to know more about that chain.

The European food industry could have been taken into account more in this report, perhaps it would have been very good. But this report also includes measures to curb price volatility, and that was very necessary.

Measures are also included to provide equity to those links in the chain, as requested by the Environment Commission, and there is also a request to fight against the abusive and unfair practices of large-scale distribution.
It is high time to establish a list of abusive practices and for European legislation to prohibit them outright.
It is also important to take measures to avoid difficult practices through white brands that go against competition and against intellectual property law.

For all this, we must support the BOVE report and we must support all the colleagues from the different parliamentary committees, INCO, ENVI or AGRI, who have shown that they have worked hard for this report to finally see the light and help European producers to move forward.
The alarm bell rings and it is true.
And the frustration is also heard, as in the interventions of this plenary session, for not having achieved the Millennium Goals.
And the truth is that what we are playing for is a lot.

Our natural environment is so fragile that if one day the big fish decided not to continue eating the small one, we would all have to pay for it out of our generational pocket with our health and well-being as the currency.
The European Union is a leader today in the fight against climate change and has been for some time in pioneering and conservation measures.

But as the unfulfilled goals show, it seems that there was a lack of will, not only for implementation and coordination, which have also been mentioned here, but also for expansion, to go beyond our very limited special conservation areas.
Of course, biodiversity is not a museum piece that can be locked up in a ghetto area, as it sometimes seems to be done, glancing at it from time to time.
Biodiversity is alive and has no borders. It crosses the entire Earth with a domino effect in which if one piece falls, all the others fall.

And I draw attention to the need for a global and more community-based will, especially with regard to the soil, because subsidiarity as the only method for the management of the soil or forests can be one of the new terrible enemies of biodiversity.

That is why I draw your attention to paragraph 67 and the possible vote that will be given, and I ask you to reject the second part, because I am convinced that a common policy on land would help to conserve the entire territory.

A European Union that is so varied, so diverse for good and for bad, and so lacking in political will from the States, and so in need of more and more European Union, with all the extension of the word, what it means, more union also for the ground.

Mr. President and Mr. Commissioner, first of all, I would like to highlight the work of the rapporteur, Ms. Macabich, not only in the substance but also in the form, because she has done it in collaboration with all the rapporteurs in the Chamber.
I would also like to thank the experts from the Spanish Administration for their contribution to this agreement.

The purpose of this European Union pharmacovigilance system is to strengthen the monitoring, transparency and communication of the safety of medicines once they are on the market, especially with regard to their risk profiles and the adverse reactions they may cause.

The creation of the European Pharmacovigilance Committee should be highlighted, which will evaluate and issue recommendations to the European Medicines Agency on safety issues that may arise with medicines marketed in the European Union.
The solution reached for the notification of pharmacovigilance of suspected adverse reactions is very important, both for the Member States and for the marketing authorization holders.

Eudravigilance will be the only source of information, but the competent authority of the Member State where the adverse reaction is suspected will be informed simultaneously, and this is very important.
It is also worth highlighting the possibility that is opened to consumers to be able to communicate any adverse reaction and, in this sense, the creation and management by the Agency of a portal
The European Medicines Agency, which is linked to the portals of each Member State, will help improve citizens' knowledge about the safety of the medicines they consume.
Lastly, we cannot forget that, given that pharmacovigilance plays a fundamental role in protecting public health, the approval of the Directive and the
This directive and regulation will significantly contribute to this by improving not only current procedures but also the coordination of actions between the different Member States.

I appreciate the effort of the speaker to accept some suggestions and, of course, his defense of the copyrights that I share. But the inclusion of the infringing and punishable nature of certain exchanges and the

The recognition of sanctioning authority to suppliers, as well as the exclusion of mass exchanges as a possible infraction in alternative resolution, make it impossible to vote in favor of either of the two reports in Liza.
The Gallo report has aroused great interest and could have been timely, but the core of the debate is too focused on the debate for or against the French law called "A".
PIP, on cutting off internet access for offenders, without there having been a genuine European debate that takes into account the reality of other advances in national legislation.

I hope we reach a common position in the Socialist Group and a majority in the European Parliament in the debates and amendments on the Commission's draft directive that will soon reach the Parliament, according to Commissioner Barnier's announcement.
On that occasion, we will try to reach a more balanced position than today, which takes into account both the rights of Internet users and the essential respect for intellectual property.
I congratulate those who have worked on this report, on this financial package, especially the civil servants and the deputies of this Parliament.
A financial crisis of enormous proportions had to occur for Europe to wake up.
However, an opportunity has been missed, in part, to strengthen the common institutions of Europe. Because, on the one hand, these new supervisory authorities have a scope of competence
limited compared to similar authorities of member states and it is a pity that there has not been progress in a similar integration to that which occurred with the system of central banks.
We have made progress, but we must continue climbing the mountain.

As a member of the Human Rights Commission, as a Spanish and European citizen, and as a victim of terrorism since the terrorist organization ETA murdered my brother and his wife in Seville, I address this Parliament to denounce the Government of Venezuela and its president for having allowed ETA terrorists to

ETA members are trained in Venezuelan soil, under the orders of the alleged terrorist Cubillas, who works for the government of Hugo Chávez, despite the fact that there is an international arrest warrant against him, which is a serious violation of the fundamental right to security of any European citizen.
I demand that the Spanish government take decisive action in the face of this grave humiliation to the Spanish people as a whole.
Zapatero cannot keep quiet while the Venezuelan ambassador calls our Civil Guards torturers, who have been and will be an example of bravery in the fight against ETA.
It cannot turn a blind eye to the growing cooperation between ETA and the FARC on Venezuelan soil, as already denounced by Judge Eloy Velasco.
Zapatero cannot shake hands with a leader like Chávez, who is turning Venezuela into a terrorist refuge.

The president of a country like Spain, where terrorism has caused so much pain, cannot continue to ignore this problem and should give a response that it deserves and that any ordinary citizen would give if they had the opportunity to do so.
On February 14, 2008, as a Valentine's Day gift, the Conference of Presidents decided that the intergroups would only meet on Thursdays.
Since then, we have tried to solve this issue.
We haven’t achieved it.
The intergroups today, Mr. President, have to meet on a date that is not the appropriate one,
They almost never have rooms and never have interpretation.

Today I speak not only as president of the Intergroup on Poverty and Human Rights, but also with the mandate of the majority of the intergroups of this House, and therefore of the members of this House who are part of those intergroups.
I solemnly ask that the Conference of Presidents reconsider and annul the decision of February 14, 2008, and return to the previous situation of freedom of the intergroups.
And if he does not do it, I say, also kindly, that we will bring the matter to the plenary session of this House and it will be decided by the sovereign of this House, which is this Parliament.
Mr. President, on the International Day against Human Trafficking and Exploitation, some data was made public that should make us act as skeptics.
More than 90% of the prostitution that takes place in Europe is due to blackmail and extortion.

Given these data, we should ask ourselves if we are doing everything necessary to protect the dignity and integrity of thousands of women whose rights are also protected by the Charter of Fundamental Rights that we approved with the Treaty of Lisbon.
Because we are not talking about the oldest profession in the world, but the only form of slavery that we have not managed to eradicate from old Europe.
Countries like Spain are making significant efforts in this regard, pursuing traffickers, raising awareness among citizens and promoting reintegration plans for women victims.
But it is not enough.
Europe has to be a single space for action and commitment.

The next directive on treatment is an opportunity to act on demand through education and make it more difficult to access the supply that is advertised in all types of media, as well as to increase bilateral cooperation with third countries to fight this scourge at its source.
We have an opportunity.
I call on this Parliament to continue being the vanguard of citizens' rights.
Madam President, we all agree that the European External Action Service is a historic opportunity for European construction.

But to do so, it is necessary to act with a broad vision, because this is not the time for internal struggles over resources that are transferred or withheld in the short term and wars between the different European institutions.
What is now required, on the contrary, is to have an overall view of what the European Union should be in the world. In other words, to do just the opposite of what has been done so far.
What happened a few days ago, on the occasion of the awarding of the Nobel Peace Prize, where too many voices have been heard from Europe, and not all of them brave.
To highlight one of the exceptions, the President of this Parliament, Mr. Buttiglione, is the author of a brilliant and worthy statement.

Mr. President, the regulation we are debating today is of vital importance for the future of a sector, that of cutlery and related products, which in my region, the land of Don Quixote, specifically in Albacete, means, in addition to the survival of more than 8,000 jobs, an element of identity and a bet for the future for craftsmanship as a source of job creation.

The "Made in" seal on knives has been claimed for some time by social groups such as APRECU and fought for by the government of Castilla-La Mancha with the unanimous support of its regional parliament.
A seal of origin is not interventionism. It is a bet on transparency, the rules of commercial play and the fight against unfair competition.

It is to increase the decision-making capacity of consumers when choosing a product so that they take into account not only the final price of the same, but also the quality brand of the place of origin or the social conditions in which they are produced.

And above all, it will mean a new horizon of optimism for many people who are having a hard time, but who today look at us thinking that we have not been indifferent when it comes to betting on fairer trade, yes, but also on giving added value to those who, in addition to producing, do so with respect for social rights and the best conditions for European workers.
That is why I thank the speaker and Mr. Menéndez del Valle for their political support and social awareness on this important issue for my land.
Thank you, Mr. President. Let's see if I can bring some calm to this lively debate.
It is regrettable that some countries, or some states that make up the European Union, are still present at this G20 forum.
Despite this anomaly, which certainly weakens Europe's image in the world, it would be good if there were at least a common global position in that world forum.
And what would be, in my opinion, that common position?

In my humble opinion, I believe that, first, the adoption of a global agreement to address the consequences of the crisis cannot be delayed, and not just a financial agreement. Second, Europe must maintain the euro as a reference currency, or, if you prefer, as an anchor for...

Avoiding that the market turbulences drag us and make us repeat the mistakes that were committed throughout the 20th century. The euro, thirdly, must serve as a herald of what Europe must represent in the world of democratic values and freedoms.
public.
In summary, it is important to know that in the global world, in this global game, the one who only plays the national cards loses.
Thank you, Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen. I believe we are in the case of congratulating the rapporteur, Mrs. Maesberg.
There were different, conflicting positions, and she has obtained compromise solutions that allow us to be together in an important result.

Ladies and gentlemen, the Transport Commission has decided that all bars should be protected in a similar way. To this end, it invokes that if this were not the case, a situation of unfair competition would arise.

We accept the position of the majority, in favor of a legal situation with uniform rules for the entire Union, but I will not spare their lordships the clear indication that it also implies a certain lack of equity.
It is evident that the Baltic Sea, the North Sea and the English Channel are more polluted areas and that the controls of the sulfur limit values should be more rigorous in their case.
The measures related to ports should be positively evaluated, as they affect the solutions for reducing transport times and handling costs.
In any case, I will not tire of reiterating that at this point we have a pending signature.
If a decision is not made to liberalize the ports, they will not be able to expand the central role they must play in the context of intermodality.
Welcome also, ladies and gentlemen, the impulse of a strategy aimed at modifying the specific impacts of climate change.
I believe that this is a positive report, that we must vote.
But we cannot forget that it occurs in the context of a serious accident, which is the one in the Gulf of Mexico.

In this regard, the Commission is urged to assess whether the framework for the review of the regulation of the European Maritime Safety Agency strengthens the role that the Agency should play in prevention inspections and subsequent tasks of cleaning up oil spills.
In my personal opinion, Madam Commissioner, yes, and those tasks should be reinforced with the mandate that is required for such effects.
Mr. President, the integrated maritime policy is a cross-cutting, regional and sectoral policy. It must include the fishing and aquaculture policy, and it must not be subordinated to other policies.
We all must respond to environmental and economic problems, both for society in general and for the fishing sector. New technologies, fishing methods, species development, a maritime economy plan.

To create more and better jobs, quality supplies, international relations that avoid piracy and promote the governance of our seas that have no borders and not have sustainability problems like in the case of Iceland.
This would be working for an integrated maritime policy. This would be working for the environment and sustainability.
Recently, the Church of Our Lady of Deliverance was attacked in Baghdad and 58 people were killed, most of them women and children, for the sole reason of being Christian.
Al Qaeda has taken credit for the feat with pride.
It is not an isolated event, but rather the culmination of persecutions and attacks against Christians in countries with a Muslim majority.
Expulsions in Morocco, threats in Turkey, attacks in India or Nigeria.
In January, six Christians were massacred at the door of a church in Cairo.
Cairo. How long will the complicit silence of Western democracies last?
Fortunately, President Bush has made an institutional statement.
The statement of condemnation by the High Representative, Mr. Ashton, has been limited to a condemnation of a terrorist act.
Terrorist. Why is the motive not mentioned? The condition of being Christian, which is the unequivocal cause of the massacre.
I haven’t heard anything from Mr. Zapatero. I haven’t heard anything from President Erdogan.
Erdogan: What is the Alliance of Civilizations for?
I feel sorry for our papanatism and our cowardice.
Inevitably, I remember the weeping and misunderstood Oriana Fallaci, who announced the arrival of Eurabia and was almost stoned for having the courage to denounce what is happening in complex Europe.
I also thank the Commissioner. I share the desire of this Chamber.
I want the European proposals to get the support they deserve in Cancun.
In relation to this debate, the importance of cities in the preservation of the environment must be emphasized.
There is a pact between more than a thousand mayors of the European Union that demonstrates the recognition of the problem by these authorities, whose actions are crucial if we want to be successful.
The great words we use are of no use if we do not have the collaboration of the mayors of the cities.
For this, it is very important to spread the emissions, since cities produce almost 80% of greenhouse gases.
Today, there is no such disclosure, and what is worse, there is no common standard for the measurement of these emissions.
There is a non-profit organization called the Carbon Disclosure Project that already houses information from thousands of companies and that I think could also be used by city councils.
Without their participation, without the participation of these town halls and mayors, environmental action is left in smoke, the smoke that we precisely want to escape from.

Thank you, President. Some have said that the condemnation of Morocco is too lenient given the magnitude of the repression of human rights in the Sahara, in which Morocco is nothing more than an occupying country, without sovereignty or any legal title.
But the important thing is the message that all of Europe and this Parliament can no longer tolerate their violence.
Yesterday I spoke about the Hague Tribunal in this very Parliament.

The international community, which sadly failed to prevent the genocide in Rwanda, Yugoslavia and Darfur, I hope will prevent the one in Western Sahara, and we will not have to see it in another court, also in The Hague, as I said, but this time for war crimes.
President, Commissioner, the directive approved in 2009 was a success because it updates the regulatory framework that has been regulating toy safety.
It is a big step in the right direction, because it shows us the way to go, but it is not enough.
We must always be vigilant and attentive to ensure that the toys that are marketed do not endanger the safety and health of children.
All toys on the market must comply with current legislation.
We must review and improve the monitoring mechanisms to detect dangerous toys, whether due to substances considered toxic (CMR), fragrances and other dangerous substances such as HPA compounds.
The instructions to be followed need to be clearer about the warning regarding the minimum age and the dangers derived from improper use.
The recommended age for toys should be based on studies of children’s behavior.
We must be able to adapt our regulations to scientific advances, supported by solid studies, and be more rigorous in market surveillance and toy imports.
It is necessary to work together and strengthen cooperation between Member States and to count on the joint work of customs to control the route of imported toys.
Citizens are getting ready to do their Christmas shopping and we must give them the assurance that the products they buy meet all safety requirements.
In this debate, we have clearly seen that we all agree in supporting the objective of this report.
The different political groups have shown their support for this directive, which offers greater protection to victims.
Therefore, I ask myself, what obstacles exist to approve this instrument?
I repeat, what fears are there for something as necessary and simple as protecting victims equally throughout Europe to finally become a reality?
Hoping that this Parliament will approve this report by a majority, I address the Council and the Commission, reminding them that we have
We have overcome the legal hurdles in our negotiations. And I applaud the Commission for recognizing our work, as we recognize the work it will do in the future.

We must not exclude ourselves, but rather help each other, by approving today this more concrete instrument, and tomorrow the broader package of measures to help victims that the Commission will present, and with which I commit to collaborate.
Therefore, let us be brave and responsible today and help all those who have the right to live in a safer Europe.
Let's help everyone, I repeat, whether they are men, women or children.
Let us help those who look to us today so that we can give them a better life, a life that returns their freedom, their security and, above all, their dignity.

Madam President, the European People's Party Group will vote enthusiastically for this report. And my congratulations first to the rapporteurs, to the Commission and to the Council for this agreement.
We coined the term "democratic deficit" in the 1980s, ladies and gentlemen.
With him we wanted to say that in the European Union the decisions were made only by the Council of Ministers, at the proposal of the Commission, and this Parliament was only advisory.
The battle of this Parliament since the 80s, through the Maastricht Treaty, Amsterdam, Nice, the Constitutional Treaty, the Lisbon Treaty, has been...

To fill that democratic deficit. And I believe that with the Treaty of Lisbon, with the new powers of the European Parliament, with the participation of the national parliaments, we have achieved that objective.
And we round it off today with this citizen legislative initiative, which was due in the Convention's work to the good cooperation between national parliaments and the European Parliament.

I would like to recall here the names of Jürgen Meyer, our German Social Democrat colleague, and Annan Lamassoure, who were the ones who brought this initiative to the Convention and who made it approved.
Therefore, I believe we have completed the circle, Madam President.
I believe that today, when we vote on the initiative, we will have put on the table the death certificate of the concept of democratic deficit.
It is now our turn, ladies and gentlemen, to act responsibly. And today we also have the opportunity to do so.
By voting on the Union budget, we will fulfill what is expected of us, a responsible Parliament and a co-decision Parliament.
I think it is a good day for Europe, ladies and gentlemen.
Thank you, President. In January 2012, 400 Spanish egg producers could disappear, around 30% of the total in my country, with the loss of 300,000 tons of egg production.

And the European Union could stop producing those 80 million eggs, those 2 million tons, and we would only achieve that they were covered by imports from third countries, whose animal welfare standards are much lower than those of the European Union, if we do not act with great intelligence.
This 1999 directive, which requires increasing the space of the cages of laying hens, requires us to act with intelligence and a realistic vision, because if not...

We will only manage to weaken European production and give extra commercial opportunities to third countries where the space for bees is infinitely worse than the current one we have in the European Union.

It is a directive that requires a great deal of effort from European producers. In Spain alone, we can understand that the cost is increased by around 600 million euros, but we must not forget that it also has an economic impact that extends to the livestock industry and the food industry in general.

I therefore ask for the support of your lordships for the amendment of the Popular Group to the second paragraph, where it is requested to find a solution at least for the responsible farms, of responsible industries that are proceeding with the transformation of their farms, and that in January 2012 will be almost finished.

We must support them in transforming those facilities and give them time to complete that process, thus avoiding irreparable damage to the farms and preventing a situation of scarcity in the community market from occurring overnight, consequently increasing prices for consumers.
It is about respecting the directive, giving an opportunity to the egg and egg product industry, while also respecting the right to animal welfare and the right of consumers to a reasonable price.

Mr. President, I believe it is only fair to thank the speakers, especially Mr. Grostet and Ms. Dagmar Roth-Behrendt, from my own group, for the work they have done to turn a stagnant regulation into a useful one. This work has allowed us to include the right to public health as a legal basis.

And to have a new orientation that allows us to lay the foundations that must guarantee citizens the security and quality they choose at each moment. Especially because it also allows to regulate clearly the role of the States, both those of origin that have to make the payment and those in which the treatment is received.

But I believe that we should not be satisfied with that alone, but that this has to be the beginning of a much greater advance that makes, as Mrs. Romperen said, this directive a mere formality, because the level of equality achieved in all states makes the movements of each citizen to each country unnecessary.

And in that struggle we must obtain a standard that guarantees more the right of citizens in relation to the attention they must receive, benefits, accessibility and security, than the mere right they already have to mobility between states.
Equality is what will make us united and if not, we will be taking very small steps.

Madam President, the Spanish Socialist delegation has voted in favor, as has the rest of our group, but I would not leave here peacefully without expressing my concern because this directive includes...
The issue of organ transplants against the criteria of the Environment Commission as a result of the Council's persistent insistence on including transplants in this directive.

I hope that this inclusion does not harm the effectiveness of the good legislation that we approved in this very same plenary session, both with the transplant directive and with the action plan, not long ago and with almost total support.

And I warn that we will be vigilant that this inclusion does not undermine the good work done by such successful organizations as the National Transplant Organization of Spain and, of course, with the intention of saving 20,000 lives that we had both in the Transplant Directive and in the Action Plan that, I repeat, we approved here.
Therefore, I make it clear and say that we will continue to be attentive to the compliance of this directive in this regard.
Mr. President, today is also the European Day for Sexual Health.
Ladies, the data is worrying. The World Health Organization estimates that more than 300 million people are infected each year with a sexually transmitted disease.
In Europe, as the European Sexual Health Forum warns, the number of unwanted pregnancies among teenagers is worrying due to an excessive deficit of education and information among our young people.

As the Commission points out, there are different and diverse inequalities in Europe in terms of access to sexual health services, depending on the country and, within them, on the income level of citizens.
To combat all of this, a European strategy is needed.

Only in five member states are there plans in this regard, but in all of them the number of unwanted pregnancies, the number of sexually transmitted diseases and the number of abortions have been reduced.
A common strategy that bets on prevention from the educational field, that expands information policies, that increases efforts in family planning and facilitates access to contraceptive methods.
A transversal and ambitious strategy, free of taboos, to guarantee the rights of all citizens to sexual health in the best conditions of safety and health.
In a moment of strong social tensions, one cannot help but welcome with enthusiasm the great social agreement in Spain between the government, the unions and the employers.
This agreement is exemplary for Europe, where such milestones have not been produced for a long time.

The reasoning of Cándido Méndez, one of the main protagonists of that Spanish pact, who attended the meeting of the Economic and Social Council in Brussels last Tuesday, February 8, should also be taken into account.
Cándido then insisted on the need to extend the agreement to the European scale and on the need to have the voice and union initiative in our Europe.
That’s how it should be.
Mr. President, with all due respect, in matters of terrorism and immigration, I have seen that the European Union unfortunately moves in response to emergency situations, such as a serious attack.
an attack or a massive landing of immigrants like the one currently taking place in Lampedusa, where the exodus of citizens from Tunisia to the Italian coasts can end in a foretold death.

The journey of hope can end up being a cursed journey and it will weigh on our conscience, on the conscience of all those who witness these continuous uncontrolled flows and do not say enough with the sufficient authority.
When it happens, we will be shocked, but the next day we will forget about it.

European citizens have the obligation and the right to know the truth, that the Mediterranean strategy is not working, that the common immigration policy will continue to be a dream while European countries do not commit sufficient economic means so that Frontex is effective.
Talking costs nothing, but you have to act.
Do you really think that Frontex can guarantee the security of the European borders today?
I don’t think so.

And let us hope that the citizens of Tunisia, Egypt and other Maghreb countries do not decide en masse to seek a better future in Europe, but rather do so in their own countries, because that is what they have fought for, and we should contribute to help them.
Therefore, solidarity, responsibility, but above all, truth, when talking about a common European migration policy, which is more necessary than ever today.

Madam President, it has been said already, the backbone of the pension systems in Europe is and must continue to be the public system, because this is the only system that guarantees cohesion and the only one that also reduces the risk of poverty in our society.

It is striking that in OECD countries, the highest levels of income equity for citizens are found in pensions, or that due to the crisis, private pensions lost only 20% of their value in 2008 and are still far from the required solvency levels today.

All this demonstrates that, at a time of unavoidable reforms, the sustainability of our pension system must be done in a cross-cutting manner, taking into account, among other factors, ambitious policies on birth rates or work-life balance.

ambitious policies for access and permanence in employment, or even immigration policies based on integration that also guarantee, from a demographic point of view, the sustainability of our pensions.
Lastly, I regret that the text does not set limits on the abuse of the figure of scholarships in companies, since, in general, these are excluded from any type of social security contribution.

In my opinion, this is essential for a whole new generation of workers, who, if they are being asked to work more to have a decent pension, it would also be necessary to make them work less to access decent work.
