Mr. President, Commissioner, we are at a key moment in the construction of the future cohesion policy, which, after the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, focuses not only on economic and social aspects, but also on territorial ones.
Territorial cohesion seeks harmonious development between territories so that their citizens can make the most of their territorial singularities.
But to achieve this goal, it is also necessary to advance in the field of cooperation between the regions of the Union that face the same challenges and the same problems.

This is the objective pursued by the European Union's strategy for the Atlantic region: a common perspective to address the common challenges faced by the states in the region, among others, marine research, maritime surveillance and environmental and economic challenges.

To achieve our goals, it is necessary to adopt an integrated strategic approach that is in line with the 2020 Strategy and the policies of the European Union for the period after 2013, especially with the regional policy and the maritime policy.
But, ladies and gentlemen, above all, it is necessary that this strategy is based on renewed multilevel governance, based on closer participation of public authorities,
regional and local, the Member States, the European Union and the private sector stakeholders and civil society organisations, including interregional organisations and networks.

It is a very significant day to talk about equality between men and women, because we celebrate Women's Day, remembering those who 100 years ago fought for labor and economic rights and for women's suffrage.
We have made a lot of progress in these 100 years, but there is still a lot to do, and true equality is still a dream, and discrimination against women is a real fact.

I believe that each one of us, men and women, can do much more to achieve the true emancipation of women, because there are many women in the world who have their right to live threatened, their dignity violated and their freedom denied.
Allow me to show my support and hope to all the women who are fighting for their democratic rights in the North African revolution on this International Women's Day.
Because a woman cannot be worth half a man, neither in Arab countries nor anywhere in the world.
Therefore, we are worth the same and deserve the same.
And I will continue to fight to achieve it. And while that equality does not exist, International Women's Day will continue to exist.
Although many do not want to see it, it is a reality that there are women who earn half of what men do, that domestic violence affects women and children above all.
And I repeat, we must continue to denounce all these events in this Parliament and, of course, I promise that I will continue to work.
Mr. President, I want to express my agreement with the opinion of the deputies who have spoken this morning here and who insist on respect for Parliament and the Commission.
Therefore, my modest affirmative vote will depend on the European Council being willing to accept the role of the institutions mentioned.
Because the new mechanism we are talking about must be an important component of the economic governance led by the European Union.
capable of ensuring the coherence between the common economic policy, which must set clear, precise and limited objectives, and this stability instrument.

That is, it must be avoided at all costs that this effort in which we are involved ends up in the intergovernmental path, which is a dead end, or the path of the predominance of a few states, because all of that would frustrate the reform.
Dear colleagues, Europe is built stone by stone, and this is one of the stones that strengthen and balance this delicate building.
There are still essential points to improve, so we have to send the report back to the committee.
The Inter-Parliamentary Union does not endorse this report.
The initial proposal was bad.
This is what the consumer associations at the national and European level were telling us.
And especially I value the work of the Consumers Union of Asturias and its president, the indefatigable Dacio Alonso.
We have managed to reject the general principle of maximum harmonization of the old article 4.

It must be said loud and clear that maximum harmonization, by establishing the same protection in all Member States, would mean a reduction in the protection of many consumers, since there is a greater tradition in the protection of consumer rights in various countries.

I would like to emphasize, in any case, that it is essential to ensure that the list of abusive contractual clauses is not exhaustive, so that each Member State can increase the number of clauses that it considers unacceptable and invalid in contracts with consumers.

It reverses the burden of proof in individual clauses, so that it is the traders who have to prove that the clauses that deviate from the generally established have been individually negotiated. That the contractual clauses must be expressed in a clear and understandable manner.
We continue to oppose the establishment of maximum harmonization regarding abusive clauses.
The Eurobarometer indicates that 79% of traders believe that full harmonization in this field will have little or no effect on their activities abroad.
Thank you, Mr. President, Madam Commissioner. First of all, let me congratulate the rapporteur, Mr. Schwab, and Ms. Gerhart for the excellent work done.
And a general reflection.
It is not about increasing protectionism, but rather about not cutting back on rights that already exist in some of the member states.
Because if we want and pursue to establish a true internal market for the relations between companies and consumers, we must...
Establish, in parallel, a balance between the high level of protection of consumer rights and the defense of the competitiveness of companies.
This balance involves agreeing on a minimum harmonization and on the possibility of allowing Member States to maintain or adopt additional regulations that improve consumer protection.
We cannot allow the adoption of a community regulation to mean the lack of protection for many consumers and users.
I am glad that the negotiations in the European Parliament have improved, but I would like to insist that the rights that have been established so far are not cut.

Mr. President, many experts are telling us that the next crisis may be an energy crisis and that we are either not doing the necessary homework to avoid it or we are not doing it at the necessary speed to avoid it.
This coming Saturday, the World Forum for Nature is calling on everyone to make a small gesture in the area of sustainability.
Many citizens will turn off the lights for an hour and many public administrations will follow suit.
But it is not enough.
Europe cannot continue to depend on energies that are not its own, that are far away, or on insecure energies.
We must help the States to build a new energy model in which renewable energies are the heart of the new world.
We must also support the awareness of new consumption patterns, because without a doubt, renewables and efficiency are the keys to future sustainability.

Lastly, I want to make a call to all the countries of the Union to join that call, that will of five of those states, including Spain, to increase the reduction of CO2 emissions by up to 30%, because that way we would demonstrate that Europe, in addition to being a vanguard of freedom and rights, is also a vanguard in its commitment to the sustainability of the planet.
Thank you. Most of the times I have spoken in this Parliament, I have done so to denounce violence against women. And I am here again to fight it.

I must say that I am not only not tired of it, but I consider it essential to continue speaking publicly about this violation of human rights, since there is no cause that can be defended without a sounding board, and this Parliament is the best place to do so.

I have a loudspeaker at my disposal to defend all those women who suffer daily abuse and who need us, legislators, to force the States to punish the aggressors according to the severity of the crime and also to help the victims.

When it is estimated that one in four European women have suffered gender violence at least once in their lives, and that children have also suffered it to the same extent, I believe it is impossible not to demand a greater commitment, such as the one recognized by the Commission in its action plan.

I believe it is necessary to keep insisting over and over again to protect the victims as we already did in the European Order of Protection of Victims, of which I was the rapporteur, and I hope it will become a reality as soon as possible.
This report has had great consensus and support from the beginning, which shows that when it comes to addressing domestic violence, which affects all members of the family,
Family, children, elderly people, women and men should not be a reason for political opportunism, since it is an honor for all of us to advance in the solution of this social scourge.
The first thing is not to keep quiet and the second is to get to work, since although we have been talking about gender violence for decades, we have not been able to reduce the number of deaths.

We must be doing something wrong, so it is time to forget about demagogy and to think and move from words to deeds, providing more real help and the necessary action so that women can live with dignity and security.
Rest assured, all victims, that I will always be here to continue lending you my voice until, together, we manage to defeat this pandemic.
A terrible enemy that sadly ends the lives of so many innocents. I say enough, enough already, and I ask all of you to say it with me.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. Thank you very much, Mr. Commissioner. I agree with you that we must listen to the citizens and regain confidence in the European project.
That is why today can be a great day for Europe and the construction of the European social model.

Because with the approval of these reports, we not only move forward towards the reactivation of the single market, a key element in the face of the current economic crisis, but we also respond to the demands of citizens who ask to move forward towards more Europe and strengthen social rights.
Europe must respond to the new global challenges and make the European economy a highly competitive social market economy that creates sustainable growth with more and better jobs.

But this objective must be based on the insertion of a social clause in all legislation related to the internal market. That they put citizens at the center of our attention and priority and strengthening their social rights.
Lastly, I would like to ask the Commission to present these proposals as soon as possible.
Mr. President, the blue tongue has been a constant threat to our livestock and, with it, to our public health.

A disease against which we fought through the use of the live vaccine, whose use entails the creation of restricted areas for the circulation of animals, because the use of these vaccines can cause unwanted circulation of the virus in uninfected animals.

For these reasons, the use of the vaccine, the use of vaccination was limited to the area where animals infected previously had been found, creating a double damage for the farmers. On the one hand, the disease and on the other hand, the restrictions.

But all these problems seem to be avoidable through the new inactivated vaccine, which, in addition to preventing the disruptions that can be caused in the internal livestock market, allows for the development of new and broader strategies, which is truly important for prevention in the fight against this disease.
For all of the above, it is vital for this sector that we modify the directive to allow its use, and that we do so as soon as possible.

Ladies and gentlemen, compliance with our treaties, especially with regard to the correspondence tables, cannot be used as an excuse for this regulation not to come into force before the summer, because with our delay, with your delay, we would only be harming livestock farmers.

Thank you, Mr. President. First of all, I would like to thank the Petitions Committee for the work it has done following the complaint filed by FEPEX, which is the Spanish Association of Producers and Exporters of Fruits and Vegetables, based on the report published in 2007 by OLAF, the European Anti-Fraud Office.

I believe the conclusions of this report are crystal clear and more than justify the European Commission having already set to work a long time ago to clarify the operation of the entry price system, at least with regard to the tomato sector.

However, the Commission has not only failed to intervene to solve possible loopholes in the current ticket price regulation, but has also negotiated a new agricultural agreement with Morocco without having previously resolved the flaws in the current import regime.

Ladies and gentlemen, it is high time that the European Commission takes its responsibilities seriously and starts investigating where frauds are taking place and, if necessary, requests the recovery of unpaid customs duties.
I think that in no way should a new agreement with Morocco be ratified without having resolved the details that we have exposed.

Our goal is not to stop the signing of international agreements, but to ensure that these agreements do not seriously harm the interests of European production and that the rules signed in these agreements are respected.

Regarding the new agreement with Morocco, the European fruit and vegetable sector only asks for guarantees that the effective compliance with the agreed measures is carried out, and this is only possible through the reform of the entry price regime in force.
Until we have a new entry price system, we cannot have a new agreement with Morocco.
We will not be able to ratify that agreement that the Commission has already closed.

Moreover, if it is the responsibility of the Member States to carry out this control, a significant economic effort should be demanded from the Member States. But it is also true that we have been demanding for a long time that there be a European customs border system, similar to the one in the United States, to ensure effective control.

Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. Commissioner, dealing with this report in Parliament has been complex, mainly because it involves measures that require the approval of the World Trade Organization, and the preliminary proposal of the Commission that was sent to Parliament is different from the one sent to Geneva.
We believe that it is necessary to help Pakistan. We understand that, exceptionally, commercial preferences can be granted, as long as they take into account the sensitivities of the environment.
European industry, and especially the textile sector, in communities such as the Valencian Community in Spain, are severely affected by the consequences of the crisis.

But this report has allowed us to verify that probably the measures that can be taken within the framework of international trade cannot be dealt with the urgency that these acts need, so we should learn for the future.

Help Pakistan, yes, but not with the original proposal of the Commission, since it does not take into account the effects on the European industry in terms of the application deadlines for sensitive products and
It would even delay the application of these measures for not coinciding with the pending text to be approved by the WTO. We would be late.
Therefore, we consider it unacceptable to maintain this proposal and we think that we will have to vote no.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I would like to begin my intervention by congratulating all those who have made it possible to reach an agreement.
It is an agreement that we all should be proud of because it affects the daily life of all citizens. But with the constructive spirit that characterizes me, I would like to make some clarifications.
First of all, I would like to draw attention to the importance of providing precise, relevant, but above all, understandable and uniform information.
...for consumers on the components of textile products. It will be of no use to provide exhaustive information if citizens are not able to decipher it.
We have achieved a positive step, necessary but not sufficient. We should advance further and protect the citizens who could become more vulnerable.
Ladies, it is essential to establish a European system of size labeling based on body measurements, because the first thing we encounter when we go to buy an item of clothing is the size.
That is why we should be much more ambitious and seek the harmonization of sizes.
Mr. President, three notes on the situation created around the cucumbers.
I am a grandson of a German and I have a great affection for that country, but it is evident that the German authorities have acted in this case with haste and imprudence.

On the other hand, if we analyze the European action, we notice that the one developed by the Food Safety Authority and by the Commission has been weak, very low-key and imprecise. It has not known how to coordinate or direct.
Third, the victims have the right to receive economic compensation quickly.
But for now, I propose to this Parliament that we organize in Brussels or here in Strasbourg a great European gastronomy exhibition based precisely on the cucumber.
We must reclaim the lost honor, an expression dear to the German writer Heinrich Böll. We must reclaim the lost honor of the cucumber producers.
Europe is the appropriate setting for it.
Mr. President, first of all, I am obliged to express my sincere condolences for the 23 victims who have already died, 22 in Germany and one in Sweden.
This crisis is, we must say, the most evident proof that the European Union must improve, and greatly, its food alert system and its internal coordination.
The Member States involved have shown slowness, inefficiency, and inoperativeness, and at this point, after 23 deaths, we still do not know where the problem comes from.

The European Commission must seriously reflect on the problems it causes through its irresponsible actions or inaction in times of crisis such as the current one, leading to cases of economic ruin and the destruction of jobs that were previously necessary.

rates of unemployment, helplessness and, of course, a health crisis with extremely high health risks for the population. Because while you were echoing irresponsible statements from regional authorities in the Commission,

German companies, very poorly informed and quite irresponsible, with names and surnames of Spanish farms. Meanwhile, the population continued to be exposed without knowing the bacteria, believing they were avoiding it, the citizens were more exposed than ever to eating something that could harm them.

The European Commission should today, at the Agriculture Council that is being held in Luxembourg at 2 pm, propose to the ministers that part of the 2,500 million euros that exist as unused remnants of the Common Agricultural Policy be used.
...those 2,500 million euros to repair, as much as possible, the damage caused.
For this, it is necessary to find a legal loophole that allows it. A legal loophole that has already been found on other occasions, such as mad cow disease or dioxins, and that should be found now.
Therefore, gentlemen commissioners, gentlemen ministers, today in Luxembourg you must be up to your responsibility.

The German authorities, moreover, given the irresponsible accusations made, should support this economic solution, without a doubt, and from the beginning, and also fund, with their own funds, communication campaigns to establish the trust of consumers lost in the fruit and vegetable productions. Thank you.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, nothing we do here or in the European Union will bring back the dead, and hopefully what is being done will prevent more deaths and stop the chain of people who are suffering without having done anything to deserve it.

We do not know the causes, surely, but we do know some things that we must call by their name. There has been negligence in political actions and there has been negligence in the German federal government. It cannot act as if Hamburg were a city-state of another continent.

The arrogance that Mrs. Merkel and her health minister have to address other states with unusual frequency, if they had translated it into diligence and effectiveness to coordinate, some of the things that have happened would not have occurred.

And that negligence has had criminal consequences on a State, which has been the Spanish State, and on its most important sector, agriculture. And it has led to the ruin of thousands of families and small business owners, and has discredited the economy for a long time.
I ask you to go to the Council and ask for full compensation for those affected, since we cannot ask for life for the dead.
and that the control systems be reviewed.
and that Mrs. Merkel be held accountable.
and that they are asked for less arrogance and more diligence.
and that he be held accountable for the damage he has caused.
You cannot ignore that Hamburg is in your state.
You cannot ignore your responsibilities.
It cannot hide behind a decentralized and federal state to cause the damage it has caused.

A little more humility, a little better management and a little less conservatism would have been very good for this crisis not to get out of hand and for Spain and other southern farmers not to have to suffer its painful consequences.
Review the controls, review the alert systems and demand responsibilities because in Spain we are asking you, Mr. Commissioner, you, the Council and the German State.
Mr. President, we are facing a public health problem, an epidemic, as the Commissioner has said, and in this regard, we have looked for culprits instead of the cause.

The system has not worked. We have 22 dead, 1,600 affected and we do not know the cause three weeks later. And appealing to a precautionary principle without scientific basis, I repeat, without scientific basis, Spain is blamed.
Honorable members of Parliament, the Spanish cucumbers were not contaminated.
They were not contaminated. I repeat this because some contrary versions have been heard here.
But so that you can see the importance of what these words have caused, 300,000 jobs could be affected, a loss of confidence.
An epidemic does not recognize borders.

I agree with you, Mr. Commissioner, you do not know borders. We ask for responsibility for what has not been done, for what we must do immediately, because Germany has a risk problem at this moment, it has a greater number of affected people, but Spain is not to blame.
We are asking for compensation.
What is important and what unites us today here are the victims, because nobody should feel as unprotected as we European consumers feel today.
And it is out of respect for the victims that we need clarity and responsibility.

And it is my responsibility to denounce the German authorities who unjustly and hastily accused Spanish cucumbers, and specifically the cooperatives of Málaga and Almería, which were models of exploitation and which will not recover from these accusations.
Thousands of families without work are asking themselves why. Why do they need an answer and, above all, what will their future be? Not only in Andalusia, but in all of agricultural Europe.

Therefore, and trusting that the experts will find a quick solution, I demand that the Commission, when it goes today to speak with the Council, ask for immediate economic and moral measures for all the producers who, from Andalusia and from all over Europe, look at us with indignation but with hope.
Instead of promoting research and European collaboration, the German authorities have slandered and harmed cucumber producers and others.
And still no one has resigned in Germany, nor have reparations been offered commensurate with the damage caused.
It is Germany that has a serious credibility problem.
Is the treatment of Mrs. Merkel towards the southern countries in terms of agriculture and finance intolerable?
Someone said that Merkel was a disciple of Adenauer and Kohl.
None of that! It lacks credibility! Morale!
Mr. President, it is no coincidence that Spain, Italy, Greece, Ireland, Portugal, and another country coincide in our reluctance to accept the call for the Eurobond with good grace.

The criticism is due to our condition as peripheral countries, which in the end will be the ones to pay this singular tax that the states of the European Union with geographical centrality will collect.
The reasoning behind the Eurovignette is full of contradictions and the supporting discourse is becoming increasingly weak.

Although the rationality of internalizing external costs is accepted as a starting point, it is not supported that only large vehicles are penalized to alleviate congestion, leaving out passenger cars. In the same terms, the old motto of "the polluter pays" is applied with evident discrimination.

On the other hand, ladies and gentlemen, the Eurovignette, which was conceived as a source of funding for infrastructure, will ultimately only have 15% allocated to the financing of the trans-European networks, and not in a mandatory way.

but as a simple recommendation. In any case, the Minister of Finance in office will allocate the funds collected to the end that he deems most convenient for the interests of his country, within the broad chapter of infrastructures.
The final result will be nothing more than another blow to the transport of goods by road, which is currently the only mode that is allowing the internal market.
This is the reality, ladies and gentlemen, a reality that is much harsher in a context of economic crisis.

In this sense, the competitiveness of European products in world markets cannot allow experiments that may contribute to further deteriorating the precarious situation of the European economy with the imposition of new added costs.

The food crisis, which has been recklessly blamed on Spanish products, has resulted in an unfair penalty and huge losses for those who are penalized by the euro vignette, namely goods transporters and early crop farmers.
These are the reasons, ladies and gentlemen, why the Spanish delegation of the European People's Party will vote against this directive.

You will all understand, dear colleagues, that in taking the chair of the session, I express my sorrow and consternation at the death of Jorge Semprún, which occurred a few hours ago at the age of 87.

In Jorge Semprún we celebrate the one who was a prisoner in the Buchenwald concentration and extermination camp, the fighter against the forces of Nazism in France and against the Franco dictatorship in my country, Spain.
We also celebrate the very notable committed writer, a particular collaborator of our program The European Book of the Year, and we also celebrate the convinced European politician.

I mourn his death, as well as his colleague and friend, and I will ask President Buzek to convey a message of condolence and solidarity to his family and to the Government of Spain, which I am sure we all share here.
The creation of an economic government space governed by the principles of federalism adapted to the European construction.
We cannot keep turning a blind eye.
It is incoherent to have a single currency and at the same time lack the fiscal and financial instruments that this currency requires.
In concrete terms, therefore, we need the issuance of European debt, a firm no to competition between the issuance of debt by States, the creation of a genuine European public treasury, the
Harmonization of tax policies that guarantee equality for citizens, combat tax fraud and help to define a progressive European social policy based on effective public services.
These ideas are, it will be seen, elementary.
But they have to be repeated and repeated, because nobody listens to them.
And precisely because they do not listen, those dark times that the poet Bertolt Brecht spoke of are approaching.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen. The current economic and financial crisis we are experiencing highlights the need for regional policy as the best instrument to reduce the development differences between regions and states.
At the same time, we can recover the positive image of Europe that, lately, citizens only associate with harsh adjustment plans and social cuts.

The future cohesion policy, a pillar of the solidarity of the European project and social justice, must take into account the following priorities: first, to strengthen social cohesion and integrate the challenges posed by the 2020 Strategy; second, to take into account the needs and characteristics

geographical features of the regions, especially the most disadvantaged ones; third, to maintain the principle of graduality in the receipt of funds, so that the regions do not abandon the objective of convergence, avoiding abrupt changes in the receipt of aid; and fourth, to promote a system
equitable.
Lastly, ladies and gentlemen, the authorities are applying harsh budgetary adjustment policies.
Therefore, the support of the Union is necessary.
I hope the Council takes good note.

In defense of fundamental rights, I ask the responsible institutions to review the designation of San Sebastian as European Capital of Culture, because I believe it was chosen following a political criterion, which implies discrimination against the other aspiring cities.

The president of the court said that she was chosen to support the peace process. And as far as I know, in Spain there is a terrorist organization called ETA that to this day has not given up its weapons and that two months ago managed to have its political arm, Bildu, govern, among other municipalities, San Sebastian.
I do not believe that from Europe we should give such a powerful voice to those who do not condemn terrorist violence and will make propaganda to share blame between victims and murderers.
Murderers! Where is the right to freedom and dignity?
Of course not in San Sebastián, where our colleagues like Mayor Oreja, Turgay, Salva or myself have to be escorted.
I believe in the culture of life, not in the culture of death.
Could there be true culture without freedom?
No, a thousand times no.
When San Sebastian is a city free for all, then they can present their candidacy again. And in the meantime, they should learn the culture of respect for those who think differently.
Because tomorrow they might deserve it, but today, with Batasuna and their heirs in the institutions, they do not deserve it.
Mr. President, first of all, I would like to thank the speakers in the shadows for the fruitful collaboration they have given me when drafting it.
I say the same about the other deputies, colleagues of the Commission of this Parliament.
Sixty years ago, the European Coal and Steel Community was created. There is no better way to commemorate this event than to discuss energy infrastructure in Europe.

Today, the European Union has clearly defined the objectives of its policy: a common European internal market, the promotion of renewable energies as a means or instrument to fight climate change, supply security and diversification of its sources.
The Treaty of Lisbon has consecrated a title to energy, the 21st, where these commitments that I have just mentioned are formulated, and also the promotion of the interconnection of energy networks.
Well, the objective of the report we have prepared is aimed at correcting energy infrastructures that, in the opinion of the European Commission, are outdated and poorly interconnected.
For example, we are seeing a spectacular increase in wind-generated electricity in the North Sea and the Baltic, with the immense potential for renewable energy in the south of
in Europe and North Africa, with the problems derived from large-scale electricity storage, with the needs of recharging electric vehicles, among many other urgent issues.
All of this is impossible to face today if we do not devise new networks and new connections, both within the European Union and with third countries.

It is therefore a matter of advancing in the coming years in the determination of the necessary infrastructures, a) establishing the criteria that allow the selection of projects of European interest.
b) eliminating energy islands; c) ensuring the execution of these projects within reasonable deadlines and arbitrating formulas to solve the conflictive issue of the
procedures for authorisation and licences in the Member States; d) ensuring financing that attracts and encourages private investment, without prejudice to the public support that may be necessary.
Energy efficiency and savings, as well as smart grids, are central ingredients in the new design incorporated into the report because we have
It is believed that by reducing energy demand, dependence on imports can be reduced, with the consequent effect on infrastructure needs.
The main concern of this report from the very beginning has been the processing of the licenses and authorizations intended to allow the execution of the necessary works.
In the present, they are eternalized.
and are delayed by the opposition of the populations to seeing towers or other types of installations grow in their neighborhood.

To solve this conflict, early information to the citizens has been considered, as well as establishing a warning system in case the authorities of a State do not attend to a request within a reasonable time.
We are facing ambitious goals for which the participation of everyone is necessary.
In this sense, companies in the sector are essential, and they demand a stable regulatory framework, the best way to ensure the financing of their efforts.
So far, the energy policy of the European Union, both towards the outside of its borders and within them, has lacked a decidedly European drive.
Europe must speak with one voice, a voice that is clearly audible and resonates well in the European building's vault, because it is from our energy fragility that we must...
to find the strength to build a Europe that is solid and vigorous in terms of energy, a worthy successor in this anniversary year of that great invention that was the ECSC, our cradle, precisely.
Mr. President, every time there is a commitment that allows us to move forward, we should be happy, but I also don't think that the commitment we have reached is something to die of happiness.
We must be cautious in the moments of happiness that we have.

It is true that we have made progress, especially in terms of food labeling, especially in terms of safety, in the clarity of the message, but we have fallen short in trans fats and, for example, in the obligation to label them.
What I do ask of the Commission is that it does not extend the deadlines.

In a continent as well-fed as this one, with problems of overfeeding, heart issues, and overweight, we need to speed up and propose as soon as possible the prohibition of adding trans fats to food, as Denmark has done, as Spain is doing, as Australia has done.
Without delay and without waiting any longer.
The commitments will depend on the speed with which we apply them, the clarity with which we develop them and how ambitious we are.
We should not get stuck in the happiness attack for what we have done, because it is good, but it is not for jumping.
We have to move forward and be more precise, especially on the issues I have pointed out.
I wanted to tell everyone that there is only one type of terrorism. There is only that terrorism that destroys the lives of innocents. It doesn’t matter where it comes from.
The victims of terrorism, whom I represent, because the terrorist organization ETA murdered my brother and his wife, have a common thread, and in the name of that
I mean that this report, with this long name, and that could have been an ambitious thing, it is not.
The result is disappointing.
It does not represent us, it does not represent the aspirations of justice and that balance that we talk so much about here between freedom and security.
It does not represent us and I believe that a report, a report on terrorism, should be thanked by the victims of terrorism, who do not thank it.
Therefore, I ask for my vote against this report.
What the economy and European companies need is confidence.
Today, auditing firms are hampered by concentration and the lack of independence of auditors, and they do not contribute to generating the much-desired confidence that would boost our economy.
It would not be out of the question to consider eliminating the legal obligation of auditing accounts.
Why not?
If we want to regain the trust of the markets and in the markets, we must carry out a deep reform of the audits so that they represent a true added value and not a mere legal burden.
The big auditing firms use auditing services as a business card for their future clients.
Once they are familiar with the company, they offer more expensive complementary services, with which they often compensate for the low prices of the strict audit.
We have a problem of price distortion in the sector.

These complementary services already account for almost 50% of the billing, so the big auditors do not want to lose the auditing services, not for the auditing itself, but to maintain and increase the complementary services.
The second major obstacle to free competition in the sector is the oligopoly of the four big companies that dominate the European markets by more than 90%.
As such, the oligopoly controls prices and establishes barriers to entry for new competitors, taking advantage of intangibles such as the international image of the brand.

It is true that this brand image can be based on certain advantages, but it does not always mean greater efficiency, given the legislative diversity in the accounting states subject to particular treatment in each member state.
I share the goals of the Green Book, the independence and the concentration of the sector, and the means to use, rotation, joint audits,
Professional skepticism, reinforcement, substance over form, separation of audit and non-audit services.
I have tried to include them in my report to the extent that the parliamentary majorities and the modest scope of the report have allowed me to.
Ladies and gentlemen, this is nothing more than a small step towards achieving new legislation that will address the flaws in the audit field that have led us to this terrible economic crisis.
Keep up the good work, Mr. Barnier, and achieve a good result.
We are all in this together and no one can save themselves alone.
The emergency requires joint efforts and sacrifices.
The Union is asked for leadership and it is demanded that the mechanisms of direction and decision-making work in real time.
The monetary union cannot survive without a single political direction.
An economic government is needed, a common budget, a certain fiscal harmonization and a shock plan.
Therefore, the first thing to do is to discipline public accounts, correct macroeconomic imbalances and stimulate competitiveness.
Let no one spend more than what their economic growth allows.
Another part is to regret the intergovernmental nature of the financial stability mechanism.
The European Union needs a permanent crisis resolution mechanism under the community method, a European Monetary Fund.

If Europe wants to have leadership, ladies and gentlemen, these decisions must be driven by the European Parliament and the Commission, more than by the Council, which is tied and slowed down in its times by the governments.
The States are in charge of doing their homework to contribute to the Union as a whole in its decisions, in addition to fully applying themselves to an essential task: growing and creating jobs.
In Spain, more than a year ago, our leader Mariano Rajoy offered in a parliamentary session his willingness to modify the Constitution in a specific way.
And last week, the Parliament, after the solemn offer of the President of the Government, reached a consensus on these terms.
The commitment to sound public accounts cannot be circumstantial; it must be, ladies and gentlemen, permanent.
Mr. President, I am a councilor of a small town in central Spain, and if it is true that the sector represents an opportunity for the European Union as a whole, this is much more relevant for the

...of our rural areas for three reasons. The first is that it diversifies the economy, representing a new opportunity for women and young people, which also means a policy to keep the population in our rural areas, because they are also...

They are totally complementary to the activities of the primary sector, and even reinforce it, in the case of agritourism, and because, unlike the coastal sector, there is not so much seasonality, which can also mean new jobs of longer duration and better quality.

For this reason, I want to highlight that this report does not fall into the error of marking a European strategy once again based on the coastal sector or the urban sector, and that it bets on the rural sector, especially in what refers to its competitiveness, investments, training and...
innovation, its commitment to excellence and uniformity of quality criteria, and greater visibility, also incorporating rural tourism transversally in all and each of the actions of the Commission.
Therefore, I would like to congratulate the Commission.
Madam, thank you very much, Madam President. Despite the lateness of the hour, this is a fundamental issue. We are talking about optimizing the...
Absorption of structural and cohesion funds, to achieve the maximum contribution of the available resources of regional policy to economic and social cohesion.

It is necessary to correct the main factors that cause absorption problems and promote the simplification and flexibilization of regulations and procedures, the access of project promoters to European funds and their good management by administrative services.
Likewise, we must pursue and sanction fraud, rather than focusing on minor formal irregularities, and promote greater synergy and complementarity between funds.

Lastly, I would like to specifically emphasize the importance of achieving maximum efficiency in the implementation of the European Social Fund, in order to respond to the current employment challenges derived from the current financial recession.
Ladies and gentlemen, it is necessary to recover the sense of direction of the European project, because Europe can be built on necessity, but it also needs ambition.
Thank you, Mr. President. This morning, the President of the Commission, Mr. Barroso, has raised this issue in the State of the Union.
This gives an idea of the importance that the Commission gives to it.
He has spoken of hope, inclusion and solidarity.

In a moment of economic crisis like the one we are in, where there are more and more unemployed people, more and more people are on the brink of poverty, this blockade manifested by some member states is the most absolute example of lack of solidarity.
Those countries that oppose, the richest in the European Union, can put at risk the maintenance of a program that with 1% of the budget of the Common Agricultural Policy, helps 18 million people.
The Commissioner is right when he calls out those members of the Council who are unable to show solidarity at this time.
I encourage the Polish Presidency to, from here on, before its presidency ends, to promote and continue with that support to move this program forward.
He deserves it.
And it is deserved by all the people who need it, and the European Union also deserves that vote of confidence and, above all, that response to its citizens.
The Council of Ministers of the Union should also take into account the opinion of the Parliament, not only to maintain the program, but even to improve it, as this Chamber has already requested.
I would also like to remind the Heads of State and Government that we hope, that we trust that in their next summit they will take this matter seriously and will politically unlock this situation.
Madam President, thank you, Mr. Commissioner. As you know, Mr. Commissioner, Parliament in its day rejected in 2008 in a resounding way the resolution proposal that was presented.
Afterwards, in the same terms, the report that I myself presented to the Chamber was approved by a large majority, with great consensus and from the effort of the Commission and the groups.
What were the reasons for this change in attitude of the Parliament?

Undoubtedly, all the requirements demanded to accept the authorization of these scanners have been met. Preservation of fundamental rights, and within these, especially the dignity and privacy of the passenger, non-discrimination, protection of personal data and protection of health.
This is how it was established what type of scanners were suitable to guarantee, on the one hand, the safety of the passenger and, on the other, to preserve their privacy.
The scanners will not use ionizing radiation, they will not be mandatory for either the States or the citizens, and all will protect the rights previously described.

The Commission has taken all these concerns into account, it is true, in its future legislation, but it includes, in addition to standard body scanners, the possibility of another modality, which, while guaranteeing the same set of rights, allows the inspection of a blurred image of the passenger.
We accept the reasons for which it has been necessary to include this alternative as an authorized control method.
The Parliament also defends the need to guarantee fair competition and thus escape any monopolistic temptation.
However, we ask the Commission to maintain all the precepts that we have defended in my report. All the guarantees of preservation of fundamental rights.

In addition, it is encouraged to work with the industry and the Member States to ensure that in the near future only automatic protection scanners are used and that an inspector does not need to view any image.

Our British colleagues in the House of Commons, honoring the admirable historical parliamentary and democratic tradition of their country, have highlighted the intolerable practices of the Murdoch Group.
The bravery of The Guardian is also commendable.
But Murdoch's aberrant tentacles reach other latitudes.
In Spain, José María Aznar, former president of the government, who wants to continue influencing Spanish and even European politics, is on the payroll with a millionaire salary.
We are going to enter the electoral campaign.
The Popular Party and its leader, Mr. Rajoy, should clarify before the campaign to all Europeans how Mr. Murdoch and his cabinet support them, what is it that they

The magnate demands in exchange for financially supporting Mr. Aznar and his foundation, and if that plot has anything to do with what happened in the United Kingdom, which has been commendably made public.

The directive on the rights of victims of crime, including terrorism, and as a Spaniard who has directly suffered the cruelty of the terrorist organization ETA, I want to thank President Vucic for his support for my country and its victims.

I understand the satisfaction of many with this new ETA statement, but I must remind you that we still cannot ring the bells, because to this day they have not handed over the weapons, nor have they dissolved, nor have they asked for forgiveness from their victims.
It is also important for you to know that in Spain we do not have to reach any peace between two sides, because there has been no war.

My brother, Alberto Jiménez Becerril, murdered by ETA in Seville along with his wife, was not coming from the war, he was going to his home where his three children were waiting for him, who would never see him again.
We have the obligation to explain to my brother’s children that their father was better than those who murdered him.
If we accept an ending without winners or losers, we will be teaching those children that killing is a way to achieve political goals.

I therefore ask for the support of this Chamber so that it is not deceived by the terrorists of ETA and their accomplices, and that it listens to the sincere voices of the victims, who only want the peace that comes from justice.
We have to break ArcelorMittal’s strategy and tactics.
I have always opposed the entry of this predatory and delocalizing businessman, Mr. Mittal, into Europe.
Do not allow, Mr. Commissioner, the social barbarity of Mr. Mittal and his executives, who have already become so rich with Arcelor stock options.
Stand up, Mr. Commissioner, in the name of Europe, in the name of European workers, of the peoples of Europe, stand up to Mr. Mittal once and for all.
Congratulations on your upcoming fatherhood, Mr. Ostoyano.
We have finished with this intervention the turn of the hunt for the president's eye in a debate that I believe has been one of the most fascinating that I have had to preside.
I am sure that my male colleagues will not be offended if I say that, as almost always, it is the female colleagues who take the floor the most, and the debates are usually very interesting.
We will now give the floor to the Council's representative, Mr. Radoslav Leskov, to conclude by reacting to the set of interventions that have taken place on such an important topic.
The governments of the member states do not want to give a joint response to a situation of war and profound social and political change on our borders.

Despite my reports on the conditions of reception of asylum seekers, they insist on systematically imprisoning the asylum seekers, those who precisely flee their countries for defending freedom, our freedom and theirs, which are inseparable.
The detention of asylum seekers is both expensive and unfair. It prevents these people from being able to
It prevents them from recovering from the traumas they have experienced, it criminalizes those who have suffered human rights violations, and it wastes everyone’s resources.
Let us use, instead, alternative measures to detention.
In a world that is increasingly bipolar and with our ailing economy, Europe is doomed to indifference and failure.
Let’s reactivate our values.
I join the questions that my colleague and good friend Rui Tavares has raised here.
Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, this crisis is teaching us a lot, but there is one that I think is of special importance, and it is precisely the following.
In the future, it will be necessary to amend the treaties in order to reform the decision-making and agreement adoption procedures within the European institutions.
The diabolical system currently in place is slow, frustrating and, moreover, full of whims.
These vices lead us to inaction and sometimes to paralysis, and from paralysis it is easy to reach economic ruin.
I will repeat it as many times as I can from this modest seat. A federal state can work well or badly. A confederation never works.

Thank you very much, Madam President. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, citizens demand that Europe provide solutions to problems and that Europe is able to achieve a sustainable economic recovery and contribute to the simplification and flexibility of regulations.
The mobility of professionals is not only a fundamental right enshrined in treaties, but also a key factor in the modernization of the labor market and economic development.
For this reason, it is necessary to adapt and update the system for the recognition of professional qualifications to the labor reality and to the demands and needs of professionals and consumers.

The future proposal of the Commission should consider greater transparency and simplification in the rules for the recognition of professional qualifications, an assessment of compensatory measures to solve existing problems, greater

Clarification of the criteria on language skills to ensure the quality of the services provided and to protect the safety of consumers and patients, and greater cooperation and coordination between the competent authorities and the national contact points.
Ladies and gentlemen, Europe must place professionals and consumers at the heart of the single market.
Only in this way will we be able to build a way out of the financial and economic crisis based on sustainable knowledge and social progress.
Thank you very much, Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen. We are facing a very sensitive issue.

On the one hand, we must take into account the cultural traditions and the important sustainable contribution in some states, such as mine, of the game to society through education, culture and sport.
On the other hand, we must fight against crime related to gambling and protect consumers, especially the most vulnerable ones, to avoid excessive or pathological gambling.
For this reason, I believe that in this area the principle of active subsidiarity based on cooperation between national administrations should prevail.
However, we must be ambitious and bet on the development of common rules and coordinated joint action against online gambling operators that operate without the necessary national licenses.
Likewise, we must ensure transparency and make possible non-discriminatory competition that pursues the public interest and the protection of the consumer.
Lastly, we must promote the formation of a network of national organizations that deal with gambling addicts to make possible an exchange of experience and accredited practices.
Madam President, colleagues, I would like to congratulate my friend Kaczmarek for his good report and for his generous flexibility in accepting the amendments I presented to his initial proposal.

After expressing my agreement with much of what has been said here and with the text that we will vote on tomorrow, I will express some satisfaction, some concern and some ideas regarding the work that we have been doing and will continue to do from the European Parliament in the Joint Parliamentary Assembly Africa, Caribbean, Pacific, European Union.

My satisfaction goes to the work of my colleague Luis Michel as co-president of the Assembly and to our friends from the Commission, with Commissioner Pivaz at the head, for their interest, attention and participation in our tasks with the simplicity, cordiality and effectiveness that characterize them.

However, I am concerned that, absorbed by the rest of the work that colleagues are developing in the Eurochamber, there is a notable absence of our representatives in the Parity Assembly whose work we are evaluating here.
It seems obvious to me that colleagues who prioritize other occupations should analyze the situation well in advance.
To give importance to his work in the ACP-EU Assembly, or to leave his place to other colleagues who may have more time for this activity.
On the other hand, I believe that our Parliament, as such, should pay more attention to this same work, that the political importance of the Catanu Agreement should be understood, which...
It is the most representative instance of North-South cooperation, with almost 80 developing countries in the world, in addition to the 27, soon to be 28, that make up the European Union.
At a time when global governance must be articulated in a multilateral key, our ACP partners constitute a huge political potential to articulate joint actions on the international stage.
Our Parliament should also pay more attention to the resolutions that our delegates approve with the ACP colleagues in the Parliamentary Assembly.

We should not continue to approve all kinds of resolutions there with the signature of the European Parliament without even taking note of said texts, at least in the corresponding committees of our Chamber.

The relevant measures must be studied so that, knowing what is debated and approved in the CPUE Assembly, the texts that our Parliament approves in the same areas are coherent and do not give rise, as sometimes may happen, to notable and frankly disconcerting discrepancies for our interlocutors.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner Cholos, I am glad that you are here with us this morning and I hope that today you will answer a little more seriously and a little more clearly.

In the proposal for the reform of the Common Agricultural Policy that you presented to us on October 12, you speak of the elimination of the sugar quota system and also of the maintenance of the planting rights for vineyards.
The European Parliament, in the report of Mr. Des, which we have recently voted on in this Chamber, is in favor of continuing with planting rights from the year 2000 onwards.
It is also in favor of not liberalizing the rights of planting vineyards until 2015 and of maintaining the sugar quota regime until at least 2020.
I ask you, are you going to follow and support the situation of the Parliament and the decision of the Parliament on these two issues?
Well, Mr. Commissioner, I have noticed that in the Council there are already 15 Member States that think differently than they did before.
The fact that Parliament continues to support vineyard planting rights makes us relatively optimistic about the Commission's proposal for next year in the wine report.
Commissioner, thank you for the explanation, but the truth is that at this moment the number of subsidies that Valencian farmers receive is almost nil.
Valencian farmers do not live off subsidies.
Let us hope that the recognition of the capacity of the small farmer that you have just defined and that the Member States will give us will provide us with clarity on the current situation.
Mr. President, the report by our colleague Levin correctly points to the fundamental issue of joining forces in the fight against illegal fishing.

The objectives of a common policy of sustainable fishing, of marine environment protection and of promoting fair competition in fishing are thwarted if illegal fishing is not combated in a committed manner.
The oceans do not have borders, so efforts must be made at both the European and international levels.

Therefore, the European Union must be credible in its policies and must sanction practices such as those recently published, in which community-flagged vessels operate illegally in waters protected by conservation measures.
The problem of illegal fishing is not only a matter of ships flying flags of third countries, but also a problem of European operators.

Moreover, we cannot move forward without having a strong financial instrument that conditions access to public money to the strict implementation of effective controls and application of all fishing regulations.
I believe it is very important to closely follow the application of the European Protection Order.
We talk about reporting, but these reports must be followed by real protection.

We need resources. We can pass good laws, but if we do not provide the countries with the appropriate means, the victims will not trust and will continue to remain silent for fear of being attacked again.
Therefore, it is necessary for judges and police to have the training and resources to do their job well.
That is true justice.
So many victims complain about the application of the law not corresponding to what they need.
It is therefore necessary that we join forces, that we insist on statistics to see how this instrument works, which I believe is truly necessary.
I ask the States to make an effort to understand and apply this European Arrest Warrant, because that is what we have worked for and we believe we have made it clear.

I believe that from now on, the European doors of victims' rights are wide open, that women and men will be able to count on this and other instruments that will bring victims to light and stop those who intimidate them.

Today, with our voices here, and tomorrow, with our votes, we will tell the victims that in the European Parliament we will never forget their rights, the support that society owes them, and most importantly, justice.
Because I tell you that justice is what keeps all the victims alive.
Mr. President, thank you to the Presidency of the Council and to the Commission, Mr. Commissioner, and thank you to all those who have spoken.

But I would be lacking in sincerity if I did not say something. Each one of us is free in this Chamber to defend those interests that we consider appropriate, whether they are from an industrial sector or from here.
We can want whatever we want. But I think we must be honest with ourselves and with others, and not disguise the defense of what we are defending with other names or with issues that cover them up.

Because I have to say that not a single one of the spokespersons who have worked, who have worked well, even like Mr. Litter, have brought these notes of humor that were much needed, none of them have had any complaints from any consumer association.
Therefore, it cannot be said here that we are not collaborating with information for consumers. Nor can anyone claim to be a greater defender of consumers than their own associations.
That is not our intention.
It is advisable to read this directive carefully and respect the work that has been done.

I would also like to dedicate a few words to three interventions, those of Ms. Reis, Mr. Kellis and Ms. Nedelcheva, in reference to the need to promote and consume local products. Because it is true that the European Union, regardless of the country of production, produces more or less.

...less is a consumer and producer power of fruits and packaged juices. And we should, for savings in CO2 emissions to the atmosphere and to boost our own, especially in times of crisis in agriculture, boost to the maximum the consumption of our products.
Therefore, those three interventions that have spoken about this have my support and I join them.

I also assume and support the words of the Commissioner when he says that we must strive to improve in quality and quantity. We have to do it. But the Union is a whole, it does not matter where it is produced and that must also be reflected in the fruits and juices.

Mr. Enerjal, I am reading the directive carefully, because what you are proposing is completely false, because it is not allowed to add flavors from other fruits. It says that flavors from the same species can be added.

What we could not accept is something that is technically impossible, which is to add the aroma, first obligatorily to favor we do not know who, to add that aroma of the same fruit that is being squeezed at that moment in the same juice.
Because when you store tanks of 4 million liters and you need 10,000 liters to extract 2 liters of aroma, it is technically impossible. And they should have told you that.
I truly invite you, with all due respect, to read the directive carefully, which will surely change your opinion.
“Light, more light,” it is said that Goethe asked for in his last moments.
Today, the poet, who was also an effective governor, would surely qualify these statements by invoking savings and efficiency.
Because in a Europe poor in energy resources, it is essential that we know how to distinguish between necessary consumption, which drives the economy, and superfluous consumption.
The latter must be controlled, and to do so, it is urgent to encourage a drastic change in the habits of many European citizens.
When we analyze the economic crisis, we ask for austerity and we also ask for growth stimulus.
Well, there are few better areas to put these beautiful words into practice than the energy sector, where savings and sustainability must be combined.
investments needed for large projects, including the construction of an integrated infrastructure network, whose report I had the honor of presenting before this Parliament.
The Commission should make more concrete efforts than those made so far, because it would strengthen the backbone of Europe.
Only a solid and well-structured European energy policy, efficient and saving, can allow Europe to walk tall and in the right direction.
All the clarifications that come from the Commission in this sense that I have pointed out in my words will be well received.
Mr. President, after the climate conferences held since 1995, it can be said that, as they are conceived, they are doomed to failure.

Indeed, a global agreement is sought and, moreover, to reach it by consensus, an aspiration that is impossible to achieve as a consequence of the very different productive, economic and social structure of the States.
Therefore, in the end, the aim is to achieve the minimum, but these are clearly insufficient.

On the other hand, behind climate change there are very deep problems in societies, such as their development and education models, social differences, poverty, etc. If all of them are to be addressed...

At these summits, the difficulties to reach these agreements will increase. Especially if, as is the case, they become large fairs, large international exhibitions with thousands and thousands of participants.
The European Union must keep its environmental flags flying, which Commissioner Hedegaard did very well in Durban.
Therefore, my congratulations.
These summits, Mr. President, colleagues, would need greater coherence among the States, more diplomatic work and less festival exhibition.

Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, my first words are to thank my colleague, Ms. Patrao, because over these months she has defended, against all odds, the opportunity of this resolution that we are debating today and that we will vote on later.
There have been many obstacles that Mrs. Patrao has had to overcome with the support of the Popular Group, and I want to congratulate her for the work that has brought us to this day.
Ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues, 50 years ago the farmer received 50% of the final price paid by the consumer. However, now it does not even reach 10% in many cases.
At the same time, in 20 years, distribution chains have gone from having a 21.7% market share to 70%.
Something is happening and it is evident.
Measures must be taken to make the food distribution chain more equitable, more egalitarian, more just.

First, we must improve the safety nets provided by the Common Agricultural Policy to ensure adequate prices. We must provide a community framework that ensures balanced relationships and prevents abuses. We must typify and prohibit abusive practices.

abusive in those commercial margins. Production will have to be concentrated by promoting producer organizations, farmers and ranchers. And equal competition conditions will have to be ensured for all producers with

Equal opportunities and equal obligations. And I am referring to those producers who are outside the European Union and do not comply with the same quality standards, food safety, animal welfare and all those things that are so necessary that we oblige our producers to do.
Where do we do all this?
Well, in the next reform of the CAP.
We must improve contractual relations in that reform of the PAC.
The objective is to improve the positioning of the primary sector within the chain, to improve the commercial policy of distribution, to improve a constant increase in food speculation.

To take into account and improve those margins that are causing an increase in non-agricultural costs. And lastly, to assure producers, thank you Madam President, that all products in the Union market comply with the same quality standards.
Mr. President, intellectual property violations may seem like a game, but they kill the game.

They eliminate equality in free competition so that the most dishonest player wins. That is, the one who does not respect the rules, who does not pay taxes, who does not comply with the rights of workers or customers.
In this report, we have finally overcome the term “piracy”.
We believe that the term piracy is misleading, since we do not understand its relation to the boarding of ships at sea or to the mythical legends of pirates.
Even the offenders themselves have sometimes made a flag of this term to present themselves as freedom fighters.
The struggle is futile, because they end up serving the interests of large multinationals that want to have content without paying.
Let’s call violations what they are: violations.
In Spanish, we say “to bread, bread, and to wine, wine.”
The Alicante Observatory, where the trademark registry is already successfully managed, will reveal with figures truths that are not so evident to everyone.
The Observatory will propose and, above all, inform about the situation in the sector and the compliance with the regulations.
In addition, the text includes an additional guarantee for data protection.
As the Observatory will be a meeting point between the public and private sectors, its composition is key.

I have therefore insisted on the inclusion of creatives to consider the dimension of employment especially, and the annual examination in the management report of the existence of a balanced representation of the actors involved.
The observatory will undoubtedly be a very important piece in the essential monitoring of the respect for intellectual property.

Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, we know that without young people there is no future and we are also certain that with the high rates of youth unemployment, Europe can be unsustainable.

It is a priority to provide solutions, solutions that will not come with labor reforms such as the one approved last Friday in my country, which will lead our young people to more labor precariousness and the demolition of rights.
The reality is that Europe has a youth unemployment rate of around 23%.
In my country, Spain, it affects 49% of young people, many of them educated, prepared and talented, who have been expressing their weariness and frustration due to the lack of solutions.
We share the urgency of approving measures to boost youth employment and help SMEs, especially those created by young people.
For this reason, I consider it a priority to adapt training to the job market, understanding that a training system with more equity in the quality of education and that puts an end to the
The differences between public and private education will serve to stimulate creativity and innovation, thus increasing the entrepreneurial spirit, specialization and mobility of students.
Could the Commission explain how the 10,700 million euros that the Commission has estimated to correspond to Spain will be distributed among the different funds?
As for the European Social Fund, what percentage of the 82 billion euros that are still to be allocated will go to this fund?
Specifically, in the case of Spain, what is the percentage?
And lastly, how does the Commission intend to integrate regional and local authorities and social partners into the action plans?
I hope, Mr. Commissioner, for a quick, decisive and viable action from the Commission, because there is not a single day to lose.
Thank you, Madam President. I welcome the election yesterday in the primaries of Governor Capriles as the candidate of the United Democratic Opposition of Venezuela.
Votes so that alternation can occur, if the Venezuelans so desire, in that beloved country, with electoral guarantees that are comparable to those in a democracy.
Democracy. Good luck, Venezuela.
Thank you, Mr. President. In addition to the 80 million poor people we are talking about, there are 43 million more people who have difficulty consuming animal protein twice a week.
This situation could also worsen because those who have difficulties in consuming proteins twice a week could join the group of the desperate, since the economic crisis
It is getting worse, and this is not the best time for the European Union to make budget savings in food aid in view of the next financial perspective period.

The agreement signed by the European Parliament extends food aid under the conditions requested by this very Chamber, but this also implies a certain resignation in the face of the blockade that some Member States have maintained for several months in the Council.
I would like to encourage all the ladies to take the necessary initiatives to revive food aid from 2014 onwards.
The European Parliament should not stand idly by in the face of such an important humanitarian issue.
We should not allow things to remain as they are, so we should take advantage of the negotiations of the next financial perspective period to express our opinion.
...respect and force an agreement with the Council of Ministers and this Parliament to allow the preservation of aid to the poorest beyond that date.
Thanks to European aid, food banks have done remarkable social work, which should not be paralyzed by the selfishness of some governments.
This work has benefited 13 million people and, thanks to it, with minimal effort, we have managed to make the Common Agricultural Policy a little more important.

Mr. President, the regulation we are debating today is not perfect. It cannot, on its own, solve the problems of a sector with structural problems and also because of the economic context we are living in with conjunctural problems.
But this regulation, although not perfect, is a step forward, a firm one and in the right direction.

Because if in the last period we have all realized that there is no perfect market, it was very necessary to introduce into this board, where we are also playing with people's food security, all the regulatory elements that we could and protection for our producers.

It was very necessary that we allow the mandatory nature of contracts with a minimum time and a maximum volume, at least as a defense instrument, because of course our producers do not start with the same negotiating strength against distribution, intermediaries or resellers.
There are many things left to do.
We must improve the safety nets and make them more agile and effective.
We should bet on further strengthening the sector in the value chain, control that there is no distribution of quotas, especially in certain areas, or promote the quality policy.

But without a doubt, with our positive vote and with everything that remains to be done, today many livestock farmers will be able to see this Parliament that has defended their labour right, the most basic of all, which is the right to live with dignity from the income of their work.
B has correctly pointed out the disastrous consequences that the approval of this agreement would entail.
Because this agreement, which expands the quotas for certain horticultural products, when the figures of the current agreement are not respected, is absolutely meaningless.

It is worth remembering that the Spanish Federation of Producers and Exporters of Fruits and Vegetables filed a complaint with the Petitions Committee of this Parliament about the massive entry of tomatoes through Perpignan at a price below the market price in the agreement.
Illegal situations such as the one described put the European farmer in a competitive disadvantage.
It should be added that our farmers must comply with strict quality, environmental and social standards that are not always respected by our Moroccan partners.
To conclude, I will mention the issue of the Sahara.
According to the United Nations Charter, the Sahara is an autonomous territory and the exploitation of its resources must benefit the local population.
It is also an area over which the UN does not recognize the sovereignty of the Kingdom of Morocco.
From the European Union, we must ensure compliance with international law.

I am in favor of an agreement with Morocco, in favor of an agreement that establishes rigorous control mechanisms from the European Union in relation to quotas and prices, an agreement that fights against dumping, that does not exploit the Moroccan farmer and, above all, that dignifies our European farmers.
It is certainly not this agreement.

Last year, the European Parliament's Petitions Committee requested that the European Commission modify the regime of entry prices for fruit and vegetables in the Union, a regime that is facilitating the fraudulent entry of products from third countries, as stated by the Union's own anti-fraud agency, OLAF.
They are mainly Moroccan tomatoes.
The same request was included in a statement signed last year by the governments of Spain, France and Italy.

This fraud is fixed by modifying the regulation of the application of the Common Organization of the Market of Agricultural Products, because the alignment of the Customs Code does not fix the problem, Mr. Commissioner.

For several years now, I have been advocating within the Popular Party the need to halt new concessions to Morocco until the European Union is equipped with the necessary tools to ensure compliance with the agreement in force.
The European Commission argues that it is the Member States who must ensure the control of imports.

However, what the Commission does not say is that the current entry price regime prevents national customs authorities from correctly tracking the prices declared by importers to check for irregularities.

If we modify the regulation for the application of the CAP, we will have solved part of the problem, because if not, the legal loophole in the European regulation prevents national authorities from doing their job properly.
Again, dear colleagues, the debate on a summit.
Many have been celebrated, all announced with great fanfare, trying to create an expectation that is less and less each day.
They are losing credibility because they are not contributing to solving the crisis.
Summits where the same agreements are reiterated over and over again.

It must be known that while there is no progress in the political union and in strengthening this Parliament and the executive power of the European Commission, summits will be repeated, but the economic crisis will worsen.
In a telegraphic way, two ideas. The first, the need to insist that responsible solidarity and the fulfillment of duties are the
The first one is the materials with which Europe is built. The second one is that the use of structural funds that are not disbursed is authorized immediately.
These amounts can easily be used to fight the unemployment figures of young European citizens.

Madam President, from the European Parliament I would like to pay tribute today to all women, who, despite the fact that we have come a long way since that March 1911, when women took to the streets to demand the vote and better working conditions, I believe that women's equality is still a long way off.
Today, women can work without having to ask anyone for permission, but in many cases they still earn less than men for similar work, which is unacceptable.
We must also remember rural women, whose work is ignored.
I believe that another uncomfortable reality, but one that we must continue to denounce, is violence against women.

This year alone there has been an excessive number of women murdered, not to mention the serious threats from those who believe they have the right to exercise physical or psychological violence against them.
It is time to say enough is enough and to say it loud and clear.
From this Parliament, I reiterate my commitment to the European Protection Order and to the Victims' Directive presented by the Commission and which will be voted on, God willing, next June.
