We also have to say, and I would like to remember, that motherhood continues to be an obstacle for women's advancement and I believe that this is a trend that should be changed.
I want to send a message of hope and with many women, with the help of more and more men, we have to move forward on the path of equality, of opportunities, rights and also of duties.
We have come a long way, but there is still much to do.
I have to admit that I do not believe in quotas at all and in a profound way, but I have to tell you that something has to be done and I agree with
Many of my colleagues and, of course, Mrs. Reding, to open this debate and to move forward on this path so that women can recover the place they deserve, and you can count on my help.

Mr. President, in a context of economic crisis and budget cuts that is affecting public health, and in which, as in the community where I live, research centers such as the Príncipe Felipe, specialized in diabetes, are left without funds, this resolution comes at a better time than ever. It is absolutely appropriate.

We need a common European strategy against diabetes and we need a recommendation from the Council that tells the States that they have to increase research, even with stem cells, that they have to coordinate their results to optimize them, that they have to establish programs of healthy habits of food and life.

In short, we must put people's health above other things, and in this case, investigating, coordinating and making national programs coordinated by the Commission and demanding results on diabetes is to guarantee the quality of life of Europeans and to guarantee their own lives.

If we dedicate more money to this, some will take a little longer to collect, but surely those who have problems now will have a better quality of life and we will be, as states, as a council and as a commission, fulfilling one of the obligations we have, which is to look after the health of our citizens.
Mr. President, of the many issues raised by this debate, I would like to highlight the emissions rights market. A market that was born with defects, certainly,
But today, the limitation of rights and the economic crisis have meant a drastic reduction in the price of carbon. That is, the price is so low that it is cheap to pollute.
It is therefore urgent to reform the design of a policy on that market, because its deterioration threatens all green efforts, all the green policy of the European Union.
If emission rights are not valued, it is encouraging an increase in emissions. Polluting industries will not invest in new techniques, and what is worse,
Important projects, such as those related to energy efficiency or carbon storage plants, will be put at risk.
This is the risk.
It is up to us, the Commission and the Parliament, to swear it.
Mr. President, few are the refugees permanently resettled in Europe.
My country, Spain, has just begun the experience.
However, the cases are of urgent need.
The deputies have confirmed this on the ground, on a trip to the Iraqi camps of Palestinian origin in Syria. Also, the news that reached us immediately from Tunisia.
Another more institutional aspect is the balance of power between the Parliament and the Council.
Our opponent, the valiant Ruiz Tavares. There are many good parliamentarians, but few with the tenacity of Ruiz.
Tavares has fought for the European Parliament to maintain the new powers it gained after the approval of the Treaty of Lisbon.
I cannot forget the permanent work carried out by UNHCR, without which success would not have been possible.
UNHCR has made us all aware of the urgency of the report so that the funds can be used as soon as possible, now that they are so needed.
And lastly, thank you very much, Commissioner, and I hope that we also give you and your good heart the satisfaction of moving forward the asylum package next month.

The European social model that we are so proud of is not only based on our pension, education and health systems, but also on a way of understanding the balance between employers and workers within companies.

The labor reform approved by the Spanish government without dialogue and without consensus breaks with that social model and moves us away from the objectives of the 2020 Strategy, both in terms of job creation and in terms of its quality.
A labor reform by itself does not create jobs, economic growth does.
What a labor law does is define the conditions under which workers enter companies, the conditions under which they remain in them and the conditions under which they leave them.
And with this reform, where 80% of workers will be unprotected because they will not be subject to collective agreements, where they can be fired for a decrease in the company's income or the

They will be able to unilaterally modify their schedules. What is clear is that workers will enter with greater precariousness, will remain in the labor market with more fear and will leave it with less compensation.

That is why this reform, which attacks the European social model and bets on the competitiveness of the Spanish economy only in relation to the conditions of the workers, deserves a general strike like the one called tomorrow in Spain in defense of this social model.

Mr. President, Mr. Barroso, the Spanish delegation of the European People's Party considers it appropriate and endorses the two packages you have presented today, both the labor package and the solidarity aid to Greece, which has a lot to do with the coherence of your proposal.
It is undeniable, ladies and gentlemen, that we are going through difficult times and the events of each day remind us that the crisis is still far from being resolved.
Attention has inevitably turned back to Spain.
The alarms have been unjustifiably triggered in the markets, partly encouraged by statements that, in my opinion, Mr. President, are untimely.
One is in the context of important elections, in which one and the other contender cite my country as a dialectical element of confrontation.
Of course, we do not appreciate any of the references.
On the other hand, to divert attention from their own problems, they also meddle in our affairs with little political tact.
Today, some people here have not been tactful, as the Italians would say, and there have been some political indiscretions.
Ladies and Gentlemen, the situation in the markets does not reflect the strength of Spain.
We are a solvent country and have the full capacity to face our debts.
The Spanish debt continues to be lower than the European Union average, and the Spanish government is fully committed to meeting the deficit targets agreed with the European Union.
Mr. Esbóveda, Mr. Rajoy has never said that he cannot meet the objectives set by the European Union.
He said the exact opposite, that he is willing to meet each and every one of those goals, and he repeats it every day.

The Spanish government, in the few months it has been in charge of the Executive, has adopted and will continue to adopt very ambitious measures to ensure fiscal consolidation and lay the foundations for an improvement in competitiveness, job creation and growth.
The IMF's forecasts, by the way, from yesterday, the IMF itself admits that they are prior to the analysis of the decisions and measures taken by the Spanish government at present.
Other measures we have adopted: the General State Budget for 2012, which in our opinion will ensure that the deficit target is met this year; the Organic Law on Budgetary Stability.

It will present a reform of education and health, which will entail an adjustment of 10,000 million euros. The reform of the financial sector will also contribute, without a doubt, to financial institutions having to provide more than 50,000 million.
In summary, Spain is meeting the objectives set by the Union and the Commission, and what we ask for is responsibility from everyone.

It is necessary that we all save ourselves together, and Spain with everyone, without a doubt, and criticism from one or the other does not contribute anything, or we are all countries capable of being together and contributing to growth and to the new path, or otherwise it will be difficult for us to move forward in the terms that the Commission proposes.
You are going to be the protagonist, Mr. Rajoy, the President of the Government.
I think it's fine. I wouldn't have any inconvenience.
But Mr. Rajoy is not the protagonist of the crisis.

The protagonist of the crisis is the inheritance received by the Spanish socialist, communist and green left, which has left the worst inheritance that any government has ever left, when they received the best inheritance that any government has ever had.
Mr. President, this morning I read in an important German newspaper the news that Spain and Argentina have a conflict related to an oil company.
This is precisely the wrong way to approach the matter.
The conflict is between Europe and Argentina, and beyond, with that great European value, which is legal security and its respect in international trade relations.
European institutions have excellent lawyers who can find the appropriate instruments in original or derived community law to neutralize the arbitrariness of Argentine authorities.
I am a modest professor of public law and I offer to collaborate with them.
The credibility of the European Union in the eyes of its citizens is at stake at this moment.

Thank you, Mr. President. From the Agriculture Committee, we share the final objective of this directive, which is to try to guide the composition of our energy mixes from tax imposition. But we are facing a very complex debate.

Full of edges in the economic, social and also environmental aspects. It is important to maintain those balances that make us progress more in the environmental aspect, yes, but that also do not harm us economically and that do not create greater social crises than those we are already experiencing.
This is the case of agriculture.

As everyone knows, energy costs are increasingly becoming a very important part of the fixed costs of our agricultural operations. At a time when, moreover, we are in a debate in which the crises of the raw materials markets are combined with a perspective of aid requests and an increase in health and environmental requirements that make their margins of profitability.
That is why we have basically asked for two things.

The first one is the maintenance of zero deductions in the energy component, now linked to the drafting and compliance of energy efficiency and saving strategies in the rural environment, and the incorporation of the
Agriculture is considered one of the sectors at risk of carbon leakage, so it can also access the allowances permitted in the CO2 emissions phase.
That is, a more environmentally demanding policy, but that maintains those balances that make our rural environment viable at a time of changes and uncertainties in it.
We are living through a great controversy that has as its indispensable references the concepts of austerity and growth.
If you listen to the noise that is being made, it would seem that the idea of growth is a recent invention.
Nothing could be further from the truth.
Since 1997, the Stability and Growth Pact has been in force in Europe.

That is why a large part of the policies carried out by European institutions, such as those of regional cohesion and research, are policies aimed at growth and that seek the development and well-being of citizens.

Therefore, and I address the Commission and the members of this Parliament who have the most chances of being heard, no complexes on our part when it comes to being in that debate, which we can face with our heads held high.
This is my minority opinion among the non-registered.

Thank you very much, Madam President. First of all, allow me to thank all my colleagues and especially the rapporteurs in the shadows for their help in this report, which has made this report much stronger.

We all know that the 20th anniversary of the launch of the Single Market is being celebrated, which should be the driving force of economic activity and growth in Europe, key to getting out of the crisis and achieving the objectives of Europe 2020.
In these 20 years, the construction of the internal market must be made compatible with its development, with a broad framework of consumer protection, growth and rights that generate dynamism.
Transparency, a basic principle of democracy and good governance, which Commissioner Barnier referred to this afternoon, and cooperation between the Commission and the Parliament.
It is now time to develop the regulatory framework for the protection and empowerment of consumers, and particularly vulnerable consumers.
We know that the diversity of vulnerability situations, both endogenous and exogenous, makes it difficult to adopt a global legislative instrument.
This forces us to address the problem of vulnerability from a cross-sectional analysis that takes into account the different needs, abilities and circumstances of consumers.
The Commission, aware of the current shortcomings, has focused its strategy on improving consumer information and education.
Being an ambitious proposal, it is not enough to protect vulnerable consumers, because their vulnerability arises precisely from their lack of assertiveness and understanding of the issue.
the information they receive or the options available to them or their ignorance of the existing complaint and compensation systems, especially in the case of cross-border and online consumption.

It is for all these reasons that, in order to solve the deficiencies, that is, the problems, it is necessary to adopt a strategy to strengthen vulnerable consumers and that both the Commission and the Member States introduce specific measures in their legislation to ensure adequate protection.

It should go beyond mere information, especially in those areas where the level has been shown to be higher and where the highest number of consumer complaints are registered. The financial sector, whose complexity implies that any consumer can potentially be vulnerable.

For this reason, the financial services industry is asked to redouble its efforts to provide understandable, truthful information, with clear explanations and direct language about the nature of the products and services it offers. The food sector, in relation to advertising...

Foods with high fat, salt and sugar content and children and young people, who are the most sensitive to the advertising of these foods. The transport sector, which often has difficulties when vulnerable people travel. The energy and telecommunications sector.

Where the lack of transparency causes, in some cases, an added difficulty for consumers. For example, in the energy sector, when determining the rate that best suits their needs. In access to justice, where consumers may find difficulties in accessing the mechanisms.
Existing.
Therefore, I ask the Commission and the Member States, and allow me to make a call to the Spanish Minister of Justice, Mr. Gallardón, not to step back on rights.
and go in the opposite direction to the march of these difficult times. Putting intelligence and good government in favor of an alternative resolution of disputes in consumer matters.
Lastly, to conclude, any of us can become vulnerable consumers. Thank you very much and thank you to all the SADOs for the help provided in reinforcing this report.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I must say that I feel a sense of despair, almost of frustration, that I must share with someone.
Will you allow me to do it this afternoon with you?

This is the third or fourth debate we have had in this Chamber recently on the situation of youth unemployment in all of Europe, and debate after debate, while youth unemployment rates are soaring, in some Member States we are close to 50%.

50% of the active population rate, while many of them are already left without any kind of social coverage or unemployment. While all this is happening, while we go from a situation that evolves from worrying to...

From unsustainable to dramatic. The Commission presents itself once again in this Parliament, in this Chamber, as if it were a political commentator, as if it were just another analyst, and not as the true government of the Union, which is what it is, and what we need.

Mr. Commissioner, governing is about setting priorities. Governing is about setting priorities, taking the initiative, and with the objective of achieving some goal, some objective. And, moreover, the Commission is not doing that.

Governing is not about simply restructuring funds, not even about doing it, announcing it, to save face in the eyes of public opinion, but about raising an ambitious, lasting and rapid strategy to end youth unemployment.

To govern is not to resign oneself to a youth unemployment rate of over 20% and to be satisfied with a pilot project of 4 million euros, which is ridiculous given the situation, given the magnitude of the problem we are facing.

To govern, not to give in to the pressures of the Commissioners' College or other Member States of the Council, who are trying to convince us that we will only get out of this financial crisis, of this new wave of recession, by giving up wages, labor rights or compensation, that we only have a future of precariousness as a generation.

Because if this were true, Mr. Commissioner, that we only gain competitiveness through precariousness and that we will only be more competitive if we are more precarious, then Zimbabwe would be the most competitive country, and it is not.
These are Sweden, Finland and Denmark, which are precisely characterized by a model of labor relations and a model of labor rights and guarantees.
Mr. President, employment is much more than a citizen's right. It is a tool for bonding with the system, it is a tool for social integration.

And therefore, the more unemployment, the greater the political disaffection. And that is why, Mr. Commissioner, it is of no use to me that you talk about issues of competence to do nothing in relation to youth unemployment.

Because, moreover, Mr. Commissioner, when you have had to interpret the treaties loosely to create, for example, the Financial Stability Fund, you have done so. And when you have had to reform the treaties to comply with or satisfy the whims of some Member State in terms of austerity, you have also done so.
So, what do I want to tell you?
For example, there is the youth employment guarantee. It is not necessary to explain it.

Fight to increase the budget. Use, if necessary, the European Social Fund as an instrument. Design an application mechanism with financing and solidarity that helps more those who have more unemployment. Pressure to change even more this policy of social asphyxia in the countries that are having the worst time. And remember that behind each figure there is a person who is having a hard time.
Then, you will think like me that the least is not the one who is in charge, because for the whole of the citizens, especially
Thank you, Madam President, Mr. Commissioner. I would like to thank the Inter-Committee for the work done, the speakers and the shadow speakers.

In general, we are facing a good regulation of the SG+, necessary, specifically in some actions to control the norms of imports of textile products that could harm the production of the European Union.
But we are concerned about the exclusion, starting in 2014, of the SPG from certain countries that are classified as upper-middle income countries, such as, for example, Latin American countries.
Because what happens with these middle-income countries that have little diversified exports?
Diversified. Why not introduce a diversification criterion for exports?

Because in this case, two speeds could be produced. Countries like Costa Rica, Cuba, and Ecuador would benefit from this, differentiating themselves from potentially developed countries like China and Brazil.

Therefore, I believe that we should support a transition period and that amendments will be presented with this transition period to adapt to this situation in these countries and to give the possibility of opening negotiations and trade agreements with them so that they can benefit from it.

I already supported the report by Ms. Nadezhda in the Congo mission, together with other parliamentarians, and I did indeed see that there are few peoples with a greater manifest will to make democracy and participate in it.
But a people, to believe in democracy, also needs to believe in its state and its government. And that will not be possible only with electoral support or with external support.
They also need a demand for the fight against corruption and to break the indecent paradox of living in misery in one of the richest countries in the world in terms of resources.

And we have to decide and denounce that part of the violence they live is imported, or at least fostered by those unscrupulous multinationals that from Europe or other continents or other states are capable of participating in corruption, without forgetting to foster the fights for those resources to gain the favor of those who direct some territories.

That is why, Mr. Astrón, even though it is not within your absolute competence, I do say that a greater demand for traceability and transparency from European multinationals and others from other continents that collaborate there would be as useful for the development of that people as the help we can provide them at the electoral and technical level.
Mr. President, to the speakers for the valuable work they have presented.
Colleagues, we are now debating package 2, after having approved package 6, after almost all the heads of state and government agreed on two international treaties outside the order.
community, after other many European regulations have created more community authorities for banking supervision, stock market, insurance, for the risks of the economic system.
A deployment of texts and more texts, of reports, of proposals that address new economic valuation criteria, new procedures, new processes.
We should not stop and apply what we already have approved.
In the face of the instability that the European continent is experiencing, what is needed is precisely the opposite: stability and legal security.
We do not need a jumble of successive legal findings.
I don’t know, dear colleagues, if I’m dreaming.
The situation that the rescue implies is very worrying.
The whole truth is not being told to Spanish citizens about the new debt that, by guaranteeing private debt, the Spanish government and state are assuming as public debt.
The Spanish government has requested aid that it previously said it did not want and is presenting it ridiculously as a triumph, as some colleague already warned in this debate.
There is no triumph, only failure with Bankia and the rest.

I insist, there is no more correct politics for Europe than the one sponsored by the French government, behind which we must close parliamentary ranks. We will not get out of debt without harmonious growth for all and for the whole.

Supervision as demanded in both reports, of course, all the supervision that is necessary, but also indispensable simultaneous growth, also anti-speculative, as is also mentioned in some of the measures of both reports and other reports as well.
Please, clarity and transparency as well, balance as my colleague Sánchez Presedo said before.
Madam President, since I entered this Parliament, I have not stopped denouncing female genital mutilation.
That silent and accepted crime that millions of women and girls suffer in the world. 70 million, I repeat, 70 million.
An unbearable figure for those who stop to study the terrible consequences of these practices, which are hidden under the guise of psychological, health, religious reasons, all of them false.

The truth is that the practice of ablation, preferably on girls aged 14 and even one year old, can lead to death from hemorrhagic shock and, in the best of cases, cause and bring about strong psychological sequelae due to the trauma.
From Europe, we must fight with all our might to eradicate this violation of human rights, which violates the right to equality of opportunity and endangers health.
It is a matter, ladies and gentlemen, of mistreatment, cruelty, torture against girls. And that degrading treatment also exists in Europe.
To do this, we must activate all the prevention mechanisms that our legal system has and I encourage our judges to act to prevent female genital mutilation.
of girls in Europe, punishing those who carry it out, so that the law in Europe speaks with one voice when combating mutilation on our soil.
Finally, I ask civil society and NGOs to actively participate in education and prevention campaigns.
There is still a long way to go, but many of us will not stop because we owe it to 70 million mutilated women.
Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. Commissioner, I am fully aware that one of the reasons why we approved the dairy package was to adapt the sector to a market without milk quotas in 2015.

But it is also true that as this liberalization date approaches, uncertainty in the sector increases because it does not see a clear exit strategy. There are also more reasons why the sector demands prudence and reflection in the decision we have to make.

Reasons such as the belief in the maintenance of the rights to plant vineyards or the maintenance of sugar quotas at least until 2020, reasons such as the uncertainty that exists in the sector about the real effects of the dairy package and about whether

We would have had time to make a serious assessment of them and reasons also, such as the uncertainty about where the common agricultural policy is going and especially its budget, that is, about the part of the income that does not come from the markets and that affects our producers.

Therefore, what do we ask of you, Mr. Commissioner, that you convey to Mr. Cholos? That we do not make a piecemeal policy of dismantling our protection system without a serious and rigorous analysis, because the effects on our producers are irreversible.

...postpone the end of the quota until 2015, until a date that gives security to the sector, and open a debate, open and transparent, on the regulation mechanisms, because the markets are still more unfair and the producers are more and more defenseless.
Thank you, Mr. President. Many of the deputies of this Parliament have heard the voice of the citizens, the voice of the street.
Commissioner, you have said that this is a yes or no agreement.
The deputies of this Parliament also have responsibility for the yes or the no.
And we say no because this agreement causes confusion, as is evident.
The intellectual property rights and the rights of Internet users are not clarified.
Do Internet users care about intellectual property rights?
Yes.
Yes, it is a suitable solution.
No, it is not a solution, because there are two issues to address. It is not a legal issue, but two political issues. One, the determination of the fight against falsification and petty crime.
Piracy and another, a new legislative framework for the digital environment, which we have repeatedly requested from the Socialist Group, we are asking for it again.
This is your chance.
Do not turn your back on society because tomorrow it will collapse, even if you don’t want it to, and you will have no way out.
In order to improve, it is sometimes necessary to accentuate the chaos.
The feeling of helplessness was so great that Europe had to react, and it has done so for the good of all. Because the big winner of this past summit has been the euro.
And with this victory, hope has returned that Europe will emerge from its paralysis, moving from reflection to action.
At this summit, Your Lordship, was it necessary to adopt short-term measures to guarantee financial stability, as well as long-term measures to solve the Union’s deficiencies?
In this case, the immediate was essential to continue working in favor of the important.
It is imperative to send a message that the euro is a common, irrevocable and irreversible project.

We welcome, ladies and gentlemen, the important decisions such as the one to enable the European Stability Mechanism to recapitalize banks directly, which will allow us to break the vicious circle between bank debt and sovereign debt, a thesis always defended, by the way, by the current Spanish government.
It will also be used to intervene in the markets in support of the public debt of countries that comply with their commitments to public deficit and reforms.
Those were necessary decisions to ensure financial stability, which must be the top priority of the European Union in the short term.
This is not the time, ladies and gentlemen, for certain countries to resort to nationalist slogans and put obstacles in the way.
I have already said it, now is the time to bet on Europe.
Spain, ladies and gentlemen, has been adopting and implementing in record time the most ambitious reform agenda of Spanish democracy, which includes a deep labor reform.
It is also carrying out a financial reform based on total transparency and all of this demonstrating its commitment to fiscal consolidation and the fulfillment of the deficit objectives.

We also welcome the decision to launch a process for greater economic integration through four blocks: a banking union, a fiscal union, a common economic policy framework and strengthening democratic legitimacy.
Mr. President, the Community has always been, first and foremost, about overcoming crises and emerging stronger from them, and then the European Union.
I am glad that we have achieved it once again.
Dear colleagues, all our attention is focused on banks, which we have heard time and again are the blood of the social body.
This image is probably correct, but we must bear in mind that every body is supported by a spine and joints.
Well, the spine and joints of that social body we call Europe are precisely its transport networks and energy infrastructures.
As it is being said this afternoon here in the hemicycle, it is essential to mobilize private financing and, if necessary, public financing.
It is also an opportunity to promote the issuance of private debt, backed by European institutions, specifically aimed at these purposes and open to any investor.
Congratulations to the speakers for their work and also to the Commission for its clear support of these projects.

Mr. President, dear Commissioner, Minister, in which I greet the new presidency, I am a veteran militant of the disappeared non-aligned movement that led your country and that strongly desires the territorial integrity of Cyprus in the face of military occupations.

Ladies and gentlemen, we should take advantage of the opportunity for a broader reform of the Court, perhaps, but the intention of the Commission and my colleague rapporteur are very positive and should be supported with the unanimity that it had in our Commission.
The agility and good functioning of the court are basic, which I question with the new jurisdiction, now delayed, of patents.
Congratulations to the speaker, go ahead with the reform of the Court.

Thank you, President, Commissioner Reding. My country has experienced too many setbacks since the Popular Party came to power. Repeated and continuous attempts to roll back established rights, such as the gag law for those who dissent, among others, consumer organizations.
The threat to FACUA, trampling, among others, articles 16 and 17 of the Spanish Constitution by the Ministry of Mrs. Mato, is a dangerous attack, not only...

not only to freedom of expression and opinion, but also to the right to a high level of consumer protection, basic principles of democracy and enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.
I therefore ask for the rectification of the government of Mr. Rajoy in the face of the outrage of illegalizing Facua. And I make a call to the Commission to guarantee the protection of the
the rights of Spanish consumers and act against the reduction of the rights and functions of consumer associations that the current Spanish government intends to impose.
Madam President, Commissioner, I would first like to highlight the great work of Ms. McAvan, the rapporteur, and also the rest of the shadow rapporteurs, for having reached this agreement.
agreement in first reading, which was very important since the regulation we had approved in 2010 was coming into force and it was necessary to amend it.
Not because the legislation was bad, the legislation was very good, but as has been said, the recent events, well known to all, occurred and showed that there was a certain...
There was a gap that needed to be corrected so that it would not happen again, and specific points of vigilance and security of the drugs once they were marketed had to be reinforced.
Therefore, from now on, as has been said, the holders of a marketing authorization for a medicine who do not renew, withdraw or request the withdrawal or suspension of the authorization will have...
The obligation to declare the real reasons and the motives that have led to the withdrawal or the suspension of the authorization of a drug.
This is a great achievement in terms of transparency and will prevent the holder of a marketing authorization from trying to hide the true reasons for their decision.
In addition, in the event that any of these transactions is carried out in a third country, all the Member States concerned where this medicine is marketed must be informed.
Everything will improve transparency and security without overloading the European Medicines Agency and the national agencies.

The second important modification that has been achieved is that all authorized products that are subject to a post-authorization safety study are automatically included in a list of products subject to this monitoring.
Lastly, we cannot forget that pharmacovigilance plays a fundamental role and for this reason this plenary must approve this proposal.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. The agreement reached by the Parliament and the Council reflects what the Member States involved approved unanimously in the IMO.
These seas are in a worrying state in terms of acidification.
In addition, their regeneration capacity is very limited.
The required fuels are going to be more expensive and that is why an economic aid for businessmen is foreseen, which is very reasonable.
But some colleagues have tried to apply the requirements for new fuels to all the seas of the European Union.

We would be faced with the paradox that an environmental problem in some countries of the Union is to be solved by creating a major economic problem in the Mediterranean, which does not have that problem, but which has other types of environmental problems whose costs are not intended to be imposed on the rest of the countries.
The treaty is very clear.
Sensitive areas must be protected.
But not all areas are equally sensitive.

Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to thank again all those who have made it possible for this directive to become a reality: the Secretariat, the Commissioner, the rapporteur, all those I may have forgotten, and all the colleagues who have been with us.
I want to tell the victims, all of them, absolutely all of them, without distinction, that for us they and their families have a face, have a name, are real, and precisely in their name

We will work so that this directive does not only remain on paper, but with the commitment and help of Commissioner Reding, which I do not doubt at all, it will have a rapid and effective implementation, which is what we all expect and all the citizens.
Citizen.

I believe that there are different groups of victims who would have liked and still want their own directive, but I will tell you that the directive we will vote on tomorrow does not forget any victims and therefore does not forget them either.
And I am sure that this is a first and important step, which will be followed by many other steps that will open those doors of justice that have been closed for too long to the victims.
When I am asked in my country what I do in Europe, I can say with great pride that I am legislating in favor of victims.
And that work, personally, deeply honors me. And it gives me a lot of strength to keep working.

I am sure that with the support and commitment not only of those of us who work here in Europe, but also in our countries, we will all manage, and also with the help of Your Lordship, to bring the victims out of that unfair oblivion.

Thank you, Mr. President. Colleague Turmes has done an admirable job because to move forward a regulation like this, the courage of this rapporteur was needed, who has known how to neutralize the obstacles, many and skillfully placed.
It was worth it because energy efficiency and savings are requirements of any energy policy worthy of the name.

We must congratulate ourselves on important measures such as the requirement to renovate public buildings, the imposition of a percentage of accumulated energy savings on energy companies, as well as mandatory audits for large private companies.
Now, the work of Turmes and the rest of the speakers will be of no use if it is not accompanied by a determined action from the Member States.
An action that, in turn, must be accompanied by the firm commitment to these objectives of the regions, the municipalities and the European citizens.
I would like to highlight the participation of the latter.
At the moment, what is noticed is a lot of frivolity among the authorities and among the citizens.
Citizens, don’t we see, dear colleagues, in the harsh European winter, people sitting in the street terraces with heating?
Friend Turnes, we must not spare efforts to save energy.
We must congratulate the rapporteur, Aira H. García, for the work she has done and congratulate the agreement reached between the Parliament and the Council of Ministers.
It is a shame that the Council is not joining us tonight.
The new quality scheme for agricultural products means a simplification of the system and a streamlining of the existing authorization procedures, and that is good news.

Moreover, it is a good achievement that the obligation to use the community logo for the designations of origin and the protected geographical indications has been included, as this allows to improve the visibility of European productions.
I also believe it is worth noting that the provisions for the protection of quality appellations are strengthened in bilateral agreements with third countries and a legal basis is created for the
to defend the European Union logo in those third countries, because I sincerely believe that the protection of European products in third countries must be a non-negotiable objective.

It is a shame that during the negotiation this package was left a little bare, and it is a pity, I say again, that the Council is not here to listen to it, because the original quality package proposed by...

The Commission has somewhat forgotten the commercial standards and the management of the supply by the quality denominations of origin, which have been left out of the agreement and, as I say, leaving it somewhat empty.
I believe that the Council's stubbornness in these two matters must be highlighted, as it has refused to listen to the Parliament's reasonable positions.
The management of the supply by the designations of origin should have been defended and is defended, of course, in the OCM.

Thank you, Mr. President. The trade agreement with Central America, Colombia and Peru is an important agreement and the safeguard clause, what it tries to do, and with the amendments that we have presented, is to make it easy, agile and to provide guarantees.

We have presented amendments to protect European production in accordance with the treaties and we have established safety mechanisms for both European production and production in the countries where the agreement is established.
The protection of the outermost regions is necessary because they are not diversified crops, for economic reasons, because it affects a large number of people.
More than 10,000 direct jobs and 35,000 indirect jobs in Spain, in a population that is very affected by unemployment and, due to its specificity,
For example, the Canadian potato has a great specificity in agriculture, culture and gastronomy.

But it is also necessary there, where we are going to establish the agreement, in Central America, Colombia, Peru, because trade is fundamental for development, and development is labor rights, sustainability and benefits for the producer.

The rapporteur's work, Mr. President, is very good, but I want to take this opportunity to say here, in this context, that our prose is very confusing, as anyone who approaches European legislation can see.
We have forgotten what Pufendorf already taught us, that general laws must be few and their meaning must be correctly understood.
For this reason, those who promulgate them must use all the clarity possible.
Montesquieu always insisted that legal language must be precise and concise.
That is, we must avoid esoteric wordiness, full of neologisms and unjustified linguistic borrowings, because it generates a malignant network where traps are laid and arbitrariness is established.
We deal with very complex issues in this Parliament, but it is our duty to make them understandable and accessible to the citizens.
It is common for even legal professionals, judges, and lawyers to despair at our texts.
Good prose, dear colleagues, is the courtesy of the legislator and a way to show his respect for the citizen.
Mr. Deputy, you have just spent the little time you had insulting and disqualifying from the most absolute ignorance.
Ignorance. Do you know the Spanish Constitution?

Because what the Vice President, Mr. Vidal Quadras, has said is nothing more than applying what is stated in the Spanish Constitution. The rest are singular personal opinions that are absolutely irrelevant and that I can respect but that I despise.
Mr. President, there is a long-standing principle that has moved from the legal to the political sphere, and that is pacta sunt servanda. In other words, agreements are made to be fulfilled.
I am referring to the important measures adopted by the European Council in June to solve the crisis that affects us.

Since the adoption of these agreements, the pressure from the markets has eased and they have positively received decisions that can break the vicious circle between banks and sovereign debt, as well as the plans to move forward towards a genuine economic and monetary union and the commitment to defend the euro in an irreversible way.
The European Council held last week contains, ladies and gentlemen, undeniable positive aspects. The conclusions of the progress towards the banking union are satisfactory.
The agreement of 27 is also positive for the implementation of the banking supervisor. Finally, it is appropriate that the implementation is entrusted to the ministers of economy of the Eurozone.
But they will allow me to make a critical judgment with the biased interpretations that have been made of it in a unilateral way.

It is not acceptable, ladies and gentlemen, to make particular interpretations that can distort the mandate given to the ministers of economy, nor do we applaud the fact that matters that were not even discussed are reported as agreements.
It is urgent to advance towards a single supervisory mechanism that must cover all financial entities.
A common deposit guarantee scheme and a crisis resolution mechanism are also needed.
The survival of the euro is linked to the urgent creation of an effective banking union.
Thank you very much, Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner. The advantages of the internal market are undeniable: increased competition, greater supply of products and services.
services, creation of new jobs, more affordable prices for consumers and greater protection, still not enough and we cannot fall into complacency.
However, cultural, linguistic, protectionist and bureaucratic barriers prevent citizens and companies from fully benefiting from the single market.
A year and a half ago, we celebrated the presentation of the 12 priorities to stimulate growth and strengthen citizens' confidence in the internal market.
Unfortunately, an agreement has not yet been reached on most of the proposals, as the Commission acknowledged in its communication last week.

Ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the urgency of the crisis forces us to be ambitious, to go much further and to reach agreements as soon as possible to boost growth, employment and the confidence of citizens and businesses in the single market.
Mr. President, I also want to congratulate the rapporteur and the rest of the colleagues who have worked on this reform very appropriately.

The financial crisis has been exacerbated by the existence of complex and strange negotiable values linked to derivative instruments and transactions outside official markets, all with the aim of achieving high returns at high speed.
It is necessary to attract financial operations to a transparent market to guarantee the good formation of prices and the competition of tradable products.
But above all, it is essential that the information provided is understandable to investors, who must have full knowledge in order to give their free consent to the risks they assume.
Transparency is of no use as a great flash of light if the confusion in the configuration of tradable products blinds the understanding of citizens.
I like Mrs. Thyssen's report because I believe that anything that strengthens the role and authority of this Parliament in the political debate is moving in the right direction.
We hear the accusation against European institutions for their lack of democratic quality too often.
This is a statement made in passing, and this is not the occasion to enter into this debate.

Yes, to highlight that this Parliament has the same legitimacy as any national Parliament, and it is even likely that, compared to some, this one is governed by more transparent rules and also allows greater freedom to its deputies.
That is why all economic measures must pass through the filter that this Parliament represents, before their final approval and then when examining their execution and results.
The group of experts appointed to verify in the States the compliance with the conditions imposed by the Community authorities and the representatives of the
The stability mechanism must appear in this House so that the deputies can have comprehensive information and first-hand information.
Mr. President, 5.3% of the active population works in the automotive sector.
The numbers speak for themselves.
The drop in sales in the European Union market, together with the business strategy, has led to the outsourcing and restructuring of companies in general.
There is an overcapacity crisis that currently affects 10 assembly plants and potentially 100,000 workers.
Unfortunately, there are few cases of restructuring with a long-term vision. Generally, a short-term vision prevails, in which the main element is to gain competitiveness through labor adjustments.

I have to say that on the same day that Ford announced the suspension of the plant in Genk, it also announced to the company in Valencia that its production would be transferred to Germany, in the same business statement.

Therefore, we believe that it is a general problem in Europe, we believe that it is essential to create a legal framework at the European level that anticipates changes and underlines the importance of social dialogue.
Social dialogue is essential.
Mr. President, today we are debating four reports that represent a revitalization of our common policy on security and defense.
It is a clear sign of the conviction that our security and defense has a clear European dimension, in the face of the minority Euro-skeptic sectors that also exist in this Chamber.
The report by Mr. Danjan, to whom I would like to thank for his spirit of seeking consensus during its preparation, contains important contributions from the Socialist Group.
among others, references to effective multilateralism, the principle of the responsibility to protect or the concept of human security.
We would like to see these aspects included in the possible review of the European Defense Strategy.
We have also pointed out that a strong common policy of security and defense is also of interest to our transatlantic alliance.
I must highlight another challenge that is gaining significant importance for our global security.
It is about cybersecurity and cyberdefense. A report that we also discussed today and whose suggestions we hope will be included in the new European cybersecurity strategy.
In a context of severe economic and financial crisis, in which the Member States are being forced to cut their defense budgets, is when European projects are most needed.
That is why it is more important than ever to reinforce the role of the European Defense Agency, which is being heavily questioned today.
I conclude by stating that we can relaunch European security and defense and do so with the project of President Van Rompuy for the December 2013 Council.
Thank you very much to the four speakers.
Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, once again the defense of the general interests defended by the Commission and the Parliament clashes with national egos that are entrenched in the Council.
From the prior acceptance of the legitimacy of both positions, it is inexcusable to reach a balance.
The relevance of the next financial framework is undeniable.
The Spanish delegation of the PPE, and I on its behalf, reiterate that the proposal of the Presidency is, in our opinion, unacceptable.
A cut of 75 billion euros on the already inevitably scarce proposal of the European Commission is sterile and useless.
And that's not all. The new blow to agricultural and cohesion policies means crossing the red line that Spain has drawn since the beginning of the work.
Ladies and gentlemen, it is not time to discuss a supposed dichotomy between austerity and growth.
Some of us are making proven efforts and sacrifices to correct the deficit.
But Spain, like so many other countries, needs to grow, increase economic activity and create jobs.
And with this budget, you won’t get anywhere. On the contrary, it’s a torpedo to the waterline.
Ladies and gentlemen, it is not possible to achieve more Europe with many fewer resources, and above all, if what there is is distributed unfairly.

If this is the case, Spain will oppose a financial framework for the European Union that plainly and simply implies the disappearance of growth possibilities and, above all, any trace of solidarity, and this is precisely the direction that the European Council is taking.
Fortunately, this is not the path that the Commission is indicating, to whom we must thank for their efforts in indicating a different route.

At this point, in the need for unity, in the need for shared efforts, I want to thank Mr. Barroso for making a clear statement the other day in Cádiz, interpreting the treaties for a supposed secessionist in the bosom of the Union.

He made it clear, unequivocally, as guardian of the treaties, that if a part of a member state separates as an independent state, it is considered a third country and, therefore, the declarations and effects of the treaty itself will not affect it in any way.

I hope, Mr. Vice President, in the absence of the President, that this can be taken into account and that this safe and constant doctrine of the Commission can continue to remain alive for the guarantee of all.
